Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:

Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

This bill amends the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (the act) to create a new class of licence—a temporary community broadcasting licence. The legislation will empower the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to allocate the licences for a maximum period of one year without recourse to the act's planning provisions. The bill also provides for consequential amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1992 to enable the new Australian Communications Authority to issue transmitter licences to these licensees.

No provision exists under the act for temporary community broadcasting licences. The ABA has, instead, provided for test transmissions of 90 days per aspirant per year, by making spectrum available to providers of open narrowcasting services, and issuing temporary apparatus licences, a power delegated to it under the Radiocommunications Act. The situation is far from satisfactory. The ABA has not been able to impose conditions that apply to community broadcasting licensees, for example, community access provisions, and sponsorship announcements limited to four minutes per hour.

Test transmissions have done much to foster the overall development of the community broadcasting sector. There are currently over 140 aspirant community broadcasters seeking a long‐term licence. But limited periods of test transmission have meant that it has become increasingly difficult for these non‐profit aspirants to maintain support from volunteers, sponsors and the local community. Some aspirants may be forced to disband before the ABA has completed the planning process, and allocated long‐term licences.

I am aware that Honourable Senators from both sides of the Senate have registered growing concern at the delays in the planning and allocation process. The ABA expects that Licence Area Planning will not be completed before 1999—a three and a half year slippage. Many markets have no long‐term community broadcasting licensees and many markets have aspirants who have been seeking long‐term licences for over a decade.

The amendments proposed are consistent with the objects of the act: to promote the availability of a diverse range of services; and to promote the role of broadcasting services in developing and reflecting a sense of Australian identity, character and cultural diversity.

The integrity of the current planning process will be maintained. Long‐term licences will not be allocated to community broadcasters before the formal planning process has been completed. After each licence area has been planned, the amendments will ensure that aspirants can continue broadcasting, in accordance with the new provisions, ahead of any further process of varying the Licence Area Plan which may result in more long‐term licences. The primary purpose of these amendments is, however, to enable the introduction of continuous transmissions by aspirants ahead of formal planning.

Many aspirant groups will have the opportunity to commence full‐time broadcasting. It is anticipated that the majority of suitable aspirants will benefit, with access made available to as many as possible. In areas where there is competition for limited spectrum, it is intended that continuous transmissions be made possible through spectrum sharing.

The conditions, content rules and remedial and enforcement mechanisms which apply to long‐term community broadcasting licensees will apply to temporary community broadcasting licensees. The ABA will also have the power to specify the times and the total number of days during which broadcasting will be permitted by the terms of the licence.

Under this bill, temporary licence holders will not have enhanced rights to the allocation of a community broadcasting licence—there will be no mechanism for converting a temporary community broadcasting licence into a community broadcasting licence. The likelihood of an aspirant eventually gaining a long‐term licence will vary from area to area, depending on a number of factors, including both the spectrum made available by the ABA in the planning process and the subsequent evaluation of the merits of applicants in the allocation process conducted by the ABA in accordance with Part 6 of the act.
These amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of the spring sittings 1997.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 June, on motion by Senator Hill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today very briefly to put on record the concerns that I and also my Democrat colleagues have in relation to the participation of young people in the proposed convention. We are very concerned about what we perceive to be a lack of opportunities for younger Australians to be actively involved in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no secret that young Australians, or younger people—those under the age of 30—in this country, are among the strongest supporters of the move towards a republic but, regardless of their views about republicanism or constitutional change, young Australians have a right to be actively involved in this process. So not only should young people have a chance to participate but they should be playing a key role in the upcoming convention.

Young Australians, those under the age of 30, constitute around a third of this country's population, with 30.5 per cent of Australians under the age of 24. Many of us would know that these numbers are not proportionally reflected in decision making bodies or institutions around this country, but 5.5 million young people have their futures and the future of their country wrapped up in the deliberations of that Constitutional Convention. Therefore, I think it is shameful that we are looking at possibly at this stage four younger delegates being appointed—only four. The government pledged that 10 per cent of those appointed delegates would be young people, so that equates to only four young people between the ages of 18 and 25.

I do not think the answer is simply to say that young people can run for election because, as many of us would know, young people traditionally do not fare well in elections. They have a lack of backing from political parties, a lack of resources and even then they are prohibited from running until they reach the age of 18.

The lack of public funding, or indeed an absence of public funding, under these arrangements will also mitigate against young people's participation in the electoral process, not to mention people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds and other traditionally disadvantaged groups who may be unrepresented or under‐represented in political decision making bodies.

A lot of young people will have no say in the actual election process, many of them not being able to vote because they have not reached the age of 18. I understand that the government initially canvassed the idea of extending to 17-year-olds the right to vote for the purposes of this convention. I believe this was discussed at a joint party meeting around May last year, but clearly this plan has fallen through, as did the government's purported commitment to involving young Australians in the so-called people's convention.

I am sad that the government did not take what would have been an unprecedented step, a step that not only would have involved young people in a greater fashion in the constitutional debate but would have demonstrated a commitment to young Australians, their skills, their intelligence, their diversity, their talents at a time when this government seems to be passing proposals and laws that only denigrate and are punitive towards young people.

I wish the four younger appointed delegates all the best with their deliberations and only wish that they were being joined by more of their peers. Again, I do not think young people should simply be tokenly involved in this constitutional process. They deserve a key role.

We should not forget that young people are a heterogeneous group. They are not a generic group. They do not have the same voice, the same views, the same mind. In fact, it is this diversity and difference that deserves to be reflected in the convention, and I think that four younger delegates would hardly allow for a representation of the diversity that we find among young Australians.

I mentioned that young people are among the strongest supporters of a move to a republic. This has been borne out by many surveys and polls. The latest Newspoll shows strong support, around 56 per cent, as a minimum for a move to a republic among 18‐ to 34‐year‐olds. Youth polls done by the Australian Democrats at our annual youth poll actually demonstrate similar levels of concern. This is not because young people support change for change's sake. Many young people take pride in today's nation. They have a strong grasp of who they are and I really believe that it is this strong sense of national identity that no longer makes a British head of state relevant.

The move to an Australian head of state is not anti‐British; it is pro‐Australian. I do not really believe that young Australians fall for some of the ridiculous arguments that I have seen put forward by some who support a constitutional monarchy, that is, that we seek to emulate our American friends or that we seek to appease our Asian neighbours. As I say, young people take pride in their nation today. They do not see this as an anti‐British move.

Finally, one of my favourite quotes—believe it or not—came from Ronald Reagan when he survived an assassination attempt on his life and was being wheeled into the operating room. He turned to the doctors and said, `Please assure me that you are all Republicans.' I am not suggesting that we should take heart from that message and make all a constitutional delegates republicans, but I think we should at least take advantage of the opportunity to shape our own nation's future. We should not be letting others make decisions about our constitution and the future of this country.

We should grasp this opportunity with both hands. But there is little point in being involved in such a process or beginning such a process unless we ensure that all Australians feel that they have a role and are involved in the process of deliberation. That includes people from all backgrounds and cultures, and especially all ages and both sexes. I give my support to constitutional deliberations and the notion of a people's convention, but I put on record today my concerns about the lack of opportunities for young people to participate in that process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech to the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 is well worth going through because of what it shows about the bill and the scheme that has been put together through the bill. The second sentence of the second reading speech says:

SPEECH.PARA: The convention will provide a forum for discussion about whether or not our present constitution should be changed to a republican one.

What that indicates is that this convention in no way will make any binding decisions. It will not determine anything; it will simply be a forum for discussion, although a very important forum. Ultimately, we as a nation must make a decision as to whether or not to become a republic or to remain where we presently are.

The idea of Australia being a republic is one that is now sanctioned by history. As an example, I will quote from a poem by Henry Lawson which was published in the Bulletin on 1 October 1887, almost 110 years ago. It was a poem entitled `A Song of the Republic', and it is worth reading the second verse which goes as follows:
Sons of the South, make choice between
(Sons of the South, choose true),
The Land of Morn and the Land of E'en,
The Old Dead Tree and the Young Tree Green,
The Land that belongs to the lord and the Queen,
And the Land that belongs to you.

Henry Lawson put forward an idea that has been with Australians for over a century and which has been growing in strength. If there is any criticism to be made of Henry Lawson's verse, it is his reference to the `Sons of the South'. These days we would say `Sons and Daughters'. Louisa Lawson, who was a great feminist, one of the great figures in the women's movement and mother of Henry, perhaps would have been disappointed with her son in his use of the word `Son' and not `Sons and Daughters'. But 110 years ago it was reasonable for Henry to go about his task in the way he did and to set out for us the framework of where our nation is heading.

It is quite clear and everybody does agree that ultimately the sentiments put forward by Henry Lawson will come to pass in Australia and Australia will become a republic. The great debate is when and in what fashion. This forum will be another step and a very important step along the road to that objective.
The next point I want to raise relates to a sentence about halfway down the first page of the second reading speech, which says:

. . . matters of national identity should not be party political issues to be fought over . . . by politicians. We are strongly committed to the principle that this is for the Australian people . . . to determine these issues.

As I understand it, that is a statement that politicians should have nothing or very little to do with the convention. If we turn to the second page of the second reading speech it is made quite clear that the government does not intend to keep politicians out of this by any means. The second reading speech says that of the 152 delegates that will be going to this convention, 40 will be parliamentary delegates.

TALK.START.PARA: —All elected at compulsory attendance ballots, too.
—That is right: they will all be elected under a compulsory system. Forty of the 152 delegates will be parliamentary delegates.

BREAK.PARA: The second reading speech says that this convention should not be based on party political issues to be fought over by politicians. Yet over the page, the second reading speech says that there will be 40 parliamentary representatives: 20 from the state and territory parliaments and 20 from the Commonwealth parliament. Of the 20 from the Commonwealth parliament, there will be 12 government, six opposition, one from the Democrats and one Independent. The second reading speech says:
This distribution broadly reflects the representation of parties in the parliament.

That is clearly a selection based on a party political consideration. So, whilst it is said earlier in the second reading speech that matters of national identity should not be a party political issue to be fought over by politicians, the very structure of this convention would seem to contradict that.

In fact, this second reading speech denigrates the contribution that parliamentarians can make and do make by setting out the statement that matters of national identity should not be party political issues to be fought over by politicians. Certainly they should not be fought over, but also certainly they should be discussed and should be debated. They should be debated by politicians, because politicians are people who are elected by the people. This parliament is much more democratically elected and constituted by the democratic process than would be the convention. Indeed, if you look at the convention, half of the delegates will be appointed, and they will be appointed by the government.

I think it is proper that we should say something about the position of parliament. Parliament is a democratically elected institution and does represent the choice of the people. For that proposition I rely on a statement by Sir Winston Churchill made on 11 November 1947 when he was debating the Parliament Bill. He had this to say:

The right hon. Gentleman spoke about Parliament, about the rights of Parliament, which I shall certainly not fail to defend. But it is not Parliament that should rule; it is the people who should rule through Parliament.
Parliament is the vehicle that the people use to manifest their will. He has this to say about that later in his speech:
The object of the Parliament Act, and the spirit of that Act, were to give effect, not to spasmodic emotions of the electorate, but to the settled, persistent will of the people.
That is what parliament should be about, and by and large is about.

This constitutional convention that is to be held does not have, in my view, the same legitimacy as a democratically elected body such as this parliament. One of the main reasons I say that is because this parliament is elected by all the people and by compulsory voting, whereas half of the convention is to be elected by a non‐compulsory secret postal ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission, and that is set out in the second reading speech. The second reading speech goes on to say:
Voting will be open to all those on the electoral roll, and will be voluntary.

In my view, voting in a matter as important as this should be compulsory. It has been said again and again by those who have spoken before me that it is appropriate and proper that voting should be compulsory because it is the civic duty of people to elect the parliament that is to make the laws that are to govern them.
The bill itself talks about the duties that people have in political life. Clause 138(1) of the bill illustrates what I mean. It reads as follows:
A person must not hinder or interfere with the free exercise or performance, by any other person, of any political right or duty that is relevant to an election.

The second reading speech talks about non‐compulsory ballots and voluntary voting. The inference to be drawn from that is that this is a matter of choice; that there is no duty on people to vote and that what all this is about is a matter of right. That being the proposition that the government have put forward, it is surprising to find in their own bill that they are prepared to have people imprisoned for up to six months if they `hinder or interfere with the free exercise or performance' by any person `of any political right or duty that is relevant to an election'.

So if a duty is so important that anybody who interferes with its exercise can be imprisoned for up to six months why is it that that duty does not extend to voting? Surely the most fundamental political obligation that people in this country have is to vote for the people who make the laws that govern the country.I would be interested to hear the parliamentary secretary or any senator from the government side who speaks after me in this debate or during the committee stage explain why the penalty of imprisonment should be imposed on those who interfere with people's duties if there is no duty for them to perform under this constitutional convention, if their duty does not include the obligation to vote which, as I say, is an obligation that is placed on people in respect of electing members to this place and which has been entrenched in our political culture for generations.

This is an important forum. It is a forum that does give a broad range of people an opportunity to make statements about perhaps the great issue that faces Australians at the moment; that is, how they will go forward and what political—and I do not mean party political—form they will use in the future to make laws in this country and what constitutional framework we will operate in. They are great issues. It is important, having gone down this path, that everybody in Australia expresses his or her view as to who should be at this forum to enter the discussions about the great issues that face us. It is appropriate that everybody be obliged to vote for those who are going to go there.

My own belief is that the republic should come sooner rather than later but that it should come by a process where there is as much agreement as possible. There will never be total agreement about that because the nature of political debate is of that kind. I am sure that once a decision for a republic is made, everybody will be unified behind it and it will go forward as a great success. But it is important that the framework of the republic and the coming of the republic are done as well as possible. It is hoped that this forum will make a significant contribution to that process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with mixed emotion that I rise to speak in this debate on the constitutional convention because this bill is a step towards a republic, a step that I rejoice in. It is a policy that the Labor Party pursued and that I personally have greeted with great pleasure and enthusiasm. I take great pride in the constitution. The aspirations of democracy and optimism that it encapsulates, the solid evidence of courage and energy of the founders of our nation, are contained in that document. But it is not inert; it is not to be handed down and to be immutable. It is a living document created to serve Australia and not to be its master.

SPEECH.PARA: It is right and proper to change the constitution as the aspirations of the nation and its citizens change. The constitution has been amended ever since it was enacted. Almost immediately, in the 1920s, there was discussion about how it should be changed. In the 1920s we had the Premiers Conference. This was followed by the royal commission of 1927‐29, the 1934 conference, the 1942 convention, the 1956‐59 constitutional review committee, the 1973‐85 constitutional conventions and the constitutional commission of 1986.

There have been 39 occasions on which section 128 of the constitution has been used to put a referendum to the nation. It has been successful on nine occasions. The interesting thing about the successful amendments is that they were not often brought about by conference or convention. Further, the constitution has been refined and, I would argue, altered endlessly by the High Court since 1901. The reality is that substantially the constitution has been a developing and living document, not one that has been unchanged. So the fears that some might express about abandoning the constitution or modernising it are really not something we should concern ourselves with.

I am of the view that there has been a fundamental change in the views of the Australian people. There has developed a view that Australia should be a republic and that it should happen reasonably quickly. As happened at the beginning of the constitution, when a fundamental change occurs in the views of the Australian people, we, as the leaders of the nation, have a responsibility to put that change into effect.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has obviously heard that change, too. He understands that Australians want a republic, and, after some dillydallying, some toing‐and‐froing, he and his government have decided to put something forward that may at least progress us in that direction. But the sad thing is that this Prime Minister, I believe, is not fundamentally in favour of that change. His views are not that of the general population on this issue. In his heart, he does not understand that a republic is what Australians want. Even though he and his government have put forward this bill, he really hopes that it does not succeed. I think that the terms of this bill reflect that fundamental lack of support for Australia's becoming a republic.

Some of the provisions of the bill are absolutely and completely contrary to the fundamental principles of democracy as practised in Australia. I look in particular at the voluntary voting provisions that are contained in this bill, which I feel are completely abhorrent and contrary to bringing about a result that will really reflect the views of the Australian people.

It is true that compulsory voting is unusual. Australia would be one of the few countries in which it is the situation. I have to say that I do not think this is a difference that condemns Australia or shows its weakness; I think it shows, in particular, the fundamental strength of democracy in Australia and the fact that we practise an extraordinarily inclusive form of democracy, and from it we gain benefits that no other countries do.

From my brief travels around the world, it seems to me that there is a fundamental difference between us and even, say, the democracies of northern America. The USA gives lip service to democracy and has elections but it is not compulsory for people to vote. It is my view that, in that situation, it is often the people who are the worst off in the community who do not express their democratic views. Often it means that the sorts of people who are elected in the United States are skewed towards those who are better off in the community. Of course, the policies that are then developed are skewed in favour of those who are better off.

I do not suggest a lack of goodwill on the part of the members of Congress or the Senate in the USA; I merely suggest that this result is brought about by having non‐compulsory voting. I would suggest to the Senate today that the provision contained in this bill will do exactly the same thing here in Australia. It is a problem and a difficulty that we have avoided to date.

The situation here is that, with their eyes open, this Prime Minister and this government have chosen to put before this Senate a proposition for the election of delegates to the convention which, in my view, is undemocratic under the Australian model. He is attempting to exclude a large number of people who may not, if not required, exercise their responsibility to take part in the democratic process. I believe that he is doing it knowingly, to skew the representation at the convention in favour of those who might be conservative, those who are opposed to change, and those who are not in support of the creation of an Australian republic.

The debate about voluntary voting has gone on for a very long time. In nearly all reports on election issues the matter is raised. But, to date, parliaments wisely have rejected any change to the proposition of compulsory voting. I see no reason why we should make any different choice in this case. I go so far as to say that, without compulsory voting, there will be no democratic process. As for the election of representatives not being democratic, I go so far as to say that the value of this whole convention is brought into question, and it may be that it is of very little value at all.

Sadly, that is not where the lack of democracy in this bill ends. It is exacerbated by the additional provision that voting should be by postal vote. Looking at the report on the bill, the only argument that I can see put forward by the members of the government for this proposal is cost. The cost of democracy is too high for this government to bear. It is really a very sad proposition that they would trade off democracy and the proper development of the constitution—becoming a republic is probably one of the most fundamental steps that we are going to take—because of cost.

I suppose people may think it is silly, but you really have to look at the natural extension of this argument. Are all referendums too expensive? Are all elections too expensive? Wouldn't it be cheaper just to appoint our representatives? Wouldn't it be preferable that we have a system—as some parts of the House of Lords still exercise—of having appointments for life? Wouldn't that be cheaper? There would be no elections at the beginning of or during the appointment of a person elected for life. Of course, if you accept that it is democratic not to have an election, or a proper one, then you must accept that in all cases that is all right—if it is too expensive, you do away with the election.

Postal voting means that those people who have a limited wage; those who do not have a permanent place of abode; those who are homeless; those whose lives are disrupted by family breakdown, drug addiction, unemployment or a death in the family; and those people whose lives are uncertain are disadvantaged because when their voting papers are posted out they may well not be at the address they were at when they first enrolled. They may not, in the difficulties of their lives, have taken the time to notify the Electoral Commission of their change of address. But this Prime Minister and this government think that is all right; that those people can be excluded because, somehow, their views are of less importance than those of other people.

Who else is excluded by postal voting? Those people who have difficulty with the English language because they are immigrants for whom English is their second language or because, through disability or lack of opportunity in education, they are functionally illiterate are disadvantaged by postal voting. Those are the people who would find that rather difficult. But, according to this bill, according to this government and according to this Prime Minister, it is all right if immigrants and those who have difficulty with the written language are excluded. This government feels that their views are of less import ance than those of other people who are in a better financial position. That is a very sad proposition. Democracy, in my view, requires the exercise of everyone's rights and duties to participate in the direction of Australia and in particular in this very important step which is the creation of a republic.

While we are talking about the exclusion of people we should also look at who is going to be included at that convention and at the lack of provision for the representation of a diversity of Australians. It should not just represent one group—the group that Mr Howard sees himself representing. No provision is made in this bill for the proper representation of women at the convention—or other groups either, for that matter. In fact, there is nothing even contained in the preamble that suggests that there should be some sort of broad representation of all the groups that are represented in the Australian community. Again, this is a very sad oversight.

An amendment has been suggested by the Democrats that requires that half the people on a ticket be women. I applaud their objective, as stated by Senator Cheryl Kernot last night, but I cannot see this as being a solution to the problem because, as we all know, if there is a gap many people will fill it. This provision would certainly allow a ticket to run, say, 10 men first and 10 women second, so that even though women were represented on the ticket they would have absolutely no hope of being elected to the convention. If this were to occur it would be trivialising and upsetting for women generally—certainly to me—to see them being used in that sort of way. So I do not think we can see ourselves clear to support that Democrat amendment. Probably privately the Democrats themselves would concede the difficulty with their proposal.

The Labor Party is putting forward a preamble that makes it very clear that it is expected that there will be representation from all sectors of the community in Australia. I suppose to some extent we will be relying on the goodwill of those who are running tickets and those members of the parliaments, both federal and state, who are appointing deleg ates to the convention to ensure that there is broad representation.

The issues that I have raised in my mind suggest that, although this appears to be a democratic attempt to move towards a republic, the bill itself does not satisfy that objective. It does not satisfy that objective because, fundamentally, the coalition does not really aspire to that objective. There may be sections in the coalition and certainly sections within the Liberal Party—I know there are because I have spoken to them—who are very supportive of a republic. But as a whole the coalition is not. Certainly the voices of those within the Liberal Party who would support a republic have been quashed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I think on a rough count those in the Liberal Party who support a republic would be about a third. Maybe the parliamentary secretary could enlighten us on this issue when he gets to his feet. As I understand it, they are not going to be represented in those numbers in the delegation of the convention. It is really a very sad thing that even within their own party they cannot be democratic. They cannot give equal weight to the voices in their own party that support a republic.
—How many Labor supporters support the constitutional monarchy? Quite a few of the battlers do.
—The parliamentary secretary raises the issue of those in the Labor Party who support the monarchy. There probably are some.
—Some? The odd one or two you reckon?

—But the reality is that they are very small in number. I would say that probably 99 per cent of Labor Party members are in support of a republic. Certainly our delegation will reflect the views of our party. We will not squash a reasonably large sector of the party which has a contrary view.

SPEECH.PARA: So I will conclude in the few moments left to me by saying that it is sad to see that the opportunity for the democratic traditions of Australia to be brought into play to bring about a republic has been lost. The Prime Minister has subverted the process to ensure that as little change as possible occurs in accordance with his fundamentally conservative views of the world and Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997. According to the explanatory memorandum issued with this bill, the purpose of this bill is to establish `a process for the election of delegates to the proposed Constitutional Convention, which is scheduled to meet in December 1997'. That Constitutional Convention will consider what Australians think about changing our constitutional structure to make it a republic rather than a constitutional monarchy.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill that the parliament has before it is a substantial document. It runs for 129 pages. It is a thick and weighty tome, but it is far from perfect. It needs to be amended in several respects. It needs to be amended to require the holding of a compulsory attendance ballot conducted by whatever reasonable means are available to reduce the cost of the ballot whilst maintaining the ballot's integrity. In other words, this bill does not require compulsory secret voting. It requires voluntary postal voting, and that needs to change.

The bill needs to be changed to ensure that the ballot is conducted in a manner that is as similar to that used for election to the Senate as is possible. This bill provides that a new form of ballot paper be issued which would be alien to the experience of most electors. The ballot paper should conform to the experience of most electors so they are familiar with it and can exercise their democratic choice in familiar surroundings, not in new and confusing ones.

This bill should be amended to provide for 20 appointed federal delegates—10 appointed by the Prime Minister, eight by the Leader of the Opposition, one by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and one to be drawn at random from the minor party and Independent members. That would obviate the allegation that this Constitutional Convention is being stacked up‐front by the government to reflect its view. It would recognise the principle that a constitutional convention should be a gathering of all Australians of all views coming together to represent a fundamental discussion about the future of our nation. There should be no argument that this is being stacked.

The bill should be amended to provide for four appointed state parliamentary delegates per state—two to be appointed by the Premier and two to be appointed by the Leader of the Opposition; to provide for two appointed territory representatives from each of the ACT and the Northern Territory by the Chief Minister and the Leader of the Opposition; to provide for 28 community delegates to be appointed by a two‐thirds majority of the appointed federal parliamentary delegates; to provide for an independent, non-voting chair of the convention to be appointed by a two‐thirds majority of the appointed federal parliamentary delegates; and to provide for the rules and procedures of the convention to be determined by a two‐thirds majority of the appointed federal parliamentary delegates, subject to amendment by the convention itself.

If this bill reflected those changes, this bill would have the unanimous support of the opposition and would be a bill which would unite this country and strengthen our constitution at a time in which we might alter it to better reflect modern day thinking. If the bill was amended in those terms, it would, I believe, meet the criticisms of it that have been offered by the Australian Republican Movement. I seek leave of the Senate to now incorporate in Hansard a letter from Mr Malcolm Turnbull, Chairman of the Republican Movement, setting down his criticisms of this bill.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Dear Senator,

In the next few days you will be asked to determine the electoral system which will select the delegates to the Constitutional Convention. The Australian Republican Movement is concerned that the bill in its current form will disenfranchise large sections of the community and prevent many Australians from voting.

The ballot should be conducted as an Australian ballot: compulsory and secret. The postal system being used and the ballot paper to be distributed are calculated to confuse and disenfranchise more than three million Australians.

The Australian Electoral Commission acknowledges that between one and two million Australians will not even receive a ballot paper because they have moved address since the last habitation review. This will impact most on people who are young or people who rent their homes.

There are two and a half million Australians living in households where the principal language spoken is other than English. Experience in other postal ballots shows that, not understanding what is in the ballot papers, many if not most of these Australians will not vote. These concerns were articulated directly to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee by various Ethnic Community Councils.

The ballot paper itself in its current form is a dog's breakfast. Common sense would decree that the ballot paper would be exactly the same as the ballot paper for a Senate election. The more familiar the system, the more likely people are to vote

The Australian Republican Movement has a simple request to all Senators: we want as many Australians as possible to participate in this process. That will be achieved if we have an Australian ballot using a familiar ballot paper.
Please help to make this a genuine People's Convention.
A copy of the draft ballot paper provided by the Electoral Commission is attached.
Yours faithfully
Malcolm Turnbull
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber. I have sat through many thousands of speeches during my parliamentary career. When you listen to them all and you hark back, it is rare that you can recall many of them. One of the speeches that I do recall, and I think I will remember it for the rest of my life, is a speech that was delivered by the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, on 7 June 1995. It took the form of a ministerial statement. It was headed simply `Republic'. I believe that was a seminal speech. It was a speech for history. I read it again last night in preparing my remarks for today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a speech that is basically about the processes to achieve a republic for Australia, but it is much more than that. It has a grandeur, a sense of occasion. It has a considered logic, explained reasonably and with understanding. Above all, it has a firm goal of Australia becoming a republic. It is a speech, I believe, of leadership.

By comparison, the second reading speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) accompanying this bill falls far short. It is a comparison that does not flatter the current Prime Minister's second reading speech. That speech is lost in superfluous technocratic detail. It does not have a vision. In many respects, it is a narrow and, some would say, a mean speech. To illustrate the point that I make, let me quote from the Keating speech of 7 June 1995. He says:

We are attached to Great Britain by long threads of kinship and affection which, to a considerable extent, are embodied in the warmth of our regard for Queen Elizabeth. Many Australians may well feel that to substitute an Australian for the monarchy constitutes in some way a rejection of these ties. I think all of us can understand these feelings.

But the creation of an Australian republic is not an act of rejection. It is one of recognition: in making the change we will recognise that our deepest respect is for our Australian heritage, our deepest affection is for Australia, and our deepest responsibility is to Australia's future.
Nothing in the creation of an Australian republic will alter the facts of our heritage and our affections.
I think that accurately encapsulates the feeling of many of us who seek a republic for this nation. The speech goes on:
The Queen of Australia is also Queen of the United Kingdom and 14 other countries in the United Nations.

Notwithstanding that The Queen is Australia's Head of State and fulfils that duty conscientiously, when she travels overseas she represents only the United Kingdom. Her visits abroad often tend to promote British trade and British interests—they do not promote Australia's trade and interests.

This is, of course, right and proper for the Head of State of the United Kingdom. But it is not right for Australia. The right Head of State for Australia is one of us, embodying the things for which we stand, reminding us of those things at home and representing them abroad. We number among those things fairness, tolerance and love of this country. It is a role only an Australian can fill.

The speech goes on and is replete with many examples of that type of sensitivity and understanding, with the calm assertion that this is an independent nation and should make independent constitutional arrangements for its head of state to be an Australian within an Australian structure.

In no sense can it be said that the second reading speech accompanying this bill captures anything like that sense of destiny, that sense of a nation being called together to consider what form its constitutional structure should take. That is regrettable. It was an opportunity for this government to stamp some vision on the direction of this nation; it was an opportunity that, when one reads the speech by the Prime Minister, one would have to say has been emphatically declined—and regrettably so.

Let me declare my position in this debate. I am in favour of Australia becoming a constitutional republic. I am in favour of Australia achieving that by a minimalist route. As someone who believes that that is the goal and recognises that many Australians, indeed, a majority of us, support that view and that many others might hold that a constitutional monarchy is the appropriate form, I nonetheless say that a republic is inevitable. Despite all of that, I have to say—and I believe this is the sentiment of all republicans—that we should be insistent that the process by which this nation chooses to be a republic is a process which is fair to all Australians, irrespective of their views on this subject, is inclusive of their concerns and is acceptable. At the end of the process, the decision should have strengthened this country, not weakened and divided it. The convention we are debating in this bill will be critical in redefining our nation whatever its outcome. It will be about how we see ourselves and how the world sees us. Therefore, as a convention, it should be inclusive and not divisive.

That leads me to the bill itself and some of the features of it which I regard as necessary to achieve the principles that I have just espoused—principles which ought to be eternal between all parties and all Australians, irrespective of their views of the particular issue. The first and most obvious defect in this legislation is that it proposes to introduce what is for Australia a bizarre voting system. I think it is a sad irony that, in setting up a Constitutional Convention to determine the structure of our democracy, we propose to introduce a new and alien voting system that is not the Australian ballot.

Australia, in the history of world democracy, has a proud place. For many years the secret ballot was known around the world as the Australian ballot. A feature of the way in which we conduct that ballot is that it is compulsory for Australians to vote. This legislation makes it voluntary for Australians to vote—and that flies in the face of what Australians themselves want. In all the polls that I have seen asking whether voting should be compulsory or voluntary, around 70 per cent of Australians say it should be compulsory. But this legislation proposes to make it voluntary—not voluntary in the sense that you can choose whether to turn up at the polling booth on the day but voluntary and postal. That is to say, a letter arrives and if you open it, read it and answer it you can then exercise a ballot and vote on the composition of this convention. That is not a system of election that we have ever had in this country for major matters. It is not a system that Australians are familiar with at all. It operates to some extent, but in a limited way, at local government level. Only this year in my own state of Western Australia has that been the case.

But for major matters of nationhood this is a mean way to conduct a ballot, and that ought to change. Our voting system is a tried and tested voting system. To introduce a new voting system now at the eleventh hour does raise the question: why would anyone want to do that? When I scrutinise the speech delivered by the Prime Minister to try to discover the motive for changing the voting system, the only explanation that becomes readily apparent in the technocratic jargon of a dense speech about superfluous detail is one of cost. I believe the costs of a compulsory secret ballot have been inflated.

But the costs are not so wildly different as to justify a change in the manner in which we cast votes in this nation. Therefore, one thinks when looking at the agenda for dealing with this issue: is there a hidden agenda that is not obvious? Anyone that follows political debate in Australia knows that within the government itself there is an intense discussion about trying to change the voting system from being compulsory to voluntary. As far as I can observe, the government has not made a decision about that and within its own ranks there are views either way on the issue. Nonetheless, for a cynic, this bill can be seen as a trial horse for such a voting system—and that in itself would be a sinister motive.

But it has an even more sinister dimension. Notoriously, voluntary voting by post does not obtain a voting turnout of 100 per cent. In local government elections where there is voluntary voting local government candidates often think they have a good turnout if the turnout is around 20 per cent or 30 per cent. If it is up around 40 per cent or 50 per cent, that is a stunning turnout. I do not know what the turnout will be in voting for this convention. For Australians to be aware of the gravity of what they are being asked to decide in but a few months, the issue certainly needs to obtain more publicity. But, if the turnout is less than 70 per cent or 80 per cent—and it could well be, given the lack of knowledge about voluntary postal voting—then those who are opposed to the process by which we would decide that this nation should become a republic will argue that this is not an important issue but one that should be put aside and not returned to.

The sinister dimension that I see in making the voting system not the one we are used to but a new and different voting system is that it denigrates what most Australians in all the opinion polls have said—that is, that they want a republic—and makes it harder for that to be achieved, putting hurdles in their way and confecting the arrangements in a manner in which it can be contended that the support is genuinely not there, when seriously and genuinely it is.

For those reasons, this issue of voting is a matter of contention and division already. It is a matter of division when the primary task of government here is to unite the country in this process of deciding the outcome of the issue. Up‐front, a divisive matter has intruded, which gives support to the claim that the government is not really serious about setting in place a fair program by which this country can determine whether it becomes a republic.

A number of my colleagues have made a series of other quite important points about the voluntary voting system. Those Australians out of the country at the time will not have a vote. For those Australians who have difficulty with English as their first language, the ballot paper and the process will be confusing, and they may risk being disenfranchised because of a lack of facility with the English language—and they will not be in a polling booth where they can go and ask for information. Those Australians in situations of real need or between addresses or not on the voting roll—and there is a significant number of them at any one time—will be disenfranchised too. There is no reason why any of those Australians should miss the opportunity to express a view about whether Australia should be a constitutional monarchy, as it now is, or whether it should become part of the modern world, becoming a republic, as most Australians wish. But this system denies those classes of Australians a chance to exercise a view. For that reason, whether you are a monarchist or a republican, this clause in this bill should change.

The other thing that many of my colleagues in this debate have spoken about is the ballot paper itself. It is to resemble the system of voting for the Senate. Most Australians find the Senate voting system a little confusing: there is a higher level of informal votes in the Senate than in the House of Representatives. But the system we have is the system we know, and to turn that system on its head and change the nature of the ticket and introduce something new is to add a dimension of unnecessary confusion which is, again, divisive and raises the question of what the real agenda here is.

One may ask what purpose that confusion serves. It does not serve the Australian people or the purpose of a fair process here. It does not serve the purpose of creating a sense of occasion—we are deciding our nation's future and the constitutional trappings of our nationhood. It does not serve any of those purposes. The only purpose it serves is that of those who wish to bring this process into disrepute and to put roadblocks, obstacles and hurdles in the way of Australia's moving to make a fair decision.

Wherever one stands in this debate—as a monarchist, a republican or someone who does not know—the process of the ballot should be something we all understand, because, at the end of the day, whatever the outcome, any of the groups, republican or monarchist, will want to be able to express their view as to what it really means. If the process is not fair, if the ballot paper is new and confusing, if the ballot itself is voluntary and postal—not compulsory and secret at the polling booth—then neither of the groups and none of the interests in Australia will be able to say conclusively what the meaning of the outcome is.

I support the amendments I referred to. I commend them to the Senate. I trust the chamber can, across the divide of political parties, find a unity around these issues, because this is a question of the destiny of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill and the maintenance of the constitutional monarchy—like hell I do! I thought if I said that, I might at least get the attention of Senator Heffernan and his colleague over there.
—Run it past us again?

—I said I was going to rise to speak in support of your legislation, Senator, but there is no way I could do that, clearly, because I am 200 per cent a republican. I want to make it very clear that, in my view, this legislation is the most despicable attempt to defraud the Australian people that has ever come before any Australian parliament.
—That's what you said about the last piece of legislation.
—At least you might be running to form. Most of your legislation probably is in that form and probably deserves that sort of criticism.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian people deserve much better from a government that said it was for all of us. We, I think, at this point in our life as a nation, ought to at least have the ability to continue the growth of the nation and see it through to where we actually stand on our own two feet. For those of you on the other side, who want to cling to the apron strings of the mother country, you can do that if you like. But I think you should let the vast majority of the Australian people get on with the job and achieve what they want to achieve in terms of a nation.

I find it very difficult to come to grips with the position that you have taken in putting this legislation together. You have proposed that only half of this convention will be elected, yet in the past you have taken a populist approach on many issues, where you have said time and again that the majority of Australians want something. My view about the question that ought to be put to the Australian public is: one question, one vote. That is, do they want Australia to become a republic? That is the ballot that should be held—no other.

My party is proposing amendments to this legislation that would clearly make it fairer, that would clearly make it better and would retain one fundamental and very important issue: compulsory voting. Despite the fact of it being compulsory, people do get to have their say. They do get to make the judgment on those people who will govern them and we should at least retain that fundamental aspect of the Australian way of life. As some of my colleagues have said, many other countries wish they had the same sort of voting system.
With regard to where Australia is proceeding, I would just like to refer back to the statement made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, on 7 June, 1995. In part, he said:

We are approaching the 21st century and the centenary of our nationhood. As never before we are making our own way in our region and the world. For us the world is going—and we are going—in a way which makes our having the British monarch as our Head of State increasingly anomalous.

The fact is that if the plans for our nationhood were being drawn up now, by this generation of Australians and not those of a century ago, it is beyond question that we would make our Head of State an Australian. Any suggestion that the British monarch would fill the role would not be entertained.

That is so true, because that is the way Australian people would feel about it. In fact, I think that if we never had the historic link with the monarchy, that is exactly how all of us would feel. Indeed, I know that many of the conservative members of parliament feel that way. The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, went on to say:

Nothing in the creation of an Australian republic will alter the facts of our heritage and our affections. Indeed our relationship with Britain may well become the more thoroughly `modern relationship' which the British Prime Minister—
then John Major—
expressed a desire for two years ago.
He further said:
We are friends with separate destinies to carve out in the world. We are not as we once were, in a parent-child relationship.

That is true. If you look at the polls, they have clearly shown that a majority of Australians want Australia to become a republic. If we do it by the year 2000, nothing could be better. It really would be, I think, the icing on the cake for the 2000 Olympics here in Australia to be opened by an Australian head of state.

I look at many things, for example, the position of the RSL in my own home state. The RSL took action against a person whom I know very well and who is also a life member of the RSL, Mick Walker, when he made a comment. I thought the fundamental underpinning position of the RSL was to protect freedom of speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —They went off to fight for free speech—except in their own organisation.

—Yes, you cannot do it inside the RSL. I thought Australia was a democracy, that people could have a say and express a view. But not according to the Prime Minister. He wants to charge people five hundred bucks to actually participate in any ballot. Poor old Mick Walker—at least he stuck to his guns. I do not know what hit the RSL, but finally something hit them and brought them to their senses because they took no action against him, and rightly so. Frankly, people like Bruce Ruxton and a few others ought to be ashamed of themselves. A person like Mick Walker, who has dedicated a lot of his lifetime to working for returned service people and who makes a major contribution to the township of Longford in so far as aged people are concerned, ought to be praised, not belittled in the way he was by the RSL.

BREAK.PARA: If you look at the legislation that we have before us, you can see rat prints all over it—from the sneaky rat who sits across the way here to the rat who has packed his bag and flown the coop, with tennis racquet, cricket bat and all, winging his way across the world. He is probably going to get into a bit of Baroness Thatcher's cheese—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy, I think the comments that you have just made are quite unparliamentary and I would ask that you withdraw them.
—Mr Deputy President, I did not know that I actually referred to anyone in particular by name, but if you find my remarks offensive, I withdraw them.

—I raise a point of order: an entirely uncategorical withdrawal is what has always been required in the history of the Senate. Senator Murphy should perhaps respect that, respect your ruling and not question it.
—The point of order is upheld and I ask for an uncategorical withdrawal.
—An uncategorical withdrawal?
—A withdrawal without qualification, Senator Murphy.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I did not know that I actually put a qualification on it, but I do withdraw the comments that you found offensive. It does not detract from the fact that this legislation is exactly what I said it is. It is the most despicable attempt to defraud Australians of what they rightly deserve. I say to Senator Campbell, through you Mr Acting Deputy President, that when it came to the issue of dealing with guns the Prime Minister repeatedly said that the course of action which the government was taking—and I agree, rightly so—was what the Australian public wanted. They wanted some form of action.

BREAK.PARA: The polls have clearly shown that Australians would like to see Australia become a republic, not because of any distaste or any regret with regards to our association and our historical links with Great Britain but more because of the fact—as I said when I read the words of former Prime Minister Keating—that we are growing up, developing as a nation in our own way and seeking our own place in the world.

There is no need for us to retain the links. We can retain the links in a different way. We may even have stronger links. They will never go away, they will never be lost, but it does not mean that we cannot progress the nationhood of this country.

The issue of the ballot process which has been raised really is one of the most pathetic, almost fraudulent arrangements that you would want to see. I had a look at the draft ballot paper. If you wanted to fix a ballot, that is exactly the sort of ballot paper you would have. You would make it so confusing that people would not be able to fill it out. You only have to look at the results of existing ballots that are compulsory, where you go to a balloting place where people can help you fill in your ballot paper, to see the informal results that you get now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that what a union ballot paper is like? Isn't that how the unions vote?

—You would not know how to fill out a union ballot paper, even if we made it very easy. The whole issue with regard to how much information is going to be sent out and the cost of it is a complete and utter joke. Unemployment in this country is almost like the old J‐curve. We are on the curve all right—up. We are going to spend money sending out paper all over this country, most of which will not even get filled out or sent back.
—Want to have a bet on that?

—Senator Macdonald, I would like to see yours when it is sent back to see whether you have been able to fill it out properly. I doubt that you will be able to. You certainly will not want to fill it out after Friday night.

BREAK.PARA: We have, of course, pursued a course of action that will make this legislation fairer. My personal view is that it should be defeated, it should be turfed out and we should have just one ballot of the Australian public. They will, clearly, make a decision as to whether or not they want a republic. Once that decision has been taken, what is the point of having some convention to determine the type of republic? How many different types of republics are there, 55, 100? Certainly not.

Surely there are people within both the parliament and the country who could sit down and very quickly put together the changes needed to the constitution and essentially work out the change that we would make in so far as becoming a republic is concerned. Why do we have to have 152 people sit down and jawbone over the fact, and never reach agreement about the specific nature of the type of republic that Australia should have? If they did, what would be the purpose of then having a vote. If you have a consensus of the representatives who have been both appointed and elected to come to a conclusion about (a) yes, we will have a republic and (b) this is the type of republic we will have, why then are we having a referendum? What is leadership in this country about?

Yes, we should give the people a say as to whether or not they want Australia to become a republic. You really do not have to have a ballot for that because we know what the result of that would be. We know the clear majority of Australians want that. So why don't we just get on with the job of actually determining what form of a republic we will have. That is not a big job. If the government and a few other people could not sit down and work that out, it is no wonder we have the problems we have with unemployment. It is no wonder we have the problems with regard to the credibility of politicians because there is no leadership in the way the Prime Minister is taking this country on this issue, let alone most other issues.

I do not know how thick the envelope is but, as I understand from the report, the envelope that all this information is going to be sent out in is slightly bigger than a DL envelope which takes an A4 piece of paper folded three times. Two envelopes, the ballot paper and a booklet with all of the candidates in it—it is going to be a fairly thick booklet in New South Wales—are going to be sent out. The poor old punter gets that and, if he wants to vote for a group but does not want to vote for the group in the order on the ballot paper, he has to look through the booklet, identify the number of the candidate that he wants to vote for first, and so on. What a ridiculous situation and time wasting exercise. It is a most disgraceful waste of public money.
I was looking at the constitutional reform section of the law and justice policy of the Liberal Party before the last election. It says:
A Liberal and National Government will—
and this is the first dot point—
ensure that as an overriding principle, the Australian people are involved in the process of debating our Constitution.

That is the first dot point in your policy; yet you seek to deny the vast majority of Australians the right to vote. You have given no justification for that. The government says, `We're going to make a provision for the people serving down in Antarctica to vote, but we're not going to make any provision for people serving overseas elsewhere. Indeed, even if they're in the Defence Force, they don't get a chance to vote.' Why is that the case? Why is it that we can send the ballot papers down to Antarctica but we cannot send them to other Australians elsewhere?

The period is one week, I think, from the time the ballot papers are sent out. The whole thing, as I said at the outset, just stinks. It is a most dirty, despicable attempt to defraud the Australian people of a right that they have had for so long. You know from the committee's inquiry that up to three million Australians may well not even get the ballot papers, let alone fill them in. So when you send it out—you can expect no more than a 30 per cent return; and I doubt that you will get a 30 per cent return—only a very small part of the population will get a say on this issue. How does that fit in with your overriding principle that all Australian people will have a right to participate in this debate? It does not at all. There is total denial and no opportunity.

Finally, I hope the amendments proposed by the opposition will be supported. I certainly hope that the Independent senators will see their way clear to support the right of the Australian public to have a say. But, from a personal point of view, I would like to see the legislation defeated altogether and for there to be an agreement whereby the Australian public are given the opportunity to simply say, `Yes, we do,' or, `No, we don't want Australia to become a republic.' Then the government should get on with the job of following the direction and the request of the Australian public. So, as I said, I hope the amendments are supported, but I have a personal preference to see the whole thing kicked out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill and support the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Bolkus on behalf of the opposition to amend this misbegotten bill that is a political device to get the present government off—
—What sort of bill?

—A misbegotten bill—a bill that has been put together in a very bad way as a political device to try to achieve an outcome to advantage the coalition in the best possible way, despite the fact that there are extraordinary problems within the coalition about how they should handle the republican issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out that we should pay considerable credit to former Prime Minister Paul Keating for the remarks he made on several occasions that have established the fact that we should have an Australian citizen as our head of state. I believe he made a speech in 1993 that started to set the tenor about our national character, or national image, that leads inexorably to why we must have an Australian citizen as our head of state.

One of those speeches, which I think has been recognised by even some of his fiercest critics as one of the great speeches, was on 11 November 1993, when he spoke at the unveiling of the new war memorial for the Unknown Soldier in Canberra. For the first time, we interred in Australia the remains of an unknown soldier from the First World War battlefields of France. Then Prime Minister Keating, in a short speech about this unknown soldier, said:
We do not know this Australian's name and we never will.

We do not know his rank or his battalion. We do not know where he was born, or precisely how and when he died. We do not know where in Australia he had made his home or when he left it for the battlefields of Europe. We do not know his age or his circumstances—whether he was from the city or the bush; what occupation he left to become a soldier; what religion; if he was married or single. We do not know who loved him or whom he loved. If he had children we do not know who they are. His family is lost to us as he was lost to them. We will never know who this Australian was.

Yet he has always been among those we have honoured. We know that he was one of the 45,000 Australians who died on the Western Front. One of the 416,000 Australians who volunteered for service in the First World War. One of the 324,000 Australians who served overseas in that war, and one of the 60,000 Australians who died on foreign soil. One of the 100,000 Australians who have died in wars this century.
He is all of them. And he is one of us.
That phrase `and he is one of us' is the phrase that resonated at that ceremony as what the Unknown Soldier represented to all Australians.

The then Prime Minister returned to that theme when he made a speech in the Australian parliament on 7 June 1995 when he responded to the Turnbull committee about the need for Australia to become a republic and the process we should go through, a speech that again has been recognised even by his severest critics as being an outstanding speech that will stand the test of time. The then Prime Minister, Mr Keating, concluded that speech with the following words:

BREAK.PARA: The meaning—
of a republic—
is simple and, we believe, irresistible—as simple and irresistible as the idea of a Commonwealth of Australia was to the Australians of a century ago.

The meaning then was a nation united in common cause for the common good. A nation which gave expression to the lives we lead together on this continent, the experience and hopes we share as Australians.

The meaning now is still a product of that founding sentiment—it is that we are all Australians. We share a continent. We share a past, a present and a future. And our Head of State should be one of us.

Again, he returned to the phrase `should be one of us', and that is the phrase that is resonating in Australia. Despite all the argy-bargy, all the fine detail, about what form an Australian republic should take, overwhelmingly Australia wants an Australian citizen to be our head of state. It is, in my view, an argument that cannot be beaten.

Some extraordinary comments have been made by those who still proclaim themselves to be constitutional monarchists that we do not need to change the constitution because we are a de facto republic already, that our Governor-General is in fact the head of state. That is a fictitious heap of lies. The head of state of Australia is whomever is the monarch of Great Britain. That is what our constitution says, and it cannot be argued any other way.

I heard on the radio only two days ago Mr Abbott, a Liberal member from the lower house and a parliamentary secretary in this government, declare that the Governor-General was our head of state. That is a lie. It is not correct. The constitution does not describe the Governor-General as a head of state.

I have even seen articles written by our eminent Clerk of the Senate saying that we do not need to change because in fact we are a de facto republic in every sense other than whom our head of state is. I do not think any country can exist on the basis of saying, `We do not need to change because, de facto, we are already a republic.' Whether it is Mr Evans, who is arguing, I think, for a wider issue about his concern for what it may mean for the Senate rather than the even broader issue about an Australian identity and Austral ian republic, or the constitutional monarchists like Mr Abbott and other representatives going around saying that the Governor-General is the head of state, that is patently absurd. The former Prime Minister made it very clear in one simple message: an Australian citizen shall be our head of state.

In I think 1988 we carried laws in Australia that made it final that the English parliament could carry no law that could affect the running and management of Australia; that is, except for one issue: the British parliament still has the power to make whom they like the King or Queen of England. If the new Labour government wanted to sack the House of Windsor and appoint Arthur Scargill—highly unlikely—as the King of England and they had a majority in the House of Commons, it would happen. That would automatically mean that person would be the King or Queen of Australia. We would have no say in it. To me it is an absolute absurdity that, at the end of the 20th century and going into the 21st century, a parliament of another country can decide on its own and without reference to us that it has the power to decide who shall be the King or Queen of England and therefore our head of state.

Also, we have the absurdity of English law saying a Roman Catholic cannot be the King or Queen, which means our head of state cannot be a Roman Catholic and has to be a member of the Church of England.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're an atheist.

—I have to say, Bill, you are dead right. I, as an agnostic leaning towards atheism, and people with a similar view could not be our head of state because English law says the head of state must be a member of the Church of England. As we enter the 21st century it is an absolute absurdity to have such rules. If some employer said, `I will not employ you because you are a Roman Catholic,' they would be in trouble with the various anti-discrimination laws of this country.
—What religion is the Governor‐General?

—I am just pointing this out to you, Senator Macdonald, and you cannot understand it: the Governor-General is a representative of the Queen; he is not the head of state. He is recognised nowhere in the world as our head of state. The Queen, when she travels anywhere in the world, is not the Queen of Australia. She cannot represent us anywhere except when she is actually in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: As Gerard Henderson, a conservative commentator, pointed out, it is really ironic that we have the future King of England campaigning in Europe in support of French farming subsidies which will affect Australian farmers. Under the present arrangements we have in Australia he is going to be our next king, and he is out publicly defending French farming agricultural subsidies, to the detriment of Australian farmers. It is an absurdity to have our head of state having a view against the interests of our own people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have views against the interests of Australia most of the time, Senator.
—We want our own head of state who can, where appropriate, represent Australian farmers—unlike Bill O'Chee, who does not represent them on this issue.

BREAK.PARA: I now want to turn to the bill itself. I find it ironic that the person responsible for this legislation is Senator Minchin, an absolutely avowed monarchist who is also avowedly in favour of voluntary voting. He has put the two together. He has had an absolute free kick and said, `I will put up a constitutional convention model that makes it almost unworkable, where you have appointed delegates and elected delegates and where we will have it by a voluntary postal ballot.' It is a joke.

Senator Minchin comes from a state which has as one of its proudest records the fact that in 1856 South Australia was the first place in the western world to introduce the secret ballot. For the first time it could not be identified how people voted and for which candidate and 141 years later a senator from South Australia is proposing in parliament that you get rid of secret ballot and have a postal ballot that cannot be guaranteed to be secret. It is the irony of ironies that a senator from South Australia should propose that on behalf of this government.

We should identify absolutely the contradiction of this senator as a parliamentary senator representing the Prime Minister and handling this matter. It would be as big a joke if you asked a republican such as myself to work on preparing a submission on how to reintroduce imperial honours in Australia. It would be ridiculous to ask any of us on that issue, just as it is ridiculous to ask an avowed monarchist when you are in the process of creating open and fair debate about how Australia should progress to a republic.

Yesterday my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, raised some very good issues in his speech on behalf of the opposition about the way a postal ballot would be rorted. The first issue he hit right on the head is Senator Minchin's argument in favour of cost. Senator Minchin said a normal, full secret ballot with polling booths, secret ballot boxes, et cetera, would cost around $50 million. He said a postal ballot would cost around $35 million. Senator Bolkus has pointed out in his speech and in information gathered from the Australian Postal Commission that, with the size of the ballot paper in New South Wales and the explanatory document, the postal costs will be a lot more and the difference will be more like approximately $5 million at the most.

Therefore, the argument of cost goes out the window. If it will cost almost the same for a postal ballot as it does for a full election, we ought to go for the full election. Therefore it will be a guaranteed secret ballot and those people elected have an enhanced credibility. They can go to the convention knowing that they have been elected by a compulsory ballot of the 10 million‐odd eligible voters right across Australia. We will overcome all the problems of a postal ballot being rorted.

Senator Bolkus has pointed out in evidence before the legislative committee on this that as many as three million people may have changed addresses since the last federal election. How do we know that when the ballot paper is mailed to those addresses the people named on the ballot paper will be the same who fill it in? We have no guarantee. How do we know what assistance the one or two million people who have difficulty with the English language will get to fill in ballot paper? None. It is wide open to be rorted. That is why we strongly oppose it.

We also strongly oppose the fact that the credibility of this convention will really be more than somewhat compromised. But we are willing to accept it, if we get a proper, compulsory, full secret ballot and attendance at polling booths. What is the government doing about the process of appointment? They are fixing the appointment to give them the best possible advantage of ensuring that, because of the numbers at the convention, they will be able to claim that there is a great division of opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been stacked.

—It has been stacked consistently. Senator Minchin is from South Australia and a former party secretary, like me, and we have had experience and understand how to appoint people to give yourself a political advantage.
