Senator Minchin understands that and that is what he has done in this case. I have to say that there will be a hybrid combination. Those delegates who actually will be elected—as we hope by a full secret ballot and by attendance at polling booths—will have credibility and be able to say, `We are representative of the 10 million Australian voters eligible to vote.' That credibility can never be undermined.

BREAK.PARA: This mob in government wants to have a postal ballot with a large number of ballot papers disappearing and a large number not even being returned. It will be a voluntary vote and therefore those elected will have their credibility diminished. They will not be able to claim to represent the Australian voting public like all of us in this chamber can. Whether we disagree with each other or not, the bottom line is that all of Australia has voted to put us in here and in three or six years' time they can vote to put us out.

The sovereignty of the actual ballot, the secret, compulsory ballot, is one of the endur ing features and strengths of our democracy in Australia. It is something that this parliamentary secretary, Senator Minchin, wishes to undermine. We believes that having a first go at a voluntary ballot will be an excuse to undermine the compulsory ballot overall in Australia. He has had a chance in South Australia. He has convinced the Liberal government there to introduce voluntary voting under his influence. He has now used his influence on the parliamentary committee to introduce it.

Everybody knows that overwhelmingly Australians believe by a margin of 70 per cent to 30 per cent that compulsory voting is a feature they wish to retain. Most other countries look at our system and say there is much to commend it. You know that when you get all the people voting, you cannot argue that you have not got some sort of mandate. We cannot argue that in the lower house the Liberal Party has been overwhelmingly elected on a two‐party preferred vote of over 50 per cent. We cannot argue that in the Senate over the six‐year period the numbers here reflect how people have voted under a PR ballot. But Senator Minchin wants to undermine that. He is using the Constitutional Convention as a device to inhibit the development of ordinary Australians' desire to have an Australian citizen as head of state and to run his own political agenda of undermining the compulsory secret ballot.

That is why we are moving amendments, and no threat, no blackmail from the parliamentary secretary on behalf of the Prime Minister will get us to back down on this. We have made it clear that this is an important and fundamental democratic principle.

I am very pleased and honoured to speak in this debate. I was honoured in 1991, as a delegate to the national conference, to move the resolution that established as Labor Party policy that by the year 2001, the centenary of federation, Australia shall be a republic. Of all the things I have done in the Labor Party and in the public forum over the last 25 years I have been involved in public life in politics, that is the one I take the greatest honour from—having had the opportunity to move that resolution that Australia will become a republic.

Therefore, it is an honour to have another chance to speak in the parliamentary forum in favour of a republic, but through a process that is decent and uncorrupted, unlike what Senator Minchin has put. I conclude with the famous words of Mr Keating in June 1995: what we want in Australia is a head of state who is one of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak mainly on the aspect of the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 to do with compulsory voting.
—Tell us how the unions ballot.

—I will come to that, Senator Macdonald, so I will not disappoint you. I think it is unfair, Senator Schacht, that Senator Minchin is denied the possibility of being called `count' in the future, if that is his heart's desire. Count Minchin has a bit of a ring to it, I think. So to deny Senator Minchin the opportunity to grandstand on this issue—
—That's not a bad idea.
—Or Baron Minchin. I think it has got some attractions to it.
—It's a really good idea.

—Being serious, it is very important that this issue of compulsory or voluntary voting in the convention is addressed directly. In Australia, despite the way the debate is characterised, we do not have compulsory voting; we have compulsory attendance at the polling booth. That is a very important distinction. You are not compelled to vote for either party or even an Independent candidate. You are simply compelled to turn up at the polling place, have your name crossed off and receive a ballot paper. What you do with the ballot paper after that is entirely up to you. Some choose to throw it away, some choose to deliberately vote informal, but the vast majority of Australians cast formal votes. Between 92 and 95 per cent of Australians regularly turn up and cast formal votes.

BREAK.PARA: Some sections of the conservatives cry currently, `How can we have a free society when we are compelling people to turn up to the polling booth?' What I say to those members of the coalition is that society compels citizens to do a whole range of things currently, of which turning up to a polling booth once every three years is probably the smallest. It includes things like compelling people to send their children to school. It is compulsory for children to go to school. It is compulsory in all states that you cannot be drunk while driving. There are laws that say you are not allowed to drink‐drive. There are laws that say you are not allowed to go as fast as you want when you are driving your car. Despite the many attempts of the coalition to let their mates out of the taxation system by way of loopholes, it is compulsory to pay tax each year. In particular, the conservatives have recently articulated the question of mutual obligation in respect of work for the dole.

So there is compulsion from this government, as there has been from all previous governments, in many areas of Australian life. A compulsion to attend a polling place once every three years, as I said earlier, is probably the smallest of all the compulsions that a government places on its citizens. It is not as if it is an extraordinary thing or the only thing they are compelled to do. It is one of many things that a government requires of its citizens.

All polling that has been done on this issue shows an overwhelming majority of support for compulsory voting. So we have a situation where half a dozen people have chosen to defy a court and not pay a fine and they have gone to gaol of their own choice. It is no different from being issued a parking ticket and refusing to pay the fine. What happens? You go to gaol. It is no different. You are issued a fine, you refuse to pay and the court sends you to gaol. I do not see any great outcry about people who have conscientiously refused to accept the parking laws, who have exercised their right to choose not to pay a fine for a parking ticket.

Then you begin to get into the question of why the coalition, and Senator Minchin in particular, would be pushing this. If Senator Minchin knew that a coalition government was going to automatically suffer a predicted two per cent swing against it as a result of introducing voluntary voting, do you think seriously—I am a bit of a cynic, but I would be happy to have Senator Minchin dispel my cynicism—he would be the champion of those six people who were in gaol for 24 hours? I think not.
The two per cent figure is not something I have concocted; it comes from independent analysts. Malcolm Mackerras was on the radio yesterday making it quite clear—

TALK.START.PARA: —What the agenda was.

—what the agenda was—exactly, Senator Mackay. Malcolm Mackerras is not a great fan of the Labor Party—he handed out for the Liberal Party at the last election, I understood, up in Belconnen. There would be a two per cent swing to the right in politics. That is the agenda. If the Liberals had the honesty to stand up and say, `What we are proposing is an electoral system that will benefit us,' you would at least have some respect for them; at least they would be up‐front in what they are about, not carrying on about personal philosophies on compulsion and how terrible it was that people were gaoled for their political beliefs. It is nothing more than a cynical exercise.

BREAK.PARA: Studies carried out by Republicans in America have identified that in America with voluntary voting it is the rich who turn out to vote; the top income earners all turn out to vote. Those who feel disenfranchised, those who are down the income scale, the racial minorities, the young, those who lack tertiary education and those who move a lot through work or for other reasons are the people who do not vote. That is what the studies show. The rich vote and the disadvantaged tend to vote less. That is what Senator Minchin and those supporting him are really about. The convention vote is just the first step.

Senator Minchin has had a particular interest in postal ballots recently. Senator Minchin and I are on another committee together which has recently been examining postal ballots in union elections. Senator Macdonald, do you need a prompt?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am listening.

—The conservatives like Senator Minchin are extremely concerned about the possibility of fraud in postal ballots. They are going to great lengths to try to prove it and they are going to greater lengths to try to find any rumour or innuendo because, they say, they do not trust it; they say it is too easy to rort a postal ballot. There are all sorts of allegations—
—It's a joke.
—I tell you Senator Mackay that Senator Minchin has spent weeks over the last 12 months pursuing—
—But how do you do it?

—Ask Senator Minchin; he is the expert. Voluntary voting is an invitation to fraud. Any political operative—and the South Australian dries are particularly good political operatives—would be able to work out which group of voters consistently do not vote. Once you know that this 20 per cent of the electorate you have identified never bother to turn up, how easy it would be to organise to have multiple voting for somebody. Senator Minchin tells us he wants electoral integrity in union and other ballots, but what you will see is the scope for organised rorting going on.

BREAK.PARA: Those opposite advocate that voluntary voting in other areas is okay but that voluntary voting in union elections is terrible. They consistently argue that the leadership in unions is elected by only a small number of the membership and, therefore, it is not legitimate. Yet when President Clinton gets elected with a 50 per cent turn‐up—of which he gets 25 and a bit per cent—that is suddenly okay. When Tony Blair wins in a landslide but fewer people turned up to vote than in the previous election—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ronald Reagan on 35.
—That is right; Ronald Reagan had 35 per cent of the vote. What sort of representative government is that?
—But how do the unions vote?

—They vote the way they are instructed both by their rules and by the Electoral Commission. We will support any amendments to make it safer for union ballots. There is no problem about that, Senator Macdonald. If you want to introduce compulsory union ballots, you will probably find I will not oppose it; I would probably even support you. If you want to put legislation up saying union ballots should be compulsory for all, I will probably support you because I think it would be a good thing if everybody in a union voted. Do you think it would be a good thing? I do.
—Is it voluntary postal?

—It currently is, but if you want to change that I will support you. It is very simple. One of the other reasons that I have heard advocated for doing away with compulsory voting is to do with a lack of education. They have failed to educate Australians in the way they address politics. That is not an argument to do away with compulsory voting; it is an argument to include course content in studies of civics, a greater study of Australian political structures and a campaign by the government to promote information about Australia's parliament. Do we see that being advocated? No They say they are concerned about the lack of education. What are they doing about it in this bill and in other bills? They are doing nothing. There is no education campaign planned.

BREAK.PARA: I was on talkback radio in Queensland this morning and other arguments given were that voluntary voting would see a better style of campaigning—fewer negative ads. Petro Georgiou has rebutted that more than adequately. In other countries, particularly in America, they have only negative advertising; the whole thrust of American political campaigning is to denigrate the opposition, disillusion potential supporters of the opposition and make sure as few people as possible turn up to vote for your opponent. That is the electoral strategy. It is not about maximising participation; it is about minimising your opponent's vote. That is the consequence of the voluntary voting system. There will be no increase, as Petro Georgiou, the member for Kooyong, suggested, in the higher political debate. It will become more base than it is now, because you appeal just to your narrow sectional interests.

We are told that Australia is out of step with the world, that compulsory voting is an anachronism. The experience I have had from meeting different people from other countries who have come here and looked at our electoral system is that they are very impressed by our participation rate. They think that 95 per cent of Australians voting for their government makes it representative. They are prepared to say that this is the sort of thing that they want to encourage overseas.
I refer to Mr Georgiou's speech to the John Stuart Mill Society, which sums up a very important point. He said:
They know this is not a flagrant attack on their rights and freedoms which undermines Australian democracy.
They know it for what it is; a symbolic nudge that voting is important and embodies a widely held community consensus that they share in.

I believe that what politics is about in principle is the pursuit of the public good, defined in the broadest sense. To me, this axiomatically involves trying to get as many people as possible to participate, to invest in the democratic process at the time when it is most meaningful.

I believe that the vote is about the only resource electors possess in which there is an approximation of equality. For electors it gives an opportunity, and still an imperfect one, to overcome momentarily the inequalities of income, age, wealth, sex, colour, ethnicity, occupation and location.

That is what it is about. That is why this bill should be amended—so that, through compulsory voting, all Australians are able to participate, so that they are not going to be driven out of the system by the advertising and be disillusioned by the process, and so that they feel they have some ownership of the government.

As I said earlier, the news polls that have been done on this overwhelmingly support compulsory voting. What the recent news poll showed, though, was that 19 per cent of ALP voters said they might not vote and that only 14 per cent of coalition voters said they would not vote. That is where this is really gross. This is self-interest masked behind philosophies about freedom of choice. This debate over the convention and our electoral system will go on for some time yet, and I welcome the debate.

There have been suggestions that compulsory voting forces a concentration of resources by political parties into marginal seats; that, therefore, people in safe seats will be ignored by the political parties; and that voluntary voting would mean that would not happen. Unfortunately, the marginal seats strategy—which Senator Minchin and others in the Liberal Party have successfully implemented recently—is about clever campaigning.

Tony Blair had a 90‐seat marginal strategy in a voluntary voting system. He won 90 seats and more, as Senator Minchin knows. So the question of a marginal seats strategy, ignoring your base, is not valid. Senator Minchin knows that. You cannot afford to ignore your base, for two reasons. One is because we are senators and we need our base seats to turn out to vote for us. But it is not the impact in the safe seats; it is the ability to spread your resources in the most beneficial, professional way. Senator Minchin has proved he is a political professional; he knows about those things. The argument that compulsory voting leads to disenfranchisement in safe seats is a furphy. I hope that Senator Minchin will deal with some of the points I and other speakers have raised.

I finish by saying that hankering after the monarchy in England is something that I have always found a bit amusing. I was born in England and grew up there. Like most English people in the 1960s and 1970s, I grew up being supportive of the monarchy and what it represented in England.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did they transfer you?

—Stealing bread. What I find astounding about the monarchists' position in Australia, which was summed up beautifully in one of today's cartoons, is that Australia is running to embrace the Commonwealth, the Queen and the monarchy, but the only problem is that they gave up on us in the mid‐1960s. They decided, for their own economic self-interest, to join the European Union. As they move further and further down the track, they continually will do what is in their best interests—supporting French farming subsidies and all the other subsidies of the European Union—as against what is in Australia's interests.

BREAK.PARA: You cannot get away from that. Australia has no economic future with the European Union. They will look after themselves and look after their own. They have walked away from us. We did not walk away from them. They did what was in their best economic interests. I do not hold rancour towards them. I just find it extraordinary that people hanker after them—`They're going to look after us; they're there to make sure our interests are okay.' They do not give a stuff about us. They are going to look after their own best interests. Good luck to them. What that means is that we have got to look after our best interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude this debate on the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill with a few remarks because I think most of the opposition arguments can be dealt with in the committee stage. The only point I want to make is that this bill to set up an election system for the delegates to the convention is one to give effect to a policy for which we have a mandate. We went to the last election with a particular approach to the question of a republic, contrary to the then Labor government's approach.

SPEECH.PARA: We were elected with an overwhelming majority. We have a mandate to give effect to the policy to deal with the question of a republic in the way we have proposed. That was quite clearly a policy for a constitutional convention at which half the delegates would be elected. We did not discuss in any way how that would be done; we said that we would have half the delegates elected.

This bill proposes an election process which the whole of government believes is appropriate for this convention. You would think from the discussion we have heard from the opposition parties that we were talking about a bill to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to change the way the Commonwealth parliament and the Commonwealth government are elected. It is not. We are talking about the election of delegates to attend a 10‐day convention at the end of this year to discuss the question of whether or not Australia becomes a republic. At the conclusion of the 10 days we all go home.

We are not talking here about electing a government to govern the country or electing the parliament to represent the people of Australia. So we have treated this issue on its merits and designed an electoral system which we think is appropriate for this particular objective. We have, as you well know, as a government decided that the most appropriate method is a Senate‐style election which will be conducted by voluntary postal ballot. We will not be resiling from that; we remain committed to that being the election system to be used for the delegates to attend this 10‐day convention. As I say, despite what the opposition has been asserting, we are not talking about any change to the method by which the Commonwealth parliament is elected. That is an entirely separate matter.

The opposition parties have proposed a whole range of amendments which essentially would have the effect of making it a compulsory attendance ballot and we will be opposing those amendments. There is a further set of amendments dealing with the method by which the other half of the convention delegates are to be appointed and we will also be opposing those. This bill deals with the election process for half the delegates, and that only. There is no need for a legislative prescription for the appointed delegates; that is a matter of government prerogative and will remain so.

I will deal with the opposition arguments at the committee stage. I will just sum up at this stage by saying that we do have a clear mandate to establish a convention at which half the delegates would be elected. This bill gives effect to that policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just seek leave to—
—You do not need leave.

—I understand that but the proprieties here are that the minister or the minister's representative closes the debate and I feel that I should observe that propriety. There was some misunderstanding in my office about the question of who was on the speakers list and who was not.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for those who have spoken in this debate, for the very full information that has been given to me and my office by Senator Minchin and for the work that was done on this matter by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee of the Senate. I am also grateful for the work that was done by the Parliamentary Library and for the information that has come from them, and for the advice I have been given, some gratuitous but most not, from sources within the community, on the way that one should vote. I would like to state that here and now. I will take the opportunity, in discussing the particular amendments in the committee stage, to put further viewpoints which refer as much to principles as to practicalities.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments that are to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 27 May 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing clause 11. I would indicate that the Democrats amendment No. 1 and the Greens amendment No. 4 seek the same outcome, which is to take out of the bill the voluntary voting proposal. This goes very much to the heart of what has been discussed extensively during the second reading debate, and that is whether we should have a voluntary vote. We reject the voluntary vote, and other amendments later on will provide for an attendance ballot in the same way as attendance ballots are conducted for elections for the federal parliament. Other clauses later on will also provide for the attendance ballot to be conducted in the way that the normal Senate ballot is conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially this is the hub of the issue and it goes to the question of whether we should be endorsing, for this particular process, the concept of a voluntary vote. We on this side of the parliament are very strongly opposed to it for a number of reasons. We claim it is a breach of faith by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Before the election the Prime Minister made the assertion that, in terms of constitutional reform, all Australians had to be involved in all parts of the process: the beginning, the middle and the end. What this voluntary vote proposal does, together with a number of other proposals in the legislation, is disenfranchise many millions of Australians.

Senator Minchin claims that the government have a mandate. They may have a mandate for a constitutional convention, but they do not have a mandate to introduce voluntary voting, and they do not have a mandate to introduce voluntary voting with respect to this, particularly when the Prime Minister committed himself and his government to involving all Australians in this process. To claim that there is a mandate for this particular style of voting here or anywhere else is a distortion of the facts of history. You cannot rewrite commitments of the past here, as Senator Minchin quite often tries to do.

There is no doubt the public have been desensitised on the issue. There has been limited publicity, and there will also be limited information available to them during any ballot. If you had been looking for a more effective way of reducing public participation in a process, you could not have designed a better proposal than the one embodied in this particular legislation. At best, on the average of attendances at voluntary postal ballots, voluntary ballots within local government and union elections, you can say that you can expect some 35 per cent to 40 per cent of the public to turn out, and I think that is a high estimation. Some 60 per cent to 65 per cent will not vote. That means more than seven million Australians, for one reason or another, can be expected not to vote in this particular ballot.

Together with that, there will not be information sent out to every home in any language other than English, and there are some 2½ million Australian homes whose first language is other than English. Those people will not participate fully in the process. For normal elections we have the capacity to assist those who are not literate, those who are old, those who have difficulties, those who might be impaired. We have all sorts of provisions to assist them through mobile booths or assistance at polling booths or electoral offices. Those polling booths, those mobile booths, will not be available this time. That assistance at the local suburban polling office will not be available this time either. People will have to travel a long way to get the assistance to which they should be due in this particular process.

Essentially, there will be one office per federal electorate. In the past if you were living in the country and you wanted to register a vote but you had difficulties in doing so, you went to your local city hall, town hall or regional hall. You will not be able to do that this time. Levels and levels of Australians, in one way or another, will be excluded or will have difficulties placed before them in terms of their full participation.

There is another matter that concerns me. There has not been a habitation review and there will not be one before this ballot. There has not been one since the last election. Two million Australians change their address every year. What is the government's response to this? It is not just to have a voluntary postal ballot but also to close off the rolls one week after nominations close. If there was a way to ensure that hundreds of thousands of Australians did not have the capacity to correct their status on the rolls, it would be this measure that closes those rolls one week after the close of nominations. So, as I say, over seven million will not vote and probably more than 2½ million will have difficulties placed before them in terms of voting.

Then you add to that the new system of voting, one that has been untried, and a proposal of government which is based on a rubbery costing figure. There is absolutely no way that this government can put all the information that needs to go out to the elector, and no way that this government will ensure it goes out to an elector, in the small sized envelope that they have asked us to believe they can. We know full well that, within days of any unamended legislation going through this parliament, the government will revise their figures and use a Tax Pack type proposal. Were they to use the envelope that they want us to believe they will use, the average elector would need a magnifying glass to read the details of the candidates.

TALK.START.PARA: —No—

—There might be a commitment in terms of the how‐to‐vote instructions being a certain size, but they are going to have to whack a lot of information into one of these small envelopes, Senator Harradine.
—It will be on disk.

—It will be on disk and I am sure as part of the costing we will provide a soft pack for every home in the Australian community. Why are they doing this? They claim it is cheaper. Their figures are rubbery. The envelopes and postage are going to cost more. There is no doubt from the evidence provided to the committee that the envelope that has been chosen by the government was not the first choice of the authorities involved in having to deliver these envelopes. The figures are rubbery there.

SPEECH.PARA: They now have to add the cost of overseas voting, something we forced on them. A figure which started off being $53 million for an attendance ballot has been pared back to $49 million, as opposed to $35½ million for a voluntary postal ballot. I think that differential is closer to $3 million or $4 million at most when you take into account the extra cost for the reasonable sized envelope that will have to go out.

BREAK.PARA: We do not believe that sort of price should be inflicted on democracy. We are talking here about some 25c per elector—one‐quarter of the cost of a reasonable ice-cream. Senator Minchin reckons the cost is an important aspect. It should not be. Such a minimal cost should not be put between an elector and their right to participate in not just a normal election but a ballot that will determine possibly the constitutional structure of this country for the next century.

It has taken us 100 years to make radical changes to our existing constitution—and we have not succeeded so far. We are talking here of laying the constitutional framework for the future and this government says, `Well, $3 million or $4 million is important between a voluntary postal ballot and a normal attendance ballot.' They should take into account, for instance, that under the voluntary voting proposal you can expect, say, four million people to vote at a cost of $35 million, some 8½c a vote. Compare that with a normal attendance ballot, which would cost $49 million, say, for 12 million people voting, 4c a vote.

It will be twice as expensive per voter under your proposal, Senator Minchin, than under a normal attendance ballot. That approach does not rub with me and I do not think it rubs with the Australian public, a public which supports compulsory attendance voting. Some 72 per cent of Australians support compulsory attendance voting, and we have this measure, totally unprepared—

TALK.START.PARA: —And 74 per cent of politicians.

—And 74 per cent of politicians, though it may not be reflected in this particular ballot, Senator Murray. But 74 per cent, I would say, when you take into account those who dissent and disagree with Senator Minchin on the Liberal Party side and the Nationals.

BREAK.PARA: So this is an experiment in voluntary voting. The cat was well and truly let out of the bag earlier this week in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters—a report which had some members of the government recommending a voluntary vote. This is, no doubt, an experiment in that, and an experiment which is contrary to the will of the Australian people.

Why does the government want to do it? It is quite obvious. All this is about is trying to grab that two per cent or three per cent advantage that Senator Minchin and others close to the Prime Minister think they can obtain from disenfranchising so many millions of Australian people. The government has not even had a joint standing committee inquiry into the issue of voluntary voting as a full inquiry but may have done some work in passing. So you want to introduce this in the dark.

We also believe that experimenting with voluntary voting now is the wrong time to do so. The outcome of this convention will be binding to the effect that it will decide the proposal to go to the Australian public. It is an important issue and resolution that this government wants to obtain from this convention—a constitutional one.

But the talk has all been about obtaining consensus. If you want to obtain consensus in this process, the last thing you should be doing is putting up a legislative structure that will force the different groups back to their constituencies to shore up their support behind their respective barricades. If you want to involve as many people as possible in educated debate, then that is enhanced by ensuring that people are engaged in the process. Your proposal will basically mean a hardening up of the two alternative sides. That will be their priority. The reality of the experiments with voluntary voting internationally is that it is very much back to the base and we have to try to build up the base and not spend money on it. In fact, organisations will not have the money to spend to engage the swinging voters—the people who should be engaged in this particular process.

We also have concerns about security. It is clear that no extra resources will be allocated to ensure that the ballot is delivered in a secure manner. That was made apparent to the committee by postal authorities. We are talking here about a four-week ballot. The only way of ensuring that a person identified on the envelope is the person who voted is by using dates of birth. Give us a break! Dates of birth are so easily accessible. If you are an employer of a couple of people or a couple of thousand people, you will have their dates of birth. If you are the owner of a nursing home, you will have the dates of birth of anyone living in your nursing home. If you are the owner of a block of flats, you will have that sort of personal information.

That sort of personal information is so readily available to so many people. You are saying to us that that is your important measure to protect the security of the ballot. It just will not wash; it does not wash. Then the Electoral Commission says, `Well, we have the bar code.' But the bar code only identifies the envelope as a legitimate envelope for the Electoral Commission. That will not, despite the Prime Minister's eye glazing performance in his second reading speech on this matter, provide any extra security. The experience has been that there are security problems.

The other thing that is placed at peril with this experimentation in voluntary voting is the secrecy of the ballot. The ballot slip will hang around in the envelopes in people's homes for some four weeks before they have to return them. When people will be susceptible to all sorts of discussions and so on, when they will not have the privacy of the ballot box—a privacy which is much cherished in Australian politics—then you cannot guarantee the secrecy of this ballot. Once again, this measure with these implications has been proposed without any public debate.

We say this particular proposal for constitutional reform is something that should be taken seriously. The only way to take it seriously is to ensure maximum engagement. This particular proposal before us ensures minimum engagement. Senator Minchin, if the government were to take it seriously, it would be spending the extra $3 billion or $4 billion, which is really the differential between the government's proposal and a compulsory attendance ballot, and ensuring that 95 per cent of the Australian public participate in it—not 35 per cent—and that more than the seven million people in the electorate expected not to vote do vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing here with the issue of voluntary voting. That is an absolutely critical issue to the debate because so many amendments will flow from the decisions that will arise therefrom. I want to commence my remarks by drawing your attention to the report of the inquiry of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee into the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill. I want to refer you to my minority report and the last paragraph, which I was dismayed to have had to write. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I wish to express my intense dissatisfaction with a majority report which has failed to follow the normal Senate committee practice of receiving submissions and oral evidence and presenting a balanced and fair analysis of all the views put forward. The obvious bias and selectivity of the report does not, in my view, reflect well on the Chair, in this particular instance, and unfortunately significantly diminishes the credibility of the majority report.
I turn to the minority report submitted by the Labor members in the same inquiry. They wrote the following right at the commencement of their report:

Before commencing our discussion of the Bill, we wish to express our grave concern at the approach taken by the Chairman, Senator Abetz, in preparing, and the members of the Coalition in supporting, the Chairman's Report. Unlike the tradition with reports from this Committee, the Chairman's Report does not provide a full and frank discussion of both sides of the issues arising out of this Bill.

I think those criticisms are very strong, and I will draw your attention to the inference I draw from them in a moment. First, I want to refer you to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which was brought down this week. I want to quote to you from my minority report where I said:

The recommendation of the Majority Committee for the introduction of voluntary voting appears to be a recommendation for strategic partisan reasons. What is worse, the case for voluntary voting has been argued selectively in this report, lacks empirical integrity, and has been argued without attempting to balance the views of those who support voluntary voting with the alternative case. It is desirable for all Parliamentary Inquiries to receive submissions and oral evidence and present a fair and balanced analysis of all the views put forward, in their reports. With regard to this section this Report does not do so. For instance statements such as 3.4: `This opinion is shared by the Committee', is wrong and deliberately misleading. This is an opinion shared by the Coalition majority members of the Committee.
The evident bias and selectivity of this section has unfortunately diminished the credibility of the voluntary voting arguments so presented.

In one or two respects we have the usual suspects transferring from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Those include me and Senator Abetz. We are diametrically opposed on this issue.

But we see a common theme. What we see is that the voluntary voting argument is so badly put, so intellectually bereft and so morally weak in its arguments that it points to a real incapacity on the part of its supporters to express their argument cogently, with conviction and without fear. It is fear that drives them not to present both sides of the story. We are not afraid of that, but they are, and they exhibit that fear by the devious, manipulative and very poor arguments and methods they present. That is because this route is being pursued by Liberal Party strategists for reasons which have nothing to do with the moral arguments for voluntary voting and everything to do with the strategic advantage that they believe will accrue to the Liberal Party.

It is very simple. There are two or three components. The first is that a benefit of two or three per cent is computed to accrue to the Liberal Party as a consequence of voluntary voting. That, depending on whether you are dealing in marginal seats or not, can vary from four or five seats upwards. The second component is the anguish members of the Liberal Party have in failing ever to manage government on their own. A number of them resent being tied to the National Party—maybe a lot of them resent it, but I have only heard a number of them express their resentment. Voluntary voting may deliver them from the yoke of the National Party. That is another attribute they want.

In complete contrast to the opposition Labor Party—which has consistently gained government in its own right, as a single party with its own policies—the Liberal Party is incapable of gaining government in its own right. My belief is that one of their motives in introducing voluntary voting in this bill is to advance their cause, to the disadvantage of the National Party. It is cynical, manipulative and very hard‐headed. We understand it. We know what you are about, Senator Minchin. We are in the political game. But I do not think you are going to be able to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian public or the media or informed commentators.

We are not afraid to have our arguments tested or to promote them. Let us turn to those areas in which we regard voluntary voting as delivering a far more favourable outcome in the democratic process. In doing so, may I add, incidentally, to the statistics with which we are assailed constantly and recognise that at least 10 per cent of the countries in the world now have some form of compulsory voting. To those who dismiss countries like Argentina and Brazil as just little places, I suggest that there are many people looking at compulsory voting with interest, including Fiji most lately.

These are the arguments we outline in favour of compulsory voting. We say voting is the civic responsibility and duty of citizens in a democratic society and each citizen must take responsibility for how they are governed and by whom. We say compulsory voting ensures the expression of the choice of all those eligible to vote and not just of those who vote—and not just the majority of those who vote. Compulsory voting ensures, as far as possible, that parliaments are elected according to the wishes of all the citizens of a country. We say that compulsory voting materially assists in legitimising the entire electoral process and each parliament chosen by it: John Howard's coalition enjoys the legitimacy of the Australian people, because all the people are represented in the parliament—they all had the opportunity of voting in the election.

We say that social and political cohesion is promoted and alienation of the disadvantaged from the political process is diminished by compulsory voting. We say that compulsory voting ensures the representation of all community groups. We say that through compulsory voting citizens develop a sense of ownership of the political and decision making process. We say that compulsory voting contributes to civic education and the en trenchment of civic values and that, in elections where voting is compulsory, the focus is on the issues and the choices before the voters rather than on mechanisms to get people to the polls.

We say that compulsory voting diminishes the opportunities for the exercise of corrupt, illegal and improper practices such as the buying off of members of the community during elections. We say that a compulsory voting system makes it extremely difficult for the practice of multiple voting to occur undetected. We say that the cost of elections is high for political participants and not having to get voters out—as has to be done for voluntary voting—saves expenditure which can be used for other campaigning activities. Compulsory voting has been with us for 80 years. It constitutes best democratic practice. It is a form of democracy which is to be desired and should be promoted internationally.

We should indicate whilst we are at it that the West Australian Commission on Government, appointed by Premier Richard Court, looked at this whole issue of compulsory voting. The Commission on Government has, without doubt, conducted one of the most extensive reviews of our political systems and principles this century. I say to Senator Minchin that they unequivocally recommended the retention of compulsory voting. The commission found that compulsory voting ensured the expression of the choice of the majority of the electorate which assists in legitimising the entire electoral process and the parliaments chosen by it. Page 316 of the West Australian Commission on Government, Report No. 1, August 1995, states:
A speaker at the Harvey public seminar reminded the audience of this State's experience of campaigning prior to the introduction of compulsory voting:

Well, I'm old enough to remember when it wasn't compulsory voting. My family were very into politics in Harvey—it was May Holman's time—and I used to go around in cars with politicians and pick up voters. We only took our own people, our own party. We brought them back to vote.

There was a lot of dirty work going on in those days. You bribed people to come and vote for your party even though they didn't belong to your party. When compulsory voting came in, it cut out a lot of that. I was only in my teens, but I knew a lot of it was going on. It was common knowledge. It was disgusting.

Let us move forward with this matter. The additional cost of introducing compulsory voting has been computed at its highest at $18 million by the government, and they are likely to promote the highest figure possible. The figure that we have heard at the lower end, I think from Senator Bolkus, was about $9 million. We are talking about an additional cost of between 50c and $1 per Australian voter to retain a system which is our right.

We say that your party, Senator Minchin, is split on this issue. We say that this is a divisive issue and we say that you are wrong to use this republican debate to promote it. We say that the disadvantage of a postal ballot is that it will disenfranchise the three million or so Australians who move house every year. We say that it will impact upon people from a non-English speaking background who find postal vote instructions too hard. There is no-one to assist them, as is normally the case. It will disadvantage students and young people who move around a great deal. As Senator Bolkus has clearly outlined, there are significant security concerns. Your only argument in favour of your proposal—your only cogent one—is cost. We think the cost is worth it. Democracy is expensive. Let no-one listening and no-one in this chamber misunderstand it. Democracy is expensive. It is worth paying for, it is worth fighting for and it is worth keeping.

The last item I want to cover is this: if this voluntary voting proposal goes forward, we see it unequivocally as the thin edge of the wedge. We will resist this in every form possible in every forum that comes before this House. Accordingly, I advise you that we will support the amendment put by Labor, which, as you know, is exactly the same as the amendment of both the Greens and ourselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend Senator Minchin for the way in which he has undertaken a very difficult task. It is not an easy situation that he has been confronted with. He has done that with integrity and a great deal of expertise. As I indicated a moment ago, I was very thankful for the information that he provided to me and my office with respect to all matters relating to the current legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to think of what the current legislation is all about and what it intends to do. Simply stated, the legislation that is currently before us is about the establishment of a convention to consider whether Australia should become a republic, which republican model should be put to the electorate to consider against the status quo and in what time frame and under what circumstances might any changes be considered. It is a very limited area of consideration, but I suppose it is one of the arguments that has been put forward for voluntary voting.

It was interesting to go back to the previous constitutional conventions and what they had on their plate and compare them to what has been proposed in this particular piece of legislation. In 1891 the delegates were actually appointed by colonial parliaments. Incidentally, the guiding principles in much of our deliberations here on these matters should be the guiding principles of democracy and federalism, which includes equality of states rights. In 1891 the delegates were appointed by the colonial parliaments. In 1897-98 the delegates were elected by the people in their respective colony.

The exception was the state of Western Australia which I found to be interesting, given what was alluded to by Senator Murray just a moment ago that only recently the commission in Western Australia indicated, I think unanimously, that there should be compulsory voting and that to establish voluntary voting in electoral matters would set a very bad precedent.

The 1973 convention, which a number of us would remember, had 112 delegates, 72 of whom came from the states and were appointed by the parliaments of those states. Incidentally, in that convention again you had equality of voting from each of the states. So it is a very interesting exercise to have a look at the history. But the overwhelming issue in respect of this particular amendment that is currently before us is whether or not there should be compulsory voting. The proposal before us is to oppose clause 11 which indi cates that voting is voluntary, that a person is not required to vote at an election.

I am not going to canvass all of the matters that have been raised by colleagues in this debate or outside. Quite frankly, I am concerned at the precedent that would be established if we voted for the government's proposition, that is to say, to entrench in legislation voluntary voting on a most important area for the future of this country. It does concern me; there is no doubt about that.

I would like to allude to one of the contributions made, that is, the contribution of Senator Cooney. I have always been interested in his contributions on debates such as this. I, too, am most concerned about the precedent that this might establish. The question is whether it is all worth it or whether the purposes of this particular legislation can be achieved by other means. As Senator Cooney said, if you are looking for people to make the decisions, then you look for people who have been elected to their responsible position to speak for the electorate. In the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997, that is not the case in a number of areas. For example, 36 of the delegates are going to be appointed. I hesitate to use the Whitlamese phrase of 36 faceless men, but it does come to mind. There would be a few around this chamber—not too many—who would remember that.

It seems rather odd that this is going to be a polyglot type of convention. We are going to have some appointed and some elected, and those who are going to be elected are going to be elected by only a few. This is what this is all about. My view is that, if you are going to have an election, you have an election, and if you are going to have a popular election for direct appointment or election of delegates to the convention, you have it by the usual method of electoral voting, that is compulsory voting, which has stood the test of time, certainly over recent years, in this country.

One of the big problems that I think any government faces—I heard it the other day—is that by and large governments tend to distrust electors. That is heartily reciprocated by the electors, generally speaking, after the election has taken place—it does not matter which government is in power. I am not saying that that is necessarily a bad thing. A healthy distrust in the sense of the need to be sometimes a little sceptical as to what governments might suggest is not harmful, provided that the expression of that is always positive and that persons can then exercise, both directly and through their elected representatives, some sort of control function over the elected government. That is precisely where we come in. As senators elected from the various states, it is our responsibility not only to represent the persons of the state but also a major function of this Senate is to exercise audit and control procedures over the elected government.

When the actual composition of the convention comes up, I will be making further comments. But here it is, I suppose, a narrow situation as to whether or not the principle of compulsory voting should be somehow undermined by this particular legislation. I fear that it would be undermined by this legislation. There would be a dangerous precedent set. I am aware that that is a view shared by persons right across the political spectrum. I am sure Senator Minchin and others would be aware that that is a view shared by quite a number of persons who are in the government parties. People have this concern about the precedent. I really am of the view that the Senate, at this stage, should adopt the amendment—that is, to delete the proposition in clause 11 which would entrench in Commonwealth legislation voluntary voting on a matter of such great importance to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Harradine. To take maybe a lighter spin on it, one has to look to see just how Indonesian we are going to become with respect to the way this constitutional convention is appointed. I have had a little look through the bill to see whether the government will not be appointing the Leader of the Opposition for the purposes of this convention.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing you do is get rid of compulsory voting. The next thing you do is move to appointing a big slab of the delegates. General Suharto appoints a good slab of the parliament in Indonesia. He then puts a restriction on the parties that can vote and then of course determines who is going to lead those parties, as we saw when Megawati Sukarnoputri was bumped out by the government and somebody else was put in.

I did say, Senator Minchin, that I was taking a lighter look at this and wondering whether the government was not moving to an Indonesian style democracy, because you have two of the moves in place here. Of course, that is not the case. But we have, I submit, some aspects of democratic process in this country which are very important in ensuring that parliaments function as top‐rate democracies—that it is a case of one person, one vote, one value. This legislation moves us well back down the track and away from that.

Australia is one of the few countries in the world which have compulsory voting. The Americans very often put to me, at least when I am discussing this matter, their abhorrence of anything compulsory. But they are slowly moving to take up the Australian compulsion for seat belts, which have saved thousands of lives in this country and would have saved tens of thousands over there if they had adopted them when we did. There are many things that governments have to legislate for which require some compulsion for the benefit of the wider community. That is what rules and regulations are about. The point is, where do you draw the line?

Through a great period of debate earlier this century, the Australian legislators and people have come to regard compulsory voting as one of those very important, if not central, laws which put upon us not only rights but also responsibilities as citizens. Why should a constitutional convention, which is going to hopefully shape the political form in which Australia goes into the next century as part of the community of nations, be seen as second rate? Why should we be going back 70 or 80 years, as far as the former voting for this convention is concerned, and dropping the compulsion to vote? It does have an air of second‐ratedness about it. It is appearing to indicate that this convention does not matter all that much, or at least the outcome of the convention is not going to be as important as the outcome of the debates which take place in state or federal parliaments. I submit that it is.

The government has determined there will be a convention. The convention is about whether or not we will have a republic and, if the Greens amendments are adopted, about a much wider look at how our constitution is shaped to equip Australia as a modern democracy in the community of nations. At the outset, to say, `We'll degrade the voting system. We'll let people vote if they do or don't want to. We'll make it a postal vote. You don't have to attend. We're worried about a few million dollars. We can give BHP $100 million on a platter in the diesel fuel rebate, but we're concerned that $9 million or $18 million is too much to put towards ensuring we have a first-rate compliance with the voting tradition in this country,' seems to me very odd indeed.

I am totally opposed to the government appointing delegates to this convention. The people ought to be voting for all the delegates to the convention. I am totally opposed to the degrading of the voting system so that it is, firstly, a postal vote and, secondly, a `vote if you want; vote if you don't want' system. The government is sending an indication to the people that this convention does not really matter. We have a long way to go, because people often cannot take out the time in their daily lives to understand the ramifications of things like constitutional conventions. We have a long way to go to bring home to many Australians the importance of this convention and their right to have a say. So it is very important for the government, having decided on this option, to be elevating in the public mind just how much each person's vote does matter.

You do not do that by saying, `Well, if you don't want to vote, don't worry about it. Skip it on this occasion.' That is a direct message that this vital part of shaping our democracy is not quite as important as the way democracy works through its parliament, and it is the wrong way to go. That is why the Greens have joined the Australian Democrats and the opposition in putting forward the amendment which would do away with this second‐rate, non-compulsory aspect of the appointment of this convention.

We will come to the other matters that I have spoken about a little further down the line, but the Greens are in favour of a fully elected people's convention which is able to not only determine whether or not we shall have a republic but put forward recommendations about how that republic should work and to upgrade and update and make more appropriate to Australia in the 21st century the constitution, which was written in the 19th century. It is a great opportunity. It is an historic opportunity. It should be elevated to the importance it deserves. It should be a people's convention, and it should be given the status that it deserves through having in place for that convention the usual voting process.

I point out as well that we will be moving in the committee stage to have at the same time as this vote is taken a plebiscite on what people think about the republic. The opinion polls show the majority of people want a republic. Let us have this convention discussing what sort of republic we should have rather than get bogged down in a debate between monarchists and republicans. Let us move to that stage. There is a money saver for the government: have the plebiscite first. Have the convention, having discovered what the polls are showing—that the people of Australia want a republic—and work on what form of republic they want instead of spending a lot of time debating what is good about the monarchy and what it is good about a republic.

The majority of Australians want a republic, let us face it, but let us confirm that through a proper plebiscite held at the same time as this vote for representation on the convention. Let us save millions of dollars in streamlining this process in that way rather than continuing with the current formula, which is to have a convention, a debate between monarchists and republicans, and then ask people afterwards what they want.

BREAK.PARA: It seems as though this is being done back to front. It is clear to me that, if the government wants to save millions of dollars, it will reverse that order and give everybody a say on polling day about, first, whom they want to represent them at the convention and, second, whether or not they want a republic. Surely that is commonsense. Surely that is the sensible and logical way to be going, and surely if the government is concerned about dollars that is the option it should take up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment really relates to the deletion of the clause in the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill that we have specifically put in that voting be voluntary, that a person is not required to vote in an election. Of course, if the bill were silent on this matter voting would, by definition, be voluntary. You have to overtly require people to be compelled to vote if you wish to do that. But we did feel in relation to this bill that to put the matter beyond doubt we would specifically provide in the bill that voting be voluntary. We did it, frankly, coming from the perspective of a Liberal government. We are not the sort of party or government that abrogates the normal democratic rights of citizens without being convinced that it is absolutely necessary to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: We have treated this entirely on its merits. Of course, some on our side think that in relation to federal parliamentary elections it is regrettably necessary to abrogate the right of citizens to choose whether or not to vote, but even those people in the case of an election for delegates to a convention were not convinced that the right to choose whether or not to participate in this particular election should be abrogated by the parliament. We must remember that is what we are talking about: by virtue of making it compulsory, the normal democratic right of citizens to choose whether or not to participate in a particular election is taken away.

By virtue of making participation in this election compulsory, Australians who choose not to participate will be guilty of an offence for which they could end up in gaol. After every federal election numerous Australians, having exercised their fundamental democratic right to choose not to vote, do end up in gaol. So what we are proposing here is that, if Australians of whatever number do make a conscious decision that they are not prepared to vote for either Malcolm Turnbull or Lloyd Waddy, they could end up in gaol. That is the effect of making this particular ballot compulsory.

I respect the comments made by Senator Harradine, and I understand the argument that this is some sort of precedent, but we are not talking about a change to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. We are not talking about parliamentary elections. Voluntary elections are conducted across this country every day of every year—trade union elections, elections within political parties, elections in a whole range of civil organisations that make up the structure of this country, elections at the local government level. They are all conducted voluntarily.

It is a feature of our federal parliamentary system that, since the early 1920s but not for the first 20 years of this democracy, it has been compulsory for people to vote. We put that to one side. We are dealing with this election of delegates to a 10-day convention on its merits, and I ask the Senate to do so.

I understand that the Labor Party are, in my view mistakenly, absolutely terrified of voluntary voting because they believe, and I think wrongly, that they get a considerable advantage from people being forced to vote and they are terrified that their voters will be reluctant to turn out if they are not forced to do so by the power of the state. We can have that argument in relation to parliamentary elections, but we are not talking about a parliamentary election in this case. So I ask those opposite to put aside their terror and fear of people having the right to choose whether or not to vote in this case.

In our view, it is unduly authoritarian and paternalistic to force people to participate in this. I have used the public airwaves to say that the government will be doing everything it can to encourage all Australians to participate in this election. We will honestly and genuinely do so. We do want Australians to participate, but we are not prepared to pro pose or agree to a law which will make Australians guilty of an offence if they choose not to vote, and that is what you are asking for when you seek to make this vote compulsory.

I would also point out the somewhat paradoxical nature of your position. From the point of view of Labor, the Greens and the Democrats, this is about wanting a quite fundamental change to our constitution, but you are absolutely outraged because we propose that the election of delegates be done by a system slightly different to that which has been traditionally the case in parliamentary elections. I would suggest that is paradoxical.

I would also point out that, in objecting to voluntary voting for the election of delegates to a convention, you are objecting to a system of election used by every one of the world's great democracies and one that was just used to elect—as I am sure you are thrilled to know—a British Labour government. It does seem to us to be utterly extraordinary that a system used in every major democracy cannot be used because it is so terrible and dangerous for the election of delegates to a convention. I assure you that we are dealing with this on its merits. It is not a proposition to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act and I would ask the Senate to deal with it on its merits. The government proposes that the clause stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me briefly respond to some of the non-arguments that were presented by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, in what I felt was a rather feeble contribution on this particular issue because it is important.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Labor Party is concerned, I hear what Senator Minchin says about the international comparisons that he wants to make. I hear what he says about the United Kingdom election. I know in fact—though Senator Minchin did not say so—that Mr Blair was elected with the biggest majority in the United Kingdom since 1830. That is the truth of matter—the biggest majority in the United Kingdom since 1830; but he was also elected with the lowest voter turnout since 1935.

Of course this is the nature of other political systems where the concentration is not on policies, not on the platforms of the parties and not on what is put before the electorate in terms of ideas and programs for government. The concentration in those systems is on getting the vote out. I do not accept the international comparisons. I am disappointed that Senator Minchin on behalf of Liberal Party of Australia would try to run those false arguments in this chamber.

We in the Labor Party are concerned about this proposal and we are concerned because we have always supported the Australian ballot. We are not ashamed of saying so. We are not ashamed of saying so because we believe that the Australian electoral system is the best electoral system in the world. We believe there is none better. We believe it is a tried and true system. We are proud of it. We are not ashamed of it. We—not only the Labor Party, but the whole community—have embraced it since the Commonwealth Electoral Act of 1924. It is not just something the Labor Party cares about; it is something that all Australians care about.

We have a traditional system of voting in this country—an Australian ballot—and we say very clearly that a voluntary, postal electoral process is un‐Australian. It is not something that Australian voters are accustomed to. It is not something that Australian voters want or are used to. This is an unnecessarily difficult and complex proposal that I believe has been deliberately designed to ensure that there is lukewarm response to the issue of constitutional reform.

As far as the Labor Party is concerned, this is a gross manipulation of the electoral process and we are not ashamed to say so. As far as we are concerned, this convention proposal for a non-compulsory postal ballot rigs Australia's electoral system. It rigs it against young people. It rigs it against people of non-English speaking background. It rigs it against people who do not live in the major capital cities. It rigs it against the poor and the more vulnerable in our society. It rigs it against the disadvantaged in our society and, for the Labor Party's part, we are not going to stand by and allow that to happen.

Mr Temporary Chairman, this is a proposition driven by certain Liberal Party apparatchiks and their motivation is pure political partisanship. I have also been a machine operator, like Senator Minchin, for the Labor Party. I know the background and I understand. He is arguing the case for a certain section of the Liberal Party, but I think that his sights are set far too low. This is about our electoral system, confidence in our electoral system and all of the Australian population having a capacity to participate in the Constitutional Convention. After all, it was Mr Howard who said:
I will involve all Australians at the beginning, the middle and the end of the process.

We are about involving all Australians, as we always have been, in this process. We are about ensuring that people continue to exercise their vote as one of their obligations of citizenship—like paying taxes, going to school and obeying the laws of the land. Another community obligation that Australians accept is voting in elections and it is a tried and true method. It is the Australian way and it is for those reasons that the Labor Party so strongly opposes this proposition driven by political partisanship from the Liberal Party to abolish the compulsory voting system.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That clause 11 stand as printed

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I understand that there is an arrangement between the whips that will give me a little latitude on this speech. On 30 October last year I made a speech expressing concern about the views of the independent member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). Today there remains a sizeable gap between the Hanson myth and the reality, a gap that demands exposure. A book published under the name of the independent member for Oxley is called Pauline Hanson—the Truth . If this book is the truth, why are the names of the authors conspicuous by their absence? Anonymity in this case implies shame and guilt, something to hide. How can concealment be part of the truth? What else has been hidden from the Australian public under the populist mantle of One Nation?

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Hanson declined to be present at the parliamentary debate on racial tolerance, because she had business in Victoria. The truth is that she could not support the motion. The truth is that she let down the people of Oxley by not being in parliament to defend her views. The truth is that Ms Hanson spends a lot of time away from her electorate, despite saying at the declaration of the poll, `I will be concentrating on Oxley.' Later, she also said, `I will not be apologising for, or retracting, anything I have said.' The truth is that Ms Hanson spends so much time away because the media attention has convinced her that she is wasted in Oxley.

Instead of remaining independent, as Ms Hanson promised many Australians at earlier meetings, she compromised her independence by forming her own party under her own name. There could be integrity in the Caroline Chisholm party or a Mary MacKillop party; but the Pauline Hanson party is arrogance indeed. The other part of its name, One Nation, is at direct odds with her claim that she would not fight for Aboriginal voters in Oxley.

The Australian on 4 March 1996 reported that Ms Hanson said she was fighting for `the white community, the immigrants, the Italians, the Greeks, whoever; it really doesn't matter—anyone apart from Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders'. Thirty years ago the Australian people called overwhelmingly for the democratic franchise to be extended to all Australians, black and white. Today we have a political party leader who would rip up the level voting field and say that some votes are worth more than others. How does this fit under the banner of One Nation? It does not. Ms Hanson, on her own definition, is about two Australias, two nations: one white caucasian and one for everyone else.

Ms Hanson is no down‐under Evita. What can she offer? Platitudes—plenty of them—but they do not get the job done. Does she still have the ear of ministers or a voice behind the cabinet door? No. Does she have some way of influencing government deci sions? No. The truth is that Pauline Hanson can do nothing. Since being elected in March 1996, Ms Hanson has contributed to the debate on legislation on three occasions. Two of these bills were related to child support and the other was on immigration. Is this the CV of a person who expects nationwide electoral support? The parliament has debated many important pieces of legislation covering industry policy, trade, industrial relations, regional and rural Australia and so on. Where was the voice of the people of Oxley?

Who are the victims of her simplistic tirades that seek to appeal to our prejudice? Is it people who look different from her? From reading her speeches it is obvious that she has trouble with people who look different from her. There are several references to the way people look. In a speech to the Australian Reform Party on 12 October 1996 she stated:
Mainstream Australians must be allowed to have a say in how this country will look in a hundred years time.
Later in that speech she said:
The atrocities in Ireland and Bosnia appal us all but the really terrifying thing is that we see people who look like each other raping, murdering and blowing each other up.

Is conflict between people who look different terrifying because it to be expected and can be justified? The truth is that Ms Hanson fears Asians because they look different from her. This manifests itself in comment after comment designed to give Asians a bad name. Ms Hanson has referred to Asians in the context of drug pushers, disease carriers, ghetto formers and job stealers. The remarks about the dangers of being swamped by Asians conjures up the old frightening image of the yellow peril. What a great message to send to the children of Australia whom we wish to see grow up tolerant and unprejudiced. This is racism, pure and simple.

Her strategy is to evade the truth by reducing current affairs into catch phrases that demand no brain power and no energy to digest. This is to let down and fail her supporters because it denies them understanding of reality—a reality that is full of complexities, trauma and variables beyond anyone's control. We could all say we would like sales tax to be removed from Australian cars. Then responsible journalists would want to know where expenditure is to be slashed as a result. Would it be on drought relief, primary research and development, or government services in regional areas; or would we raise the Medicare levy? Perhaps we would just run up exorbitant deficits and turn ourselves into a financial basket case.

The people of Australia deserve the whole truth, not a self‐serving, rose‐coloured glasses vision. Anyone in this place could grab headlines by coming out with unrealistic, populist statements. What judgment prevents us? It is the judgment that says you will not be taken seriously in the long run, the judgment that says a platitude is no answer to the complex problems of today's changing world and, most importantly, the judgment that says it is wrong to escape responsibility by attaching blame to scapegoats, easily identified because they look or act differently.
The unknown author of a paper in Pauline Hanson's book compares Kim Beazley's attitude to Asia as:
It's like running a shop and having a major trading partner only deal with you if you allow them first to have sex with your children, move into your home and take over.

Most Australians would think this kind of talk is beyond the pale yet this is copyrighted to Pauline Hanson. I remind the Senate of Ms Hanson's assertions on the PM program on 22 April 1997. She said:
I've put my name to this book and I have backed this book.
Later she repeated:
I put my name to the book and I support my book.

This book uses arguments from a paper by noted extremist Denis McCormack of Australians Against Further Immigration fame entitled The Grand Plan: Asianisation of Australia—race, place and power . McCormack even claims to have proof‐read the Hanson book. A fellow AAFI candidate once said in a New South Wales election: `My policy on refugees and illegals is to reopen the second Yallah meatworks, creating up to 500 local jobs, and convert them to blood and bone.' Does Ms Hanson go along with Denis McCormack's arguments? She must. They are in her book. Are we to take it then that Mr McCormack and his associates are viewed as credible sources for One Nation policy development?
Apart from the bloodthirsty ramblings about Aborigines, there are meandering fantasies about republics of Australia with a population of 1.8 billion people in the year 2050. The book says:

Australasia's new President is Poona Li Hung. Ms Hung, a lesbian, is of multiracial descent, of Indian and Chinese background, and was felt by the world government to be the most suitable President. She is also part machine—the first cyborg president.
Does Ms Hanson agree with this scenario? It is in her book. She claims to be representing the views of ordinary Australians.
On the gun debate, the author notes that:
Freud did recognise that a fear of weapons is a sign of retarded sexual and emotional maturity.
Does Ms Hanson agree? It is in her book.

The reader is also told that the groundwork for a global gulag, a cosmopolitan police state, has already been `put in place' through international treaties and that `governments must comply with as surely as if the law were from Yahweh himself'. Does Ms Hanson believe that we live in a global gulag? She must, it is in her book.
