We are told that Ms Hanson is brave in saying what ordinary Australians really think. I challenge that and I dispute that. Where are the tens of thousands who sit around their living rooms discussing the global gulag, a cyborg Asian lesbian president and comparing Kim Beazley's trade policy with child molestation? They do not exist in their thousands or in their hundreds and you would be flat out finding three or four.

This article concludes by saying that Pauline Hanson is `one of the few politicians to even dare criticise the internationalist rule of Australia.' No wonder, therefore, that Ms Hanson has found fellow travellers in a variety of right wing extremists who explain everything in terms of international conspiracies.
Bruce Whiteside's contribution at the end of the truth book talks about `wresting our nation's destiny from those who pander to the big A factor—the Asians and the Aborigines.' He wrote:

BREAK.PARA: Pauline has absolutely no intention of becoming involved with any party, old or new. Pauline Hanson is singularly independent.
Even to her own supporters, Pauline cannot be true.
Mrs Whiteside told Woman's Day that Bruce was Pauline's greatest fan but, in the end, he felt `betrayed'.

The clear truth which emerges from Pauline Hanson's book is that she supports race as a ground for discrimination. That is why she attracts the extremists. That is why National Action turns up to her meetings.

We will pay a terrible price if we follow the Hanson tune. Our children will suffer not only from an intolerant and prejudiced society, but also from lost export markets. Under a `fortress Australia' policy, we could not negotiate more open access in offshore markets. Jobs would go. Regional economies would come unstuck.

I spent 26 years as a salesman and the best lesson I learnt was that you do not insult your customers if you want their business. That is the basis of any sales organisation. We produce a multibillion dollar surplus of agricultural goods. If we promote a bad image of our best customers—Asian buyers—what will we do when they knock our goods back? Where will Pauline Hanson sell our primary industry goods?

We must realise that Asia is the market for 74.5 per cent of our minerals and fuel exports—some $11.6 billion worth. Asia is the market for 53.6 per cent or more than $13 billion of our manufacturers' exports. Asia buys 69.9 per cent of our primary product exports. We export over $11 billion of primary products to Asia. Over two‐thirds of the export product at the farm gate goes to Asia.

The Supermarket to Asia Council recently predicted that food exports to Asia would jump by 60 per cent to $16.4 billion during the five years to 2000‐01. A vote for Pauline Hanson is a vote to cut the throat of the bush. It should fall to our regional communities and farm leaders to demand that Ms Hanson stop endangering our markets and our reputation in Asia. If Ms Hanson is only saying what everyone is thinking, then Australia must have an economic death wish.

There is no panacea for life's problems. There is no political messiah who can come in and turn everything around. For those who are tempted to believe that Ms Hanson is value for their vote, I ask that they carefully scrutinise the company that she keeps and the statements that she supports. The truth book is not a collection of sayings from the man in the street. It is the ramblings of a political opportunist and some disturbed minds. Hanson and One Nation claim that they have nothing to do with extremist groups such as the League of Rights. Regarding extremists, David Ettridge, the party's director, in the Australian on 30 May, claimed:
I'm streetwise enough to spot them and get rid of them.

But the facts are that Pauline Hanson's One Nation not only harbours and promotes extremists as office bearers and potential candidates, but it advertises in the anti‐semitic, racist and extremist rag, The Strategy . Along with pages of glowing editorial, Ms Hanson's party has taken a half page ad soliciting for membership and donations. This was not done months ago when she was a naive politician. This advertisement appeared as recently as last month—May. (Extension of time granted).

TALK.START.PARA: —Ettridge was boasting to the national press about not having anything to do with extremists when his party had just done a deal with the country's most powerful extreme Right publication. The Strategy promotes many of Australia's leading extremists, from the League of Rights to Christian identity ministries, to the National Reporter , Lock, Stock and Barrel , Denis McCormack, Dennis Stevenson, and even uses stories from the La Rouchian news service. To just give a sample of the editorial style, there is an article by Vera Fletcher which compares Anglo‐Jewish institutions to supping with the devil. She says:

BREAK.PARA: We, the white race, are enveloped in a vicious deadly race war.
This involves maniacal minds—
read `Jews'—
conceiving the destruction of our gene pools and seed stocks of our white creative race.

And this is the paper in which One Nation advertised for supporters. The same edition that carried Ms Hanson's sales pitch also carried an article alleging that Martin Bryant could not have acted alone in the Port Arthur massacre and that it was all a conspiracy.

The editor of The Strategy, Ray Platt, organised the visit to Australia of the US militia extremist, Jack McLamb. McLamb's business partner, Bo Gritz, had stood as a Vice‐presidential nominee on the ticket of former Ku Klux klansman, David Duke. McLamb and his associates have featured prominently in American press profiles of groups with similar conspiracy theories as the Oklahoma bomber, Timothy McVeigh. McLamb was described as `one of the nation's most militant militia organisers'.
Not surprisingly, one of the contacts for McLamb's Australian tour is Peter Archer. And Tony Pitt pops up again reviewing McLamb's Brisbane visit on behalf of meeting organisers.

Who is the One Nation organiser and would‐be candidate in Newcastle? The very same Peter Archer. Archer was for a long time on the staff of The Strategy. In 1994 Archer addressed and helped organise a forum, which featured a line‐up of distinguished extremists including the national director of the League of Rights, David Thompson, and Joe Bryant—who may be remembered for championing the spurious claims of the self‐styled duke and duchess of Marlborough.Archer describes the events as follows:
One of the projects I was extremely proud to be involved in was a magnificent event called `Inverell 94'.

Not only does Ms Hanson sell her wares in the nation's most notorious far Right newspaper, but she recruits her organisers from its staff. Archer is also self‐published. His book The Australian Crisis crudely summarises a variety of one world government conspiracies. Archer pays special thanks to none other than Jeremy Lee, former deputy national director of the League of Rights. The book endorses material from Jeremy Lee, Peter Sawyer, a League of Rights front—the Institute for Economic Democracy—as well as Joe Bryant. All are notorious for their contribution to the extreme Right.

Peter Sawyer tried to tell us that this parliament house was built to a satanic occult design and that George Bush was the head of a child molesting ring. Archer's paranoia reaches to the country music industry. About the singer John Williamson, he says:

Is he really the true blue dinky di Aussie that his image portrays? Or is he really a socialist one worlder using deception as the Pied Piper did to lead us into the new world order and world government.
Obviously, Pauline Hanson thinks that Archer is prime One Nation material. Are his heroes also hers? The Peter Sawyers and Jeremy Lees? Are his conspiracy theories and paranoia also hers?

I mentioned Tony Pitt as a writer for The Strategy. His latest role is as the secretary of `The Bay' One Nation group in Queensland. Pitt used to produce his own paper called Fight, which housed a variety of extremists, including the League of Rights and Peter Sawyer. Pitt used to be press secretary for the confederate action party which disintegrated, following claims of fraud, unethical conduct and finances not accounted for. Does the same fate await One Nation?

Pitt was also press secretary to the extremist gun lobby group, the Firearm Owners Association, serving alongside Ron Owen, the publisher of yet another extremist rag, Lock, Stock and Barrel. This magazine promoted the racist AWB or Afrikaner resistance movement in South Africa to its readers. AWB's leader has just been sentenced to gaol for the attempted murder of one of his black workers and assault on another.

It is quite clear that Ms Hanson, far from distancing herself and her party from these extremists, is making them feel welcome. As with all populist movements, the great majority of supporters have no idea of the hidden agenda of some of the key people. This speech is to let them know, so they can make an informed decision about their involvement.

I also urge the nation's media, from the large city dailies to the small town weeklies, to prosecute the truth with regard to Ms Hanson and her extremist associates. Morally, socially and economically Australia cannot afford Ms Hanson. It is not serving the truth to report Ms Hanson's platitudes without her prejudices or to report one‐line policy statements without reporting on their consequences.

There will be well‐meaning candidates—honest, hardworking and patriotic Australians. It is for them that I fear most because, by association, they will lose their credibility and their good names. There will be no happy ending to the Pauline Hanson book, no romantic triumph at the poll, just a legacy of betrayal and misplaced trust and division in the wider community.

The people of Oxley, Bruce Whiteside, Ted Drane and an array of former advisers already litter the One Nation political landscape—betrayed and let down. Well meaning Hanson supporters should take warning now before they get burned as well. I seek leave to table my resource material.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish that the world was as simple as Pauline Hanson makes it out to be. I wish that the solutions were as obvious. But the truth is, they are not. Like Pauline Hanson, I have a small business background and a limited formal education. Politics can be terribly frustrating, especially when you are sensitive to the needs of your constituents. I have often been in trouble for my efforts—often fighting against the tide to deliver for my constituents—both in the public area and behind the scenes. But I have not taken the easy way out. I have been here for the long haul, the inch by inch slog. I know that Pauline Hanson's way is not, in the end, the way that will help her supporters. While she provides a temporary emotional outlet for fear and uncertainty, her solutions would only entrench trauma, insecurity and division.

BREAK.PARA: What sort of Australia do we want? One where Australians shout at other Australians across police barricades, where hearts that should beat as one in facing the challenges of our future instead beat to the drums of division? No, for in that conflict, we are all losers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Member for Oxley National Crime Authority Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Fine words, Senator Boswell. I am sure that everyone in the chamber agrees with you, but the question that has been asked, and which you will not respond to, is with regard to the National Party secretary in Queensland saying that the Labor Party will be last on the how-to-vote card. The Deputy Leader of the National Party is standing there, and Senator Boswell you could have given a commitment in this chamber now, that the National Party would put Pauline Hanson and her supporters last on your ticket. And you did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to turn to some events that took place last week before the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority and the efforts by some members of the committee to avoid discussion and evidence before the committee.

Many of you will know that we had John Elliott appear before us and that I had attempted to read some documentation. I would just like the Senate to take note that, in his evidence to the NCA, Mr Peter Scanlon concedes that he, Peter Scanlon, initiated the contact with Hawkins, that he received instructions from Ken Jarrett on how to conduct the negotiations, that he introduced Jarrett to Hawkins and that, after talking to Hawkins a second time, he reached agreement with Hawkins on the transactions. The transcript of evidence given to the NCA under oath by Mr Peter Scanlon reads:

"Now I wonder if I might ask you to tell us, Mr Scanlon, your first knowledge of the transaction referred to in the summons whereby a foreign exchange loss of some 39 odd million dollars was suffered by Elders IXL in favour of the Bank of New Zealand?"
"I think, sir, my involvement in that may be in setting up a hedge contract that led to the transaction."
"And can you recall when it was when you set up the hedge contract?"
"Approximately the third quarter of 1987."
"What were the circumstances in which you set about setting up that contract and who were the parties to it?"

"I was a non-executive director of Elders IXL at the time. Elders IXL had a large sterling exposure; it was their corporate policy to hedge assets back to Australian dollars. As a consequence of the Courage purchase some time earlier in that year, I think it was, they were substantially long in sterling and had been unable to find sufficient hedging contracts and coverage to eliminate that long position in sterling. At a number of the meetings during that part of 1987, it was brought to my attention that they were still long in sterling and had not been covered. In a conversation by phone with a Mr Hawkins from the Equiticorp Group, the conversation of which had other purposes if I recall, I asked if he had any interest in being on the other side of such a hedge contract. He, in fact, said, yes, and I suspect that that led to that hedge contract referred to in point 1 there, sir."
"Well, when you spoke to Hawkins and he expressed some interest in this matter, did you discuss it in terms of amounts and times? Was there any finality or certainty about the problem?"

"Yes, in relating it with him he said that he was interested in it. I believe the amount was of the order of 100 million pound he was interested in. I said to him that obviously I could not commit that I would get the Treasurer of Elders IXL to talk to him. After that phone call, I then talked to the Treasurer of Elders IXL, Mr Ken Jarrett, who in my recollection was not in the office here, he was overseas somewhere at that time."
"What were you able to tell him, that Hawkins was an interested party?"
"Yes, a very interested party, that he was interested provided the rates and that were correct, to be on the other side of a hedge contract of the order of 100 million pounds."
Page 645 reads:
"So, having had this conversation with—how many conversations did you have with Hawkins?"
"Two."
"I take it that we are dealing with the first one at the moment?"
"We are."
"You then contact Mr Jarrett who is overseas?"
"Yes."
"Tell him that Hawkins is interested. You are able to say to him that it is in the order of 100 million pounds. And that the terms something in the order of four years?"
"Yes."
"What does Jarrett say to you?"
"Jarrett says that he would be very keen to do that, but he was unable to follow up directly with Hawkins himself, and would I go back to him and try to tie it down."
"All right. Now, what follows after that, as far as you are concerned? "

"I cannot—I do not believe I had another telephone call conversation with Ken while he was away, but I may have. I am unsure of that. Either by phone or when Ken returned, he had rung me and to confirm that it was all done and I said, yes, and that was the last I had to do with it."
"All right. Did you—did you make some written report to the board or to—to the company saying, look, I have just entered into a contract for 100 million pound with. . . . ?"
"No, I did not, no, I did not, and I did not enter into a contract. I had no authority to do that. I really was acting as Ken's spokesman for convenience at the time."
"You would say, would you, that the time when you spoke to Hawkins last, there was no concluded agreement between Elders IXL and Equiticorp?"
"I would say there was."
"There was a concluded agreement?"
"Yes, well, I would have thought Jarrett had gave me conditions that would enter into that contract for and asked me to---"
"So you would say a deal was done?"
"Yes, I would."
"You on behalf of Elders, and Hawkins either for himself or on behalf of Equiticorp? And the amount had been fixed?"
"Yes."
"And the rate had been fixed?"
"Yes."
"And the term had been fixed?"
"Yes."

I would now like to move on to an evidentiary statement given by Jane Yuile, who was in the employ of Price Waterhouse and was the manager responsible for the audit of Elders IXL in 1988. Her evidence reads:

PARA.TAB: "I do recall the particular foreign exchange transaction referred to in this document, which resulted in a $39 million loss to Elders."
"In relation to this particular foreign exchange transaction involving the 39 million dollar loss to Elders IXL, I recall speaking to Mr Biggins about it. . . "

"The gist of the response from Mr Biggins was that the transaction was authorised and that the purpose of the transaction was to hedge foreign currency exposure in the investment in the UK assets, primarily being the Courage Brewery."

"If an agreement was being entered into by a company and a bank or, a deal was being entered into, normal practice is that the bank would send a copy of the confirmation notice to the company at the time that the deal was entered into, evidencing the transaction. They often send confirmation by Telex. There was evidence on other files of this method of operation being utilised but I understand that no such documentation was available on the files for this particular transaction, nor was any ever produced to me. The lack of documentation in regards to this transaction was certainly unusual, as normally transaction slips exist, being documents that evidence such deals."

"Now Produced and shown to me are exhibits MX37698/010 to MX37698/020, being minutes of a meeting held on 20 September 1988, in the boardroom of Elders IXL at Number One Garden Street, South yarra between members of Elders IXL and Price Waterhouse, to discuss the audit conducted on that company for the financial year ended 30 June 1988."

"The following paragraph on folio 012 of exhibit MX37698 has been brought to my attention and states `Exchange Fluctuation Reserve—It was noted that the exchange fluctuation reserve was now $150 million debit and that components would need to be monitored to enable appropriate elimination on when investments are sold."

"A component of the increase was a $39 million loss on a contract taken out to hedge the investment in Courage. JDE confirmed that the hedge was valid and had been taken out under his authorisation, it was acknowledged that the paperwork was weak."

"The initials JDE contained in this paragraph refer to John Dorman ELLIOTT and the confirmation he gave in respect of this particular transaction, namely $39 million loss, would have been in response to questions raised mostly likely by Mr DIXON or possibly myself. At no time during this meeting did any member of Elders IXL present indicate or state that this transaction was in fact conducted with Mr Alan HAWKINS in New Zealand or any companies associated with Mr HAWKINS. From discussions undertaken at this meeting and my conversations with Mr BIGGINS, I was under the belief that this transaction was to hedge the Courage assets in the United Kingdom."

SPEECH.PARA: I finish those documents there.

It is clear from the evidence given under oath by the accountants and auditors of Price Waterhouse, who were doing IXL, that there was quite a bit of knowledge of this transaction. In fact, it was even acknowledged that the paperwork was weak. Yet the 15-page statement issued by Messrs Scanlon, Elliott and co, at 12 noon on 22 August 1996, states:
Jarrett implemented a contrived FX transaction to discharge a legal obligation of Elders to ensure that a bad debt to Elders Finance was repaid.

That is not what they said to their auditors. They never mentioned it to their auditors. They go on later to say that they knew nothing about the transaction, absolutely nothing. Page 13 of the Scanlon press release states:

None of Messrs Elliott, Scanlon and Biggins were privy to what had been planned. The Plan was devised and implemented by Elders Finance and its Chief Executive Officer Jarrett to the exclusion of Messrs Elliott, Scanlon and Biggins.

There are many questions that arise from this testimony given under oath to the NCA and how it matches up to the public position that these individuals have taken since the trial. As Henry Bosch has annunciated earlier this week, this is a matter which did not go before a jury. Justice Vincent described it as a mountain of evidence that he was ruling inadmissible and illegally obtained. How Mr Elliott and Mr Scanlon account for their statements to the NCA on oath and their public position is now a matter for some public debate. I look forward to hearing the explanations, if there are any, from those individuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, it is good to see you in the chair.
—Thank you.

—I wanted to first of all comment on Senator Boswell's speech. Obviously, the Democrats agree with the content of that speech. We certainly support his contention that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) needs to be seriously analysed by the Australian public. However, I must ask the question and put it on the record: if Pauline Hanson is such a danger to the Australian community, then I challenge both the Liberal Party and the National Party to put on the record, well before the election, what they are going to do about preferences. I believe, in the end, that that action will speak much louder than any words which are expressed in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: In rising today, I want to address another problem. It is a problem that has taken my interest and time over many years and has used up many hours of my time in pursuit of it. I refer to the whole issue of whistleblowing. On Monday, 26 May, Tuesday, 27 May and Thursday, 29 May 1997 I made a number of speeches supporting the contention that there ought to be whistleblower legislation within the federal parliament. In support of those speeches, as I understood at the time, I tabled some documents on Thursday, 29 May 1997—documents supplied to me by Dr De Maria of the University of Queensland. I was unaware that they contained very adverse comment about certain staff within the University of Queensland. I take responsibility for the fact that I had not checked those documents carefully enough.

The documents spelt out Dr De Maria's side of the argument in what were long‐running disputes between Dr De Maria and a number of staff within the Department of Social Work in the University of Queensland. In fact, I underline that these have been long‐running disputes and that they are between Dr De Maria and I would say most of the staff of that department. I have discovered since that Dr De Maria has no support amongst the staff within the department.

I want to apologise to the Senate and to those involved that I did not check carefully enough the contents of those tabled documents. I want to apologise especially to Professors Ian O'Connor and Linda Rosenman, to the staff, including Peter North, Susan Tasker and Judith Strachan, and to students who have complained about Dr De Maria's attitude and behaviour. I spent many hours talking to University of Queensland staff about their concerns, which I felt was only fair. I am convinced of the integrity of those to whom I spoke, particularly those whom I have already listed.

I think it is fair that I should seek leave to table a number of documents which would put the other side of the argument and answer those adverse comments. So that the Senate is aware, I list these documents as: a letter from Professor O'Connor, in support of the staff of the university; a letter from the academic staff in support of Professors Ian O'Connor and Linda Rosenman and in support of other staff—that letter contains over 20 signatures—and my letter to the University of Queensland explaining how the tabling came about.

This whole incident has caused me quite a deal of distress and a lot of concern. My concern about the situation of whistleblowers in Australia continues. The tragedy is that this dispute clouds the work done by so many sincere whistleblowers. I hope that I will be able to revive my rather dented enthusiasm for pursuing whistleblower legislation in the federal parliament. I seek leave to table the documents.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Constitutional Convention draws closer, more attention has been given to the debate over whether the Commonwealth should become a republic and whether we should have an Australian head of state to replace the Queen of England. This is an issue not only about our national identity but also about our national maturity. This issue is about whether we believe that our nation has come of age and whether we as a nation should take ownership of our political affairs and have an institution for a national head of state which embodies the democratic and egalitarian values of Australia rather than continuing with the British monarchy.

SPEECH.PARA: In a matter of such importance to our nation's future, I believe that the debate on whether or not we should have an Australian head of state should be conducted in a mature and rational manner without deception and scaremongering. Unfortunately, there is growing evidence that those who support the continuation of the British monarch in Australia are not committed to rational debate on the question of whether we should have an Australian head of state. For example, I was appalled by the recent action of the Longford branch of the Tasmanian RSL in putting one of their members on trial for voicing his support for an Australian republic.

I have always thought that the RSL represented the men and women of Australia who fought and died for the preservation of democracy and freedom of speech. Yet last Friday in Tasmania, Mr Mick Walker, a member of the RSL for 51 years—a World War II veteran—was put on trial for his views about supporting the concept of an Australian head of state.

This is the kind of intimidation the Nazis and communists practised. It is certainly the last thing I would have expected from the RSL. In my opinion, the Walker trial dishonoured the thousands of Australian men and women who have given their lives fighting to preserve Australia's tradition of freedom of speech and democracy.

It is surely a very sad matter that an RSL veteran should have been intimidated in this way for expressing support for Australia having an Australian head of state. I thought our service men and women fought and died under the Australian flag for Australia. I can only say that the RSL has lost a lot of credibility because of the shameful trial that Mr Walker was put through.

One of the most misleading statements that has been put about which is of concern to ex‐service people is that the Republican Movement wants to change the Australian flag. There is no truth in this claim at all. Speaking as the co‐patron of the Australian Republican Movement in Western Australia, I would like to reassure the ex‐service men and women of Australia that the ARM has no policy about changing our national flag. I understand that, to ex‐service people, the flag they fought under is sacred and represents our history.

Another matter I wish to address in this vein is the claims by Australians for a Consti tutional Monarchy, or ACM as it is known, that the Republican Movement does not know what it stands for or what it wants. This is simply not true. The position of the ARM is very clear and simple. The ARM supports, firstly, creating an Australian institution reflecting the democratic and egalitarian values of Australian society for a national head of state to replace the British monarchy in Australia. Secondly, the office of the head of state, or president, would be largely ceremonial. Thirdly, the ARM supports the retention of the Westminster system of parliamentary government, with the Prime Minister and cabinet coming from the parliament. Fourthly, the ARM would want Australia to still be called the Commonwealth of Australia. Fifthly, the ARM supports continued membership for a republican Commonwealth of Australia of the British Commonwealth—that is, we would still remain members of the British Commonwealth; Australia would still compete in the Commonwealth Games; and of course, we would still play cricket. Sixthly, and finally, Australia would still give continued recognition to the Queen as head of the British Commonwealth.

The public draft of the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy statement that was published in the Australian on 28 May 1997 and that will be circulated for the Constitutional Convention also contains some grossly misleading statements. Such statements were obviously deliberately included to confuse the Australian people. For example, the ACM statement reads:
A Republic will put at risk what we now enjoy: our political stability, our national flag and our national anthem. In other words, Australia as we know it.

All I can say about that is that it is absolute and utter, irresponsible nonsense. The claim that our political stability will be at risk if the Commonwealth becomes a republic is absolute rubbish when one considers countries such as Germany, India and Ireland. They are all parliamentary republics of the kind that it is proposed by the ARM that Australia should become. All of these countries enjoy political stability, and there is no question that a republican Commonwealth of Australia would not be politically stable.

Australia's political stability does not depend on having the Queen of England as our head of state. Australia is one of the most mature democracies in the world, and our traditional commitment to democracy will continue whether Australia becomes a republic or not. Becoming a republic will only mean that the symbol at the top will change and our basic political system of Westminster style parliamentary government will remain unchanged.

The Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy statement that our national anthem will change is also complete nonsense. The Australian national anthem is Advance Australia Fair and was chosen by the people of Australia back in the 1970s. There will be no change in our national anthem if Australia becomes a republic—unless, of course, the monarchists are referring to the use of God Save the Queen, which demonstrates how out of date they are and illustrates, as nothing else could, that the monarchists are clinging to the past, the last of the British Empire loyalists.

The truth is that if Australia becomes a republic there will really be no change at all to our way of life. For example, nothing in our legal system will materially change, except that it will be the state rather than the Crown that the law is administered in the name of. Nothing in the way we are governed will change. The Westminster system of responsible parliamentary democracy will continue.

The only significant change will be that instead of having the Queen of England we will have a distinguished Australian as our head of state. After all, that is the whole point: we are Australians and we should have an Australian head of state.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you. However much the monarchists might like to pretend otherwise, the truth is that in the wide world out there, the Queen is regarded as the Queen of England, not the Queen of Australia. When the Queen travels to other countries, the headline in the local papers is not `The Queen of Australia visits New York'—or Paris, or Tokyo. Instead, Her Majesty is referred to as the Queen of England visiting New York, Paris or Tokyo.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely Australia has reached a point in our national maturity where it is important for us to have a recognisably Australian head of state. This is the view of Richard Woolcott who was the former head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and formerly Australian Ambassador to the United Nations. He wrote last year about the confusion caused by having the Queen of England as our head of state. Mr Woolcott's experience was that many countries around the world questioned whether Australia is really an independent country and whether we really control our own foreign policy when we have the Queen of England, clearly the head of another country, as our head of state.

Woolcott also made the point that when the royal family travel overseas the British government uses them to promote British commercial and trade interests. This means that there have been times when our head of state, the Queen, and members of the royal family have been working against Australian trade interests. With regard to that, I would like to quote the former deputy chairman of the British Conservative Party, Lord McAlpine, who, in an article in a recent edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, wrote:

The monarchy is thoroughly good for Britain and should continue. However, it does nothing for the Australians. Take the simple proposition of a State visit to Japan. The Queen goes there to sell Britain, and often her visit will be timed to coincide with British trade missions . . . She does not promote Australian trade interests in Japan or anywhere else. The monarchy is a thing of the past in Australia; Australia will never truly be a nation while the monarchy lasts there.

As I said in the beginning, I hope the republic debate will be conducted in a mature and sensible manner. Debate should be conducted in an open forum style with respect for the opponent's point of view, and there should be respect for freedom of speech and, in the end, respect for majority rule. The forthcoming Constitutional Convention should be seen as an opportunity for the views of all Australians to be represented and I trust that the consensus that will emerge from the Constitutional Convention will be respected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to speak about something that deeply concerns me, and that is the large number of people who are disabled by acquired brain injury both in my home state of Queensland and around Australia. It is not just the large number of people who are afflicted by this condition which concerns me; it is especially concerning because these people receive very little access to services and support and no government department wants to own them.

SPEECH.PARA: For those not familiar with people who have ABI, it may be important to briefly discuss the unique nature of this type of disability. Many people who acquire a brain injury do so in road accidents and on rural properties. These include horse, motorcycle and machinery accidents. The worst aspect of this is that the support services are virtually non‐existent in rural areas. Another aspect of ABI is that there are many young sufferers. Of all people with a disability arising from ABI, the proportion in the 15‐ to 24‐year‐old age group is higher than in any other age group below 75.
In a recent letter to me the Executive Director of Headway Queensland stated:

Before this year is over, we can expect to see an additional four thousand (4,000) names added to the list of Queenslanders disabled by acquired brain injury. Unfortunately, services available to support them are virtually non‐existent. Not only are there no services for people with acquired brain injury, it is impossible to find a Government Department to acknowledge responsibility.

The situation is little better for the rest of Australia, bar one or two state governments that have started to tackle the problem. The CEO of the Head Injury Council of Australia said that, on very conservative estimates, 254,500 people in Australia are seriously affected by ABI or strokes and suffer long‐term problems. If we add to this figure the less serious cases, the total is 500,000. Remember that these are conservative figures only, and the Head Injury Council of Australia has good reasons to believe that the numbers are in fact much higher. Why then does no‐one want to take responsibility for this very large group of people? Why are young people being placed in aged care hostels when that both is inappropriate and does not allow for the appropriate support services? And why is there a dearth of support services for people with ABI?

I refer to the report of the strategic review of the Commonwealth disability services program called Working solutions, written by Kathleen Kay and Professor Peter Baume. This report illustrates quite clearly the very small impact that the disability services program is having on people with ABI.

Of the various employment services funded by the DSP, people with ABI were able to access only two per cent. This small, two per cent figure translates to 582 people who were assisted. Out of a quarter of a million people with serious cases of ABI, that is just 0.2 per cent of their number. I have to say that that is an abysmally low level of support for a group of people who are one of the biggest, if not the biggest, in number when compared with other groups with disabilities.

To put it into context, there are 3.2 million people—18 per cent of the Australian population—who have a disability. Eight per cent of this number experience disability caused by brain injury. Unfortunately, when compared to assistance to all states, my home state of Queensland has access to fewer services than the general state population would warrant. At the same time, Queensland has a higher percentage of people with ABI than other states. Queensland, therefore, is losing out both ways, in an area which is already neglected.

I have outlined some of the figures that relate to a definite lack of access to employment services for people with ABI. However, another very important aspect is the need for support services immediately after the incident where people first suffer the brain injury, as well as the counselling and support services for the family. People suffering from ABI are often not aware of the problems they are suffering. This is something unique to this type of injury, because these people were functioning quite well before their accident. Subsequently, with only a part of their brain injured, they often cannot see that they are acting differently or are not able to do things as they did before. In some cases, the families, unfortunately, cannot recognise the problems either. The problems often manifest themselves through frustration, anger and aggressive behaviour by the victim, and this can do a great deal of damage within a family.

BREAK.PARA: If I use my state of Queensland as an example, there is just one hospital that has a specialised unit for people with ABI. I am informed that it does excellent work. Unfortunately, though, it can cater for just 140 cases per year, when there are 2,500 cases per year that need the service it provides. Therefore, more than 2,300 cases per year, out of the 2,500, receive no diagnosis of any psychiatric disorders that may require treatment. As I pointed out before, many of the sufferers are not aware that they have any problems. Subsequently, there is no education or counselling for the families either. This is a very serious problem and needs to be changed as soon as possible.

In addition to these problems, the government is now reviewing the need to fund advocacy services. The Head Injury Council of Australia can employ only two people with the federal funding they receive. This takes 90 per cent of their income. It is essential their funding is renewed after 30 June this year. Otherwise, who is going to fight for the recognition of the services for people with ABI? Remember: people with ABI make up just two per cent of those assisted with the disability services program employment schemes. Without an advocacy service to assist these people and fight for them, what percentage will be able to access services in the future?

Finally, I want to point out the inappropriate actions that occur when a group of people is not formally recognised by a responsible government department and where necessary services are not available. In New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia and the ACT, young people with ABI are inappropriately accommodated in acute hospital beds, aged care nursing homes, aged hostels or the mental health system.

It is totally inappropriate for young people to be accommodated in aged care accommodation around the country. One can only guess how many are in hospitals or in the mental health system. It raises many concerns because the potential of these young people is never reached due to the fact that support services are not available. People with a disability such as blindness, deafness, cerebral palsy, and other groups who have been recognised for decades or centuries, have a much higher level of direct funding. I certainly do not want to take anything away from these sectors. However, those with ABI are always last in the queue and are therefore restricted in access by budgetary limitations. It is time that the government started to implement the recommendations of the Baume report that will make access more equitable for all of those with disabilities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, will be absent from question time today. Senator Kemp is in Melbourne attending a funeral. During his absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolios of Treasury and Finance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, is it true that under the youth allowance, which Senator Newman announced yesterday—an announcement which you wisely boycotted—16‐ and 17-year-olds will no longer be eligible for any income support while looking for jobs? What choices are you giving 16‐ and 17-year-olds who have not completed year 12 and who, for whatever reasons, are not in, or cannot remain in, full-time education or training? Isn't it true that their families will now have to meet the full cost of their job seeking activity while they look for non-existent jobs? Aren't you saying to the parents who are struggling to support these young adults, `They're yours; you look after them. Don't look to us for any help'? Are you now going to discuss with the states raising the compulsory school leaving age to 18?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for the question because he highlights one of the key aspects of the youth allowance. In fact, incentives finally have been rejigged, after many years—
—Ha, ha!

—The senator over there laughs and scoffs. So incentives are there for young Australians either to complete their year 12 training or, if they leave earlier than that, to take up some other form of education and training on a full-time basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, if you look at the make‐up of unemployed youth, you will see that the quickest way to ensure that someone is unemployed and looking for work in the short term, and remains unemployed for a long period of time and faces a very bleak future, is to say to them, `Why don't you leave school at the minimum age? The government does not express any view about whether you do more training. We do not have extra incentives—in fact, the incentives are there for you to just look for work and we will pay you the unemployment benefit.' If that is the situation you want to retain, then you live with it.

We are changing the incentives. The people on this side want there to be an incentive for education and training. There will be that incentive. Students around Australia for years have been asking for the rent allowance to be paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will make them starve.
—Answer the question.
—Order! The level of noise on my left is too high.

—It does not surprise me that the little angels on the other side are upset, because finally something that should have been done a long, long time ago has been done. Finally the incentives are skewed towards education and training. They are no longer skewed towards leaving school at the earliest possible age and not going into further education and training. Finally someone has had the stomach to make that change.

BREAK.PARA: It is obviously true that, when you rejig incentives, there are winners and losers. It is quite clear that students around Australia are the winners under this proposal. The benefit is that, over the long term, there is an incentive for young Australians either to stay at school and complete their year 12, which increases their opportunities for getting a job, or to leave school early because school is not appropriate for them to continue with. We could have another debate about that—schools focusing themselves on the 25 per cent who want to go to university and not paying enough attention to those who want to go into vocational education and training. We have some reforms that are affecting the schools in that respect.

There has to be an incentive. It is about time somebody said to young Australians, `This is a bad thing for your to do. It is a bad thing for you and for your future to leave school at the earliest possible age and not do further training.' You were happy to let them do that and leave them with a very bleak future.

Senator Cook, you would understand that, with the changing industries, the availability of jobs to low and unskilled workers is diminishing. The sorts of jobs that kids who leave school early can get are in shorter and shorter supply as the economy internationally changes into higher-tech and service industries. Senator Cook knows that. I have heard him talking about it on many occasions when he was on this side of the chamber. You guys were too gutless to rejig the incentives in favour of young Australians, to give them an incentive to do more education and training. Now you have the cheek to come in here and complain about what we are doing. You must be crazy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you guarantee here and now that your government will provide sufficient education and training places for all those 16‐ and 17-year-olds who need them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will guarantee you this: we will do a much better job than you ever did. The previous—
—Madam President, I have a point of order.
—Order! A point of order.
—Sorry. You cannot accept the point of order; I have said only one phrase.

—Madam President, my point of order is this: I asked Senator Vanstone a direct question whether she would guarantee that the government would provide sufficient education and training places for all 16‐ or 17-year-olds who need them. In her answer she indicated that she wanted to provide some other form of guarantee, which is clearly out of order. I ask you to direct her to answer the question.

—Order! Senator Faulkner, I think you are using a point of order to make another speech on the matter. The minister has so far had just under six seconds to answer your question. I am sure she is aware of the supplementary question you have asked and I am sure she will deal with it.

—Senator, I would have thought you would have been embarrassed to ask that question. After 13 years of Labor you want to seek to imply that there are not enough training places; that you left government with not enough places there. This much I will guarantee you—

—This much I will guarantee you—

—If a kid cannot get a place because there are not enough places because you let the training system run down, we will give them the youth allowance. There you are.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Malaysia, led by the President of the Senate, the Hon. Senator Tan Sri Mohamed. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, in 1995, with Senator Ian Campbell and other coalition members, I participated in a series of youth forums in New South Wales and Queensland. The No. 1 concern of many young people was the fact that they could get more money in their pockets being on the dole than they could get from Austudy. They asked why they should study if they were paid more not to work. Minister, how does the government's new youth allowance address this disincentive to study and what other benefits will the youth allowance have for young Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that we have an intelligent question about a most important social policy reform, probably one of the most important reforms in social policy areas in decades—and badly needed, as Senator Payne has pointed out. This government's highest priority is to provide young people with jobs. The youth allowance is designed to achieve just that by encouraging young people to go for more education and training so that they are less likely to end up on the dole. The fact is that the early school leavers are three times more likely to end up unemployed than are those who leave at year 12.

ANSWER.PARA: The trouble is that the previous government seemed to focus on academic achievements for the handful who will go on to universities. I would have thought that the party that was founded on the blue‐collar men and women of Australia would have understood the need for vocational training for young people. It has been totally neglected over these years of Labor government.

We are determined to give incentives and send messages to young people and their families about getting the right skills and getting the education they need. We do not want them down the blind alleys where they have been over the last 13 years. In 1994‐95, Labor's last year in office, youth unemployment was a staggering 32.3 per cent and yet it was 27 per cent when they took over. Hawke, Keating and Beazley presided over the virtual demise of Australia's—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Beazley, Senator.

—I am sorry—Mr Beazley. Mr Beazley presided over the virtual demise of Australia's apprenticeship and traineeship system. In 1995 apprenticeships and traineeships fell to their lowest levels as a percentage of the work force in three decades. But Labor was prepared to churn them over and then dump them on the scrap heap. Ineffectual, confusing systems.

ANSWER.PARA: What we are doing—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing?

—What are we doing? I will tell you what we are doing. We are making it clear that those young people under the age of 18 should focus—and so should their families—on the value that they will get from training and education. Academic education, yes; vocational training, yes. It will lead to jobs and greater opportunities for them to be in the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: What are we doing for the 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds? We are treating students and unemployed people on a fair and consistent basis. Payments to students will now be brought up to the level of unemployment payments and students will be eligible for rent assistance. This is long overdue, as Senator Payne mentioned, and desperately needed by all young people, but it is particularly valuable for those who live in country areas, who come from the bush. It will be up to a hundred dollars a fortnight more in the pockets of a family with a young person who is going on to education. I would have thought that was a message that the Labor Party would not want to hear. Clearly that is why they are trying to make such a din now.

BREAK.PARA: What are we doing for the kids in the bush? We are giving them the opportunity to get away for study or job search and to get assistance in terms of not only income support but also rent assistance. We are treating them in a fair and equitable manner.

I notice today that Mr Beazley was talking about, `Hands up if you think $41,000 makes you feel well off.' I would say `hands up' to the Labor Party who thought that $37,000 made you feel well off enough to pay for your kids on Austudy. We are raising the ceiling for children. For young people, whether they are students or they are unemployed, the ceiling for parental income will be raised to $41,000 if there is one child. It will be higher for those with more children in the family. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, the Labor government swept Australia's young people into the highest level of unemployment since the Depression. In July 1992, youth unemployment reached 34.9 per cent when the now Leader of the Opposition was employment minister. These young people were largely condemned by Labor to a bleak future.
