ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon for the question. In short form, as has already been indicated in a couple of earlier answers, this government has been prepared to rejig the incentives so that finally there is an incentive for young Australians leaving school to go into further education and train ing. There is no longer an incentive, the government will no longer pay people, to leave school in the hope of getting a job.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that our Malaysian friends who are here today, who of all the South-East Asian nations understand very well the value of training and education and have put so much effort into encouraging young Malaysians in their education and training, would understand why this government has changed the incentives in this way. Senator Synon refers to what Labor did for young people in Australia, and I think that is worth dwelling on just momentarily. I generally do not like to look back but, just so people are kept in the picture, it is important we look at some of these things.

Labor halved the number of young people employed during `the recession we had to have'. That is right. During the recession we had to have, Labor halved the number of young people who were employed. Full-time youth employment fell from approximately a quarter of a million, some 465,000, in 1989 to 227,000 in 1994. The youth full-time unemployment rate peaked at 34.9 per cent in July 1992. It was 34.9 per cent when they had been in government for nine years. They were in government for nine years and they had a youth unemployment rate of 34.9 per cent. We have been in government about 15 months and they think we should have been able to fix up the mess they created in 13 years.

They had the highest youth unemployment rate since the Depression. For the last five years of the Fraser government, youth unemployment was over 20 per cent for eight out of 60 months. For the last five years of the Keating government—and those of you who were members of it should listen to this—youth unemployment was more than 20 per cent for how many out of 60 months? For 60 out of 60 months—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order on a question of relevance. Wouldn't it be more relevant for Senator Vanstone to be telling us that youth unemployment has increased under her stewardship as she has cut back on 40,000 traineeships? That would be a more relevant answer, wouldn't it, Madam President?
—There is no point of order. The minister is answering Senator Synon's answer.

—Isn't that disgraceful! In the last five years of the Fraser government, youth unemployment was over 20 per cent for just eight out of 60 months. For the last five years of your stewardship, it was over 20 per cent for 60 out of 60 months. You should be ashamed of yourselves!
—Isn't is true that it has increased under your stewardship? It has gone up under you, hasn't it? You have cut back on training. What a dishonest answer!
—Senator Bolkus! Cease interjecting.

—This government has a very comprehensive strategy for increasing youth employment. We are reducing the huge deficit left by Labor; we are promoting growth in the small business sector—the source of more jobs; we are increasing labour market flexibility; we are reforming labour market assistance and training; and, finally, we are putting incentives there for young Australians to go into education and training and removing that incentive to go on the dole and hope to get a job. You and I know death to the bright future of a young Australian is to leave school at an early age and not go into further education and training. That is a disaster for young Australians. This government has been prepared to say that it is not going to happen.

ANSWER.PARA: There are significant incentives for students in relation to the youth allowance. Senator Synon, if I do not get time you might ask me a supplementary question so that I can get to them. We are removing the financial incentives that have seen young people choose to receive unemployment benefits rather than undertaken education and training. What an indictment on a nation.

Under the existing Austudy rules, students do not have access to rent assistance unless they qualify for the homeless rate—and students have been complaining about this for years. You would think the President of the National Union of Students, John Carey, would be supportive of this change. All he says is, `We have no plan for the unemployed.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you further expand on the future opportunities for young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that very good question. What we are doing for the young unemployed is putting incentives, amongst other things, there for them to go into education and training. About 70,000 students will be eligible to receive rent assistance. Students will be able to earn $6,000 gross per annum, $230 a fortnight, whereas people on unemployment benefits will be able to earn only $1,560. So the incentives are very much there for young Australians to finally go into education and training.

ANSWER.PARA: The work force requirement will be halved as students who have been in full-time employment for 18 months over a two-year period or who work 20 hours per week over the two years since leaving school will now be entitled to the independent rate free of parental means testing. This will affect something like 16,600 students. Students who have been in a de facto relationship for two years will be entitled to apply for the independent rate. I could go on. The change is beneficial for students and good for young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that you cannot go on, Senator, as your time has expired.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, isn't it true that the harsh changes your government has made to the Austudy independence age for 1997 were not supposed to affect continuing students? Can you explain why students who were engaged in work experience in 1996 as a compulsory part of their course are now being denied Austudy? Did you intend all along to exclude such students or is this yet another example of an Austudy bungle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Hold the presses! You are really on to something here. It is true that if people were not in full-time study it created a difficulty for them. I have fixed that difficulty. The situation for students not in full-time study as a consequence of their course, not for some other half‐baked reason—architecture students, for example, might be an indication of that—has been drawn to my attention and I have fixed it. So you are about a week too late.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you are indicating in your response that you considered changes to Austudy to take into account these circumstances and that you have fixed it. Can you provide details of how you have fixed it and when those regulation amendments were made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I signed a brief in my office some time ago. I cannot give you the exact date. It was not that long ago. That brief will be implemented. I cannot recall at this moment whether it actually requires a regulatory change. If it does, the regulation will be put before this place and I will look forward to you supporting it. Perhaps you will even run around and say it was your idea.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. I refer to the government's plans to deny around 46,000 young Australians income support under the new proposed youth allowance. Can you confirm that a family on an income of $42,000 a year with a 20-year-old job seeker living at home will suffer an income loss of $190 per fortnight—a drop of 10 per cent—when the young family member loses their unemployment benefits? If that is the case, your government is joking when it refers to cutting the youth dole as a `pro-family' measure. Minister, isn't it true, as the Brisbane director of Lifeline said today—and I think I would believe him—that the youth allowance dole cuts will create financial stress on families and lead to family breakdown as young adults are forced to become financially dependent on their parents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I would think from the public utterances of the Australian Demo crats that they are prepared to have young people stay on unemployed benefits for years and years. They do not want to do anything that will encourage them to have greater life opportunities. That is a terrible shame. Some of the Democrat senators have been hitting the airwaves today talking about suicide in relation to youth allowance. I cannot think of anything more despicable than to be doing that. We have some unacceptable levels of youth suicide over the last few years.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise in the chamber is far too high. Senator Bolkus, you have been persistently interjecting today.

—We have had unacceptable levels of youth suicide for a number of years, and I deplore that. This government is doing its utmost to stop that cycle of despair which young people get into through lack of hope—which comes from lack of training and lack of job opportunity. It is incredible that the Democrats would play that sort of game with something which is a social policy reform. I would have thought they would have been interested in what the Brotherhood of St Laurence had to say about this. Go home and do your homework! And Cheryl Kernot went on the airwaves this morning, using examples that were absolutely factually wrong. Get your facts right if you are going to do this. Do some study. This is a major social policy reform which is going to benefit young people. It will be of massive importance to them.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me get some things on the record that I would like to make everybody understand. Those who were on newstart or sickness benefits yesterday will not have their payment affected. Our means test, as I said earlier, is more generous than Labor's. It is $41,000—compared to $37,000—for a family with one child at home and it will go up by several thousand per child. If the child is living away from home, it goes from $58,000 up. Are you saying that families who are on relatively comfortable incomes should not be supporting their unemployed children, when they are required to support their student children? Get real! That is a nonsense.

BREAK.PARA: If young people cannot find a place in training or education, as Senator Vanstone said, they will still be eligible for a youth allowance. Rural and regional Australians will benefit by up to $100 a fortnight, mostly from the extension of rent assistance to young people who are studying or in training. The vast majority of young people—378,000 of them—will be unaffected by the youth allowance. They will stay the same. Another 137,000 will be better off and 33,600 will receive a reduced payment consistent with a needs based social security system. They had no problem making reduced payments for students' families. Reduced payments for students' families were okay; reduced payments for unemployed young people's families are, apparently, something different again. Families—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator—
—I am waiting for my time.
—Senators on my left, cease interjecting.

—Families with students to keep are likely to have to keep them for up to five years. Social security statistics show that 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds are on newstart for an average of five months. Even if you double that, it is a darned sight longer to support a student than it is to support a young unemployed person. It is reasonable to expect families who are on reasonably comfortable incomes to support their unemployed young as well as their student young. That is fair. It is treating young people in an equitable way across the board.

BREAK.PARA: It is restoring the incentive. Many families have written to me over the years about their young people dropping out of education because the dollars that Labor offered were greater for the unemployed than they were for students. We are rectifying that. We are fixing that. It is incredible that you did not do it after 13 years. You had the opportunity and you stuffed up. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the Democrats do not want young people to stay on the dole; they would like them to have jobs, which you are not providing. These youth allowance dole cuts have the stamp of the Lyons Forum all over them. Minister, you have said that around 33,000 young people not in full‐time education or training will lose all or part of their allowance. Can you tell the Senate where the extra 33,000 education or training places for those young people are?

—I rise on a point of order. It is important to point out that I am not a member of the Lyons Forum. I never have been, I never will be and I support shifting the incentives in favour of education and training.
—Senator Vanstone, that is not a point of order. That is a matter you can debate later.
—On a point of order, Madam President: I am a member of the Lyons Forum, and it has not even had a meeting this year.
—Senator Herron, you are wasting question time.
—On the point of order, Madam President—
—There is no point of order, and I have ruled both of them out as wasting question time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —What Dr Kemp is doing in an integrated way with this reform is to provide more places for young people, more vocational education money and more TAFE places, with the cooperation of the states. There is a massive program being negotiated with the states right now of billions of dollars over the next five years to achieve 100,000 places per year over the next five years in TAFE. In addition, there are 100,000 extra places being provided under the vocational programs that Dr Kemp has in his budget for this financial year. So this government is taking an integrated approach to getting the skills needed for young people to get jobs and the income support to help them and their families achieve just that. After all the years that we had the Labor Party governing this country, they never gave that emphasis to supporting an integrated approach to skills and, therefore, jobs for the young. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, why has the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee written expressing concern at the information being requested by you for this year's profile negotiations, and why are some of the vice chancellors taking the unprecedented step of threatening not to cooperate with this profile process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much for that question. If you are referring to the correspondence I think you are—there is a volume of correspondence vis a vis universities—there was some concern earlier in the year at the profiles process, because, in its concern for quality in universities, this government decided to ensure that quality became a part of a university strategy. They could not just plop a program here and take a bit of money from the government there and say, `We have a quality program.' We wanted it to be a part of the profiles process, some sort of means of having it—what can I say—permanently locked into the university structure.

ANSWER.PARA: The Higher Education Council has had this reference. They have been looking at the question of quality and they were going to participate in the profiles process. Some universities believed that the profiles process, inquiring as to their quality mechanisms, would be intrusive because they might have commercial-in-confidence matters that they did not want to disclose. I find that somewhat difficult to accept, but there could be some circumstances where that might happen. I have yet to have one specifically pointed to me.

A university did raise this with me, in addition to some correspondence, basically arguing that if they found the way to be excellent teachers, they do not necessarily want to share that in a particular faculty or share that with every other university. They do not want to let the other universities know what they are doing that is making them a better quality university than others. That was the concern. You are frowning at me, Senator Neal. Do you not understand or do you have a headache?

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think it is what they meant at all. You completely misunderstand.
—You should not ask questions that other people give you if you do not understand them. Give them back and get someone else to ask them.
—Senator Vanstone, you should be directing your remarks through the Chair.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: VANSTONE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Madam President. There have been negotiations between parties on these matters. As I was last informed, the profiles process will continue and continue well. Let me add that students around Australia might like to consider the following. It is true that students around Australia have not warmly welcomed having a HECS increase. I understand that. I never expected that students around Australia would line up at the bank and say, `Get out of the way; I want to pay my HECS more quickly. I'm just looking forward to paying more.' I never expected that that would happen. We will have a difference of opinion with students over that. We will argue that it is fair that students pay more. After all, they get so much more than the other kids who do not go to university.

INTERJECT.PARA: But—and this is a big but—students should understand that we put something like $5 billion a year into universities. I am pre-determined to ensure that students get value for their money, that they get quality teaching and that that teaching improves and improves, because we do not pay the $5 billion for nothing. There is no point in saying that we can have universities without students; it is like hospitals without patients.

Students are the most important people in the higher education sector and we are determined to ensure that they are delivered a quality education. We will go quietly working about it through the profiles process and a few other mechanisms that I have in mind to ensure that universities actually pass on the benefits of government policies to students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I must confess that I was frowning because I was startled by the minister responsible for universities, who seriously thought that concerns about commercial-in-confidence were related to teaching methods rather than technology and knowledge, which is very saleable in today's community. How do you reconcile your government's policies when the vice-chancellors describe your activities as `intrusiveness' when you said during the election, `Too much bureaucratic interference and government red tape are stifling universities'? Isn't that exactly what you are doing in the vice-chancellors' opinion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated, as I understand it, negotiations have been settled on this matter and there is an easy path ahead now for the profiles process. As for intrusiveness, I use that term insofar as it does not apply to just teaching as a method; it applies to the method by which you teach, which would include technology. I understand that.

ANSWER.PARA: But, Senator, we never said to you that we want universities to have more freedom. You should understand that. We do not want to control everything that universities do, as you did. But if there is one thing that we will try to ensure that universities deliver, it is quality. We will not have universities saying, `Well, we don't want you to be intrusive; give us $5 billion and have no thought about the quality that is delivered to students.' Universities are very important, but students are more important than the administrators and we will ensure that they get quality. If the universities think that is intrusive, bad luck.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the minister agree that the rearranged youth allowance will, in fact, impose increased financial burdens on families with sons and daughters who, as a result, will no longer be eligible for government support? Will that fact be acknowledged by the government in amendments to the income tax assessment legislation or will the income outlaid by families to meet the additional costs also be the subject of income tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that technically is correct, to the extent that there certainly will be some circumstances where government paid income would have been coming into a family, if you put it in those terms, where it will not be now, because the children are no longer eligible for benefits. That is set to criteria, depending on the income of the family.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with you in general. I ask you to take into account the fact that families have already received benefits through the family tax initiative that this government implemented upon coming to government. Whilst in some ways you may say that we are imposing an extra pressure on some families, we are also doing it to a background that we recognise it is not easy to bring up children. It is expensive. That is something that families accept when they have children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that right?

—Yes, it is part of the family responsibility to support your children. We do not shy away from that. We are quite happy to say it. I will say it again if you like. I guess the answer is that in some families there would be some extra pressure, but I believe we have adequately taken that into account when we have struck our cut-off levels.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I go to the last point and ask: is it a fact that the income which will be outlaid by families to meet the additional costs of this government's decision also be the subject of the taxation by this government or will you please consider amending the income tax legislation so it too can acknowledge the facts as a result of your decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point is that this is not a reform that is designed to benefit the government from a revenue perspective. Although we talk about it in terms of it being revenue neutral, in fact there is greater cost to revenue, as I understand it, from the additional administrative burdens that will be imposed. So when you talk about it being at a cost to some families, I ask you to take into account that there will also be significant financial benefit to some families arising out of this package, particularly to those who are in education, as has been well expressed by Senator Vanstone and Senator Newman today.

ANSWER.PARA: I hear your question whether there should be some extra deduction for the extra income which some families will have to apply towards their children. I do not know that the government has any plan to change the taxation system in that regard, but I will refer it back to the Treasurer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, is it not a fact that the percentage of questions on notice answered by you since the commencement of the parliament stands at a mere 61.4 per cent? Are you aware that this outcome rates as the second worst performance by any minister in your government and is beaten only by the lacklustre performance of your junior minister who has answered only 50 per cent? Is it also a fact that it has taken, on average, 85.5 days to answer questions asked of you? Are you aware that this outcome also rates as the second worst performance by any minister in the government? Minister, why do you constantly defy the provisions of continuing order of the Senate No. 16 which requires you to answer a question within 30 days? Or is it simply the case that, like the unemployed, we just have to be patient?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ray for that question. No, Senator Ray, I was not aware of that fact. I give you an absolute undertaking that I will make appropriate changes as are required to get you answers more quickly because I think you are entitled to them more quickly. It is not satisfactory and I will make sure that it is improved. If you like, we can have a continuous performance index and come back here each month and tick it off.

ANSWER.PARA: What I would like to have, though, is an index on the quality of the questions asked which merit some attention. Senator Ray raises a very good point. Questions should be answered quickly. If my department is not giving me the answers quickly enough and, therefore, you are not getting them quickly enough, I will attend to it and make sure that within a couple of months that matter is very rapidly fixed.

I come to the question about the unemployed being told to be patient, Senator Ray, because inadvertently you have given me the opportunity to put that in the proper context in which it belongs. I did do an interview in relation to the unemployment figures last Thursday and I did quite rightly say that there are no Nescafe fixes for this problem, the problem that has been amply canvassed today with the unemployment levels created and left by the previous government. It would be nice to pretend that there was a magic wand, that we could go out and fix this—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left should cease interjecting.
—If they get more than 40 grand, they only get 40 beans in each cup.
—Senator Collins!
—It would be nice to have a magic wand and be able to fix things. If a magic wand was available—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You asked them to be quiet, Madam President.

—If a magic wand was available in the 13 years that you people were in government, you would have fixed it. So you know that a magic wand is not, in fact, available. I did point out that the government would, of course, like the changes that it has made to be washing through the economy more quickly than they are. Everybody would like that. He would like that and I think members opposite would actually like that too. As much as they would like this government to be in trouble, they would like employment figures to improve—most of them would, at least.

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the interview I was asked, `Do we have to be patient then?' to which I responded, `Regrettably, patience is a virtue.' Senator Ray, you might think it is appropriate reporting to take that out of context and say, `Vanstone says that the unemployed should be patient,' as though it were a Marie Antoinette `Let them eat cake' remark, but presumably, since you have been in here longer than I, you would understand that that is not the tone in which I would make that remark and that was not the remark in itself. It was, `Yes, regrettably, patience is a virtue.' Regrettably it is. How regrettable it is that you left us with a shocking mess to clean up and how regrettable it is that we do all have to be patient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her commitment to go away and look at this particular problem. Will you also draw the problem to the attention of your junior minister who has problems here?
—Yes.

—Also, there are usually two reasons for the delay in answering questions—slowness and tardiness on behalf of departments. Could you check whether that is a reason? Sometimes, regrettably, it is a slowness—I do not know whether that is so in this case—in being cleared through ministers' offices which delays them being put down. Maybe you could respond to that on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Ray. I will of course take those remarks back to Minister Kemp as well. I will undertake to ensure that there is no tardiness either in my office or in the department.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister advise the Senate of the reaction of Australian National workers to the proposed sale of the Australian National rail network? What will be the impact on staff if the sale of the Australian National is blocked?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly assure the Senate that the sale of AN is very much supported by the workers and by many other groups who have a very keen interest in the outcome. AN workers have been calling for the sale of AN to go ahead for quite some time. They understand that the future for all AN workers depends on the sale of AN and on the injection of private sector enterprise and investment.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, in Tasmania there is also an acute awareness of how crucial the sale is to Tasmania's rail industry and freight transport generally. The sale there is supported by the Tasmanian government, the unions and even the Tasmanian Labor Party. It is certainly supported by AN workers in Tasrail, who realise that if the sale does not go ahead then there will not be a railway left to sell. Tasrail's major customers, like Goliath cement, are also very supportive.

In South Australia, Rail 2000, the TLC of Port Augusta, the corporation of the city of Port Augusta, the Spencer Region Development Association, the Northern Regional Development Board, the SA Farmers Federation, the Australian Barley Board, the Australian Wheat Board and AN itself all very much support it. Indeed, the State Secretary of the Public Transport Union, Rex Phillips, warned recently that any delay to the sale would cause `unneeded heartache and grief for workers'.

Against that background, one ought to ask oneself, `What is the attitude of the Labor Party?'—apart from talking amongst themselves and pretending that this is not an issue that they have to face. The fact is that they do have to face it. What they are doing now is putting themselves on the record as being opposed to something that is in the interest of not only the workers but the people of Port Augusta.

What was the response of the Leader of the Opposition? He sent Mr Tanner, the opposition spokesman, to Port Augusta the other day to try to defend the indefensible. What happened there as a result of that was an interview on Radio 5CK yesterday with an AWU representative. He made clear that this was absolutely devastating as far as they were concerned. He said, `I must say, as much as it hurts me, that after Lindsay's visit we are even worse than we were before.' He was asked, `Did you get any guarantees from the minister?' He said, `No guarantees at all. To see our own people coming out and endorsing the blocking of the sale sort of left us with a bit of egg on our face.' What he really meant was an omelette the size of a satellite dish. He was just being polite to people he thought used to be his friends. He was asked, `Do you think there was any point in the visit at all?' He said, `Going on that, no. A lot of our people asked, "Where's Lindsay been over the last 18 months?"'

The fact is that Mr Tanner may well be the victim of some vicious infighting on the part of the Labor Party, who clearly want to see the young turks knocked off by the old turkeys who are in the leadership group at the present time, who read his speech on populism and rationalism and who understand that there is nothing in that that offers the old guard any encouragement. It certainly offers the people of Australia some glimmer of hope, but it says nothing about privatisation.

Madam President, ask yourself, `Why is that?' The answer is sitting opposite—28 of them, 18 belonging to the trade union movement; in other words, two-thirds. Since May of 1995, that is over two years ago, eight out of eight have been trade union members. That side of the chamber looks like a branch meeting of the Canberra branch of the ACTU. The only difference, of course, is that the delegate fees are paid by the taxpayers.

As long as the Labor Party thinks that the interests of the trade union movement, of which it is a wholly owned subsidiary, ought to be put ahead of the people of Australia, then it will continue to find itself not only languishing in the polls but also being ridiculed for its policy position on these issues. You only have to look at what is going on over there to see that this crowd has absolutely no interest at all in policy issues. They are interested in vicious infighting. They are interested in jockeying for position. They are interested in ensuring that some people's careers prosper at the expense of others. But they are not interested in the workers of AN. They are certainly not interested in the people of South Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you tell the Senate what this government will do to ensure a future for Australian National workers? What hope would they have under a Labor government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two simple answers to those questions. Under us, they have every hope of AN getting a new lease of life if this sale goes ahead. But I can assure you that they are acutely aware of what happens if it does not. I remind the Senate of what Senator Bob Collins had to say at an estimates committee in February this year. This is the bloke who is very good at mea culpas! He said that we doomed AN to failure in government. The Mayor of Port Augusta was giving evidence. Senator Calvert asked, `What would be the effect if the Senate were to block the sale of AN?' The mayor said, `I refuse to believe senators are that dumb.' Senator Collins asked, `How many of them have you met?' The mayor said, `Well, I've met you, dear.' So I do not think you will be holding on to that seat for much longer. The game is up as far as the people of Port Augusta are concerned. The workers in AN know that their interests are not being represented by a crowd that is stacking this place like you have never seen. ANSWER.PARA: That is consistent with the government's objective of contributing to a better global outcome. We accept that. Australia produces about only 1½ per cent of the world's greenhouse gases, so we are really insignificant in terms of the total global picture, but our per capita output is quite high and we believe that it can be improved. That is why we are working cooperatively with industry to produce a better result in that regard. In producing a better result in that regard, we will be making a contribution to a better global outcome.

If we are being asked to contribute unfairly—in other words, if we are being asked to accept that Australians should take a greater personal loss than Europeans or some other states—then we regard that as an unfair solution. As a matter of interest, we also regard it as unworkable. That is why we have said that the conclusion to the Berlin mandate process must be to an outcome which is fair and achievable. We are wedded to that. We think that not only is it fair but, being achievable, it will produce a better global greenhouse outcome as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Bob Collins asked me a question in my capacity representing the Attorney. I have an answer for him, in one day, and I would be very happy to give it to him. I indicate that my giving him a good answer on time is not because he once gave me a bottle of French champagne—and a very nice bottle it was, Senator, thank you—like the Prime Minister did. I do not need to be bribed to do that. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
On 17 June 1997, Senator Collins asked me, as the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question:

Minister, you are no doubt aware that the Northern Territory police have just paid $440,000 of money levied from taxpayers under the national gun buyback scheme to an individual for 22 Second World War 2 millimetre Hispano-Suiza aircraft cannons which were illegally imported into Australia, which must have seemed like Tattslotto for the owner. You may also be aware that the gun curator of the National War Memorial, Mr Peter Aitken, has stated publicly that `millions' of these old cannons are lying on scrap heaps around the world. The responsibility for this farce has been laid squarely at the feet of the Commonwealth government by the Northern Territory Chief Minister and Minister for Police, Shane Stone. Is the Chief Minister correct in his public assertions? Is the Commonwealth responsible for this? If so, can you explain to the levy payers why their money was spent in this way?"
The Attorney-General has provided the following response:

"Questions regarding the importation of prohibited goods should be directed to the Minister responsible for Customs. The question of whether any alleged illegality has occurred with respect to the cannons to which the Honourable Senator referred yesterday has been referred by the Northern Territory to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. In accordance with usual procedure, the AFP has in turn referred the matter to the Australian Customs Service. Pending the outcome of any inquiries by those bodies, it is inappropriate for me to offer any comment on whether or not the aircraft cannon which were the subject of the Honourable Senator's questions were in fact illegally imported into Australia.
My Department advises that there is no record of any prior approval given by the Commonwealth for payment for aircraft cannons by the Northern Territory.

My Department advises that, at a recent meeting, some State officers associated with the administration of the firearms buyback scheme discussed with Commonwealth officers the eligibility of some weapons of warfare for compensation under the scheme.

I am advised that the Commonwealth officers subsequently wrote to all jurisdictions advising that the Commonwealth would not "reimburse on instruments of warfare, cannon (defined as a fully automatic weapon firing high-explosive rounds), heavy machine-guns and the like".

Further advice as to the attitude the Commonwealth will take to compensation for any payments that may have been made by the State and Territory jurisdictions in a bona fide but mistaken belief that weapons were within the scheme is in course of preparation."

What we have seen is $65 million in savings in 1997, $138 million in 1998, $151 million in 1999 and $160 million in the year 2000—a total of $513 million taken away from student assistance. We also need to look at the additional strain that is being placed on the TAFE and school systems as a result of this government's actions. What we see is that the resources to cope with that demand are not being increased. The programs in TAFE are terribly underfunded. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: But what do we hear Labor getting up and doing; what do we hear the Democrats getting up and doing? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The new youth allowance, which has just been introduced, shows that incentives for education and training are at the top of the priority of this government. Let us compare this with what happened to youth under the Labor Party over a period of 13 years: youth unemployment went from 27 per cent of youth to 33 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Great Depression, how many people were unemployed? Of the population, 33 per cent of the population were unemployed and were trying to get work. What this last Labor government created was a great depression, in more ways than one, for the youth in this country. One-third of youth were unemployed. It reached a peak in the great Keating recession of 1992, when it got up to 35 per cent.
Senator Patterson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Patterson points out, it was much worse in rural areas and much worse in the depressed industrial cities of Australia.
—Thirty‐seven per cent.

—The problem, Senator Stott Despoja, was that all the incentives were in the wrong direction. The incentives were for young people to stay on the dole, not to get into training. If you had been with us on the Austudy inquiry, when we went around Australia, and listened to what the students had to say, you would have found the students saying, `Well, here we are on a certain level of Austudy, but we can get more benefits if we go and lie on the beach.' That was the system set up by that government. What the youth allowance has done is turn that right around. You were very quiet, Senator Stott Despoja, about what happens to the people who are on Austudy in this system.
—Senator Tierney, would you like to address your remarks through the chair.

—Through you, Madam Deputy President, I say to Senator Stott Despoja: you would be aware that, under this scheme that we have set up, people who used to be on Austudy are now in a much better arrangement. They are on a higher rate of pay and are eligible for the living away from home allowance, which is something they were not eligible for before. There is now no incentive to move to unemployment instead of study. That is something that was recommended by the students. That is something that we have introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Carr talked about the fact that there were turf battles over who controlled the payments in social security and education. Sure there were turf battles under your government, and it was never resolved in 13 years. You had students moving from Austudy benefits onto unemployment benefits, but it took a while for the system to catch up. So they would find out that students, after having left study, were still being paid. Then they would have to pay it all back.

What we have done is something that Labor could never do: we have resolved that problem. It is now a seamless web, where a person will move from one position to the other. There is no payback—none of that nonsense that occurred under your system. I think that what we have done is best summed up in the editorial of this morning's Daily Telegraph. It says:
. . . using the dole . . . money—
for—
. . . unearned holidays have cost taxpayers dearly, and have been extremely harmful to the youngsters themselves.
They have been putting off their responsibilities just at the time when they should be studying or starting a solid career.

The incentives are now in the system for them to move into training. If they are a 16‐ or 17-year-old, they can continue training. For heaven's sake! That is what we want them to do. If they are 16 or 17, they should stay in training.

What does the research show about people who stay in training? It says that they have three times the chance of getting a job as someone who has not been trained. That is what this government has set up. It has set up the incentives for them to go on and be trained and to be provided with the better jobs.

The broader policies of this government are to set up a framework where the jobs will be available. We are getting government debt down. We are getting growth for small business underway. We are developing labour market flexibility. We are giving young people incentives to go into education. When we held our inquiry two years ago, all the evidence suggested that we do what we have done today.

This is a program which is successful for youth. A youth allowance will get the appalling levels of youth unemployment down. The great depression for youth will be over because we will not have one-third of them sitting out there without training and without jobs. In this system, the incentive is to train, and we will have a system available where they will be able to get jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is classic scapegoat politics: when you cannot solve the problem, blame the victim. That is exactly what is happening. Young people are not choosing to be unemployed. Young people may not fit into the school system, but they are being punished for not being catered for by the system. I would have thought we would have learnt something during the Great Depression. All this government has done is go to the past and blame the victim. It is not good enough.
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That the workers of Australian National (AN) at Port Augusta are greatly concerned by claims by the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats that they will block the legislation for the sale of Australian National (AN).

That over the past five years, the impact of establishing National Rail (NR) has been that Australian National (AN) had its revenue generating business taken away, while it was left with all the debts. As a result there has been an enormous loss of jobs in AN and in Port Augusta.

That the workers of Australian National (AN) at Port Augusta believe the best opportunity for job security and future jobs in the rail industry in South Australia generally and Port Augusta in particular, is through the sale of AN and the involvement of the private sector in owning and operating railways.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

PARA.TAB: Ensure the passage of the AN sale Legislation through the Senate to ensure that private sector operators can purchase AN, removing the existing job uncertainty and creating the best possible opportunity for viable jobs in the rail industry in SA and Port Augusta.

AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION SALE BILL 1997
The bill will enable the Commonwealth to sell non-interstate mainline track rail assets currently vested in AN, with the initial elements to be sold by 30 June 1997. It is intended to:
provide authority and mechanisms for the sale of AN;
provide authority for the repeal, replacement or amendment of rail agreements with the States following their agreement to the sale arrangements;
amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 to allow the wind-up of AN after the sale; and
amend existing legislation for matters consequential to the above

The legislation underpins the Government's rail reform package and is thus essential to its implementation. The reform package has a number of elements but, in particular, seeks to revitalise rail transport by separating the provision of access to essential infrastructure (the track) from the provision of rail transport services which is more appropriately the role of the private sector.

Passage of the legislation is crucial to the attainment of the Government's timetable for the sale, ie 30 June 1997, as it will enable the Government to sell AN assets and services thus clearly signalling the Government's commitment to reform. It will also directly increase participation of the private sector in the rail freight industry.

AN is losing money and is in a unsustainable and declining financial position which is unlikely to be improved in the current environment of uncertainty. The extensive restructure required to generate an efficient and profitable rail system is best able to be achieved through government divestment and the injection of private sector transport expertise.

Prompt passage of the bill will mean that elements of AN can be divested in the current financial year and will also reduce uncertainty for AN, its staff and the community. Delays in sale will unnecessarily increase taxpayer liabilities and adversely effect the Government's budget strategy.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development
COMMONWEALTH VEHICLES (REGISTRATION AND EXEMPTION FROM TAXATION BILL 1997

The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill 1997 will provide for a system of Commonwealth registration for vehicles which are owned by or leased to the Commonwealth or Commonwealth authorities. The bill will also exempt from State and Territory taxation:
the sale of DASFLEET assets, including the vehicle fleet; leases of vehicles to the Commonwealth and to Commonwealth authorities; and
registration under State or Territory law of vehicles leased to the Commonwealth or to Commonwealth authorities for a continuous period of at least three months.

The bill has been prepared in the context of the sale or refinancing of DASFLEET, however, the bill's ongoing provisions will apply to any vehicle owned by, or leased to, the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority. The process of the sale or refinancing of DASFLEET is nearing completion and any delays in the process pending passage of the legislation would be likely to create unrest in the business and uncertainty in the minds of DASFLEET clients and parties interested in its purchase or refinance. The bill is a companion bill to the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill 1997.

The bill has been prepared in the context of the sale or refinancing of DASFLEET, however, the bill's provisions will apply to any vehicle owned by, or leased to, the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority.

This bill is a companion bill to the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill 1997.

INTERNATIONAL MONETARY AGREEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill will amend the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to enable the Commonwealth of Australia to lend money to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in the event of a crisis in the international monetary system; and introduce a simpler and more transparent framework for the conduct and recording of Australia' s financial transactions with the Me

The financial crisis in Mexico late in 1994 prompted concerns about the adequacy of the IMF's financial resources in the face of a similar crisis. In response, the New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB) have been developed—these arrangements will double the amount available under the IMF's existing arrangements to borrow from its members. Australia played a key role in the development of the NAB. Under the NAB, Australia may be required to lend up to SDR810 million (around $A1.5 billion) to the IMF in the event of a crisis in the international monetary system. In view of continuing risks in international financial markets, it is desirable that the NAB come into operation as quickly as possible, and that Australia take up its part in it.

Australia regularly undertakes financial transactions with the IMF. The Commonwealth and the Reserve Bank of Australia (which are responsible for undertaking transactions with the IMF) have agreed on an improved framework for conducting and recording Australia's transactions with the IMF. A simpler recording system is likely to reduce the administrative costs associated with, and enhance the transparency of, these transactions. It is desirable that these changes be introduced at the same time as Australia takes up its membership of the NAB to ensure that all these transactions are conducted in a consistent framework.

Introduction and passage of the bill in the Winter Sittings are necessary for Australia to complete the necessary steps for adherence to the New Arrangements to Borrow in the internationally agreed timeframe.

The first meeting of NAB participants will be held at the IMF/World Bank Annual Meetings in Hong Kong in September 1997. Provided that Australia has completed the processes for adherence, it will chair the first meeting of participants.

If the bill is not passed by 30 June 1997, Australia will not be able to fulfil its international obligations of adhering to the NAB before September 1997. This may delay the NAB coming into effect—the NAB will come into effect once participants with 85 per cent of the credit arrangements have adhered to it. It would also prevent Australia chairing the first meeting of NAB participants, which would be likely to attract considerable criticism.
Circulated with the authority of the Treasurer
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 1) 1997

The proposed bill provides amendments to implement the Government's 1997-98 Budget measures relating to higher education funding. In particular, the bill will enable the Minister to make special grants to higher education institutions for rationalisation and restructuring activities, and to issue guidelines and apply conditions relating to the criteria for, selection of and expenditure on proposals receiving assistance. It will also provide two ARCS measures—a 25 per cent discount to students who wish to make an up-front payment of $500 or more of their HECS liability, and simplification of the application arrangements for remission of HECS debts.

Passage in the Winter sitting period is required to enable implementation of the Budget measures in 1997 in order that institutions may have access to the financial assistance as soon as possible, and students may benefit from the HECS measures from the beginning of the 1998 academic year.

A delay in finalising the bill in the Winter sitting period would result in delays in the provision of financial assistance to institutions and delay the implementation of the HECS measures which would disadvantage students.

SMALL SUPERANNUATION ACCOUNTS AMENDMENT BILL 1997
To give effect to the 1997-98 Budget announcement reforming the current arrangements for the early release of superannuation benefits.

The Government announced in the Budget that the reforms to the early release of superannuation benefits would take effect from 1 July 1997. The reforms will restrict the ability of members of superannuation funds to access their superannuation benefits. WOOL INTERNATIONAL AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Wool International Act 1993 to provide for the liquidation of Wool International on the sale of the wool stockpile and retirement of the associated debt,—allocation of entitlements and making of cash distributions to wool-tax payers from the liquidation of Wool International's assets, trading of entitlements and borrowing against the security of those entitlements, and phasing out of certain functions of Wool International related to services to the wool industry.

The wool industry has endured the impacts of drought and low wool prices since the collapse of the market in the early 1990s. Many growers are heavily in debt, and are still incurring operating losses or are only minimally profitable.

The amendments provide for payments to be made to wool-tax payers from the assets of Wool International, the first of which can be made in the first half of the 1997/98 financial year. The legislation also provides for growers to sell their entitlements to future distributions, or to borrow against them, providing valuable income sources for some distressed growers.

There is a wide expectation in the wool industry that the cash distribution will be made to growers in about October 1997, and the Minister has pledged to try to provide the legislative basis for trading in entitlements by July 1997.
The amending legislation would need to be passed in the Winter Sitting for this to be possible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect if the bill is not passed this sittings

SPEECH.PARA: A legislative basis for trading in entitlements would be delayed until later in 1997 and the distribution of some $75 million by Wool International to growers would also be delayed by 3 months or more. There have been widespread representations from the wool industry and Wool Council in particular, in the lead up to the Government's recent policy approval and industry has an expectation that these amendments will be implemented within the next few months.
A failure to implement these changes by 1 July 1997 would result in additional hardships to growers and strong negative representations from the industry.

The correspondence read as follows—

Attorney‐General
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600

I refer to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 3.

Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 26 March 1997 concerning the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1997 No. 3), and to the notice given by Senator Calvert in the Senate on 26 March 1997 that you will move, 15 sitting days after that date, that the regulations be disallowed.

You have expressed concerns in relation to two regulations (3(1)(b) and 12.11). For the reasons set out below and in the context of all the relevant legislative provisions, I consider that regulations 3(1)(b) and 12.11 are acceptable. I therefore urge you not to proceed with the motion of disallowance.

I note that the proposed disallowance motion relates to the whole of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1997 No. 3). If these were to be disallowed, the operation of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 (MA Act) would be affected which would impact adversely on case matters. If you do proceed with a motion of disallowance, I strongly urge that you seek to disallow only regulations 3 and 12.
Regulation 3(1)(b)

Regulation 3(1)(b) provides that a Magistrate may issue a summons requiring a person who is only to produce documents, other articles or both, to attend before the Magistrate and produce them. You state that this appears to be a restrictive provision given the distance that people may be required to travel and the rapid forms of communication available today, and you suggest that flexible electronic or courier services should be available to members of the public.

The regulation must be read in the context of section 13 of the MA Act. The purpose of section 13 is to enable the taking of evidence and production of documents or other articles in Australia on behalf of a foreign country in relation to a criminal matter.

In practice, a foreign country would make a request to the Attorney‐General for documents or other articles in Australia to be produced for the purpose of criminal proceedings in that country (subsection 13(1). Where the Attorney‐General authorises the production of documents or other articles, paragraph 13(2)(b) provides that a Magistrate may require the documents or other articles to be produced. Regulation 3(1)(b) sets out the procedure by which a Magistrate may do this (namely by issuing a summons). If documents or other articles are produced, the Magistrate is then required to send the documents, or copies of the documents certified by the Magistrate to be true copies, or the other articles, to the Attorney‐General for forwarding on to the requesting country.

The amendments made to regulation 3 do not substantively change the previous regulations. The new regulations clearly distinguish between persons who are required to attend and give evidence as witnesses (regulation 3(1)(a)), and persons who are required to attend only to produce documents or articles (regulations 3(1)(b)). An example of a person who would come under regulation 3(1)(b) is a person who is required to produce business records such as bank records, but who is not required to provide evidence and to be cross‐examined. The intention of the amendment to the regulations is to ensure that the purpose of a summons issued under these provisions is clear on its face. The person to whom the summons is addressed is left in no doubt about the purpose for which he or she is required to attend before a Magistrate.

As you would be aware, `production of documents or articles' has a technical legal meaning in this context. In producing the documents or articles, the relevant person will need to provide appropriate information on oath (formal evidence) on such things as their position in the company, the status of the items produced and in the case of records on the accuracy of their contents. This formal evidence is necessary to put the documents or articles in admissible form so that they may be adduced in evidence in any proceedings in the requesting country. It is important to bear in mind that the material is to be used in criminal proceedings and therefore will need to comply strictly with admissibility requirements. It is also important to bear in mind that the material is to be used in a foreign country. Providing this formal evidence to a Magistrate in Australia is preferable to requiring the person to attend a court in another country in order to comply with the necessary formalities relating to the admissibility of documents or articles.

Because of the international nature of these requests and the implications for admissibility in court proceedings involving criminal matters in other countries, my view is that it is essential to have a person, who has custody or control of the relevant documents or articles, to appear physically before a Magistrate in order to produce those documents or articles. The person should not, for example, be able to simply mail those items or deliver them to the Magistrate using electronic or courier services.

Accordingly, I consider that it is appropriate for regulation 3(1)(b) to require a person to attend before a Magistrate for the purpose of producing documents or other articles. I assure you that, as a matter of administrative practice, the documents or other articles are always sought in a manner involving the least amount of inconvenience to the holder of the documents or other articles. For example, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions proceeds on the basis that a warrant should be issued in jurisdiction in which the relevant person resides.

The production of documents or other articles would therefore be sought in the State or Territory in which the person who has custody of those things is located. I would not envisage the situation arising where, for example, a Magistrate in Hobart who considers that a person in Darwin has custody of some relevant documents requires that person to bring the documents to Hobart. The Attorney‐General's authorisation under subsection 13(1) would instead be given to a Magistrate in Darwin. I wish to draw to your attention that in cases where documents have been located in different jurisdictions, the Attorney‐General has issued multiple authorisations to Magistrates in different jurisdictions in order to avoid the type of problem you have identified.
Regulation 12.11

Regulation 12.11 omits Forms 4, 5 and 6 which comprise an Application for Search Warrant (Person), Application for Search Warrant (Premises) and Search Warrant respectively. You note that the current Form 6 provides the usual protection relating to necessary and reasonable force, and on reasonable grounds, and you seek confir mation that the new electronic forms will include these safeguards.

It is important to note that the protections you refer to are the subject of substantive provisions in the MA Act itself. The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Act 1996 inserted a new Part VIIA in the Act dealing with search, seizure and powers of arrest. This is an extensive new Part (comprising sections 38A to 38Z) which is consistent with amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 made by the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994.

The procedures for applying for, issuing and executing search warrants are all subject to the requirements of the legislation. Section 38B deals with the application for search warrants, and requires a police officer to have "reasonable grounds" in relation to suspecting the location of relevant evidential material. Section 38C required a Magistrate to be satisfied that there are such reasonable grounds before the Magistrate can issue a search warrant. Section 38J, which deals with the execution of search warrants, authorises the obtaining of assistance and use of force as is necessary and reasonable in the circumstances. These requirements would all need to be satisfied, regardless of whether they are stated on a statutory or administrative form.

Previously the MA Act required the relevant forms to be prescribed in the regulations. The reason for no longer prescribing these forms statutorily is that prescribed forms are inherently inflexible, unable to be updated without amending regulations, and can give rise to technical legal arguments about whether the prescribed form has been strictly complied with. For purposes of administrative convenience and efficiency, precedents will still be drafted so that a new form does not need to be re‐invented every time an application is made. It is intended that these forms will be available electronically to investigators and prosecutors so that they can readily enter their specific information, while retaining the standard provisions.

While it is not necessary as a matter of substantive law to have the wording you have referred to on the forms, I do see considerable benefit in including words relating to reasonable grounds, and necessary and reasonable force on the face of the form to advise recipients of those limitations and to reinforce the substantive law. I am advised that the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions has issued draft administrative forms which include such wording.
I hope this explanation addresses the Committee's concerns and that you will not consider it necessary to proceed with the motion of disallowance.
Yours sincerely
DARYL WILLIAMS
Attorney‐General
