SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray is requesting, among other things, the tabling of information which will identify—and he does not deny this, as I understood his remarks—directly or indirectly the successful applicants of financial assistance schemes established under section 183 of the Native Title Act and the non-statutory special circumstances scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is prepared to provide statistical information and general material relating to the assessment of applications for financial assistance which does not identify any particular applicant or involve disclosure of their financial or other circumstances. That was outlined in the Attorney-General's letter to Senator Murray of 28 May.

I have for tabling information prepared by the Attorney-General's Department which answers those aspects of Senator Murray's motion which do not require disclosure of identifying material—that is, paragraphs (d), (i) and (k) of the motion. There are also aspects of paragraphs (h) and (j) for which we will be providing material—and these matters relate to the number of people assisted.

The government is able to provide the Senate with the means test which is applied in requests for financial assistance in native title matters. This means test is contained in the relevant guidelines. Those guidelines were approved by the previous Attorney-General and are attached to the information provided.

The means test is applied to all applicants, irrespective of whether they are indigenous or not. The means test requires consideration of the financial hardship to the applicant and the focus is whether the applicant could meet the costs of the matter without getting into serious financial difficulty. Applicants are required to provide extensive financial information about themselves as well as full details of the case to enable a proper assessment of the application.

The Attorney-General's Department has prepared tables which set out the number of individuals, groups or corporate bodies—both indigenous and non-indigenous—who have been assisted to May 1997 under the native title assistance schemes. The rates at which assistance is provided is also set out in the material prepared by the department. There are two different rates. For standard matters, the rate is 80 per cent of the Federal Court scale, and for cases determined by the department as test cases, the rate is 100 per cent of the Federal Court scale. Standard conditions are contained in the guidelines. Senators should of course note that where a particular applicant is assessed as being able to make some payment towards the cost of the case, a contribution is required as a matter of course.

While the government is prepared to provide information which is statistical or general in nature, to the extent that the senator's motion requires tabling in parliament of material which identifies individuals—whether they are corporate bodies or natural persons—or would involve disclosure of their financial or other circumstances, the government is not prepared to breach applicant confidentiality.

There exists a longstanding practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys-General, to treat applications for financial assistance in confidence. This practice extends to neither confirming nor denying that particular applications have been received. The practice accords with the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988 in relation to information provided by natural persons and the general law of breach of confidence.

Most of the information in the present circumstance was supplied to the government for the purpose of the administration of section 183 of the Native Title Act. Noting that one of the criteria under section 183 for granting assistance is hardship to the applicant, it is obviously necessary, for the administration of section 183, that applicants disclose full details of their financial circumstances. The balance of the information in this matter was supplied to the government for the purpose of the administration of the non‐statutory special circumstances scheme—for provision of financial assistance prior to the inquiry stage of native title proceedings and also to assist persons involved in common law native title claims. Again, one of the criteria for granting assistance under this scheme is hardship to the applicant.

To demonstrate hardship, it is required that applicants disclose their financial circumstances. If the confidentiality of such information could not be maintained, there would be a substantial risk that persons having legitimate applications for assistance would be dissuaded from making such applications. This would prejudice the proper operation of the assistance scheme established by section 183 of the act and of the special circumstances scheme. That would be contrary to the public interest.

The native title financial assistance schemes are a form of legal aid provided directly by the Commonwealth. The vast majority of legal aid in Australia is provided through state and territory legal aid commissions. Senators should note that in New South Wales, for instance, there is not only a longstanding convention that successive Attorneys‐General do not release confidential information about individual applicants; there is also a statutory prohibition on disclosure. Similar secrecy requirements are imposed in Senator Murray's home state of Western Australia. He could not obtain from legal aid in Western Australia the kind of information that he is asking the Commonwealth to disclose in relation to applications that are made to it.

In summary, the government resists those aspects of the motion which would identify successful applicants who are non‐natural persons, on the basis that this would be contrary to the principles of the general law of breach of confidence and contrary to the public interest. Had the senator continued to seek the tabling of material which identifies natural persons, this would have been further resisted, on the basis that it would be contrary to the principles established by the Privacy Act. I am sure the Australian public would expect that information provided in confidence to government would not be released or used for purposes other than those for which it was originally provided.

I have only one other point to add, Senator Murray. You indicate that you believe that there are only 30 of these. That may be the case, but the point of the confidentiality of someone's financial circumstances relates to that person. It is their financial circumstances that they are entitled not to have displayed before the world simply because they are an applicant for legal assistance. Whether there is one of them or there are 30 makes little difference; the sin committed is the same. The government is not persuaded by the fact that you seek it for only this or that number. The point is that there is a longstanding practice—for the purposes I have outlined—of not revealing the details of individual applicants. The government believes that is an appropriate practice which it intends to maintain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are guidelines in relation to such things as in confidence and commercial‐in‐confidence. In many cases, what happens with governments and government departments is that the actual reality of the confidence is hidden in other issues. The names of people who, for instance, apply for legal aid would hardly be secret in the end. Court lists are not secret. It is possible to find out that a person has been represented by a legal aid lawyer. You might find out that some people may have requested legal aid and got it knocked back. In some cases, that might be thought of as a secret.

SPEECH.PARA: The confidential information about a person's private financial situation can be argued in various ways. If that is what the guidelines say, those elements can be removed from the information that is sought. The fact that various Attorneys‐General, under freedom of information or requests from the Senate, have very frequently used the issue of confidentiality—and especially commercial‐in‐confidence—does not necessarily mean that it is right. The very recent AAT ruling, which I mentioned in the Senate just the other day—that ruling was in May—would indicate that the range of what commercial‐in‐confidence comprises is actually very narrow, even under AAT rulings. It looks at the books and the specific financial situation of a company.

It may be possible that departments can provide information without providing anything that will specifically damage the business of any individual. That is quite possible in a grown‐up world. It is time for governments of all colours to stop hiding behind a very broad concept of secret—and commercial‐in‐confidence and confidentiality—and to start looking at the fact that there are issues which people deserve to know. There are issues where any relatively competent department can provide information without damaging anything of a commercial nature for the people involved—or their confidences.

As I said, you do not have to come into court with a bag over your head. People do know who it is that is standing up in court, unless you are a minor, and it is easy to find out whether a person is represented by a legal aid lawyer. So I do not think the argument holds water. There are guidelines, and it is possible to protect specific information about a person's wherewithal. I do not think what is being asked here is unreasonable.

HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1997

The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the government's on‐going commitment to quality, diversity, equity and innovative change in the higher education sector. It strengthens the framework, initiated by this government last year, on which the sector can build for the future.

The bill provides supplementation for price movements, covering items such as superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals, special capital projects, grants to open learning organisations and the total limit for certain grants. The total increase in 1998 will be $9,658,000.

The bill also provides $26 million over the next four years to fund the rationalisation and restructuring programme, as announced in the budget. This programme complements the existing provision that allows institutions to receive an advance of operating grant to assist with the cashflow implications of restructuring. The programme will assist institutions with restructuring and rationalisation activities that will lead to permanent benefits, and which are beyond the funding capacity of the institution involved.

The funds will be used to support a variety of proposals including: rationalisation of programmes; the joint development of infrastructure, including electronic infrastructure; and the collaborative use of shared activities and resources with other institutions. Assistance provided under the programme is anticipated to be of particular benefit to regional institutions.

Through this bill, the government is furthering equitable access to higher education by introducing a 25 per cent discount for partial up‐front Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) payments of $500 or more. This will benefit students who have been unable to access the previous 25 per cent discount, available only to those students who were able to pay their full hecs contribution up‐front.

The measure also redresses the existing inequity between an arts student receiving a 25 per cent discount on an up‐front payment of their full hecs contribution of $3,300 and a law student who might wish to pay the same amount, but would not be eligible for any discount unless they could pay their full up‐front HECS charge.
This measure provides an incentive for students to partially pay their hecs contribution up‐front, and will be of real benefit to HECS liable students.

The arrangements build on and strengthen the essential features of HECS, to continue to ensure that no qualified student is prevented from entering higher education because of an inability to pay at the time of enrolment.

The bill also provides for streamlining of the application arrangements for remission of student debts incurred under HECS and the Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme (OLDPS). This measure will make the remission arrangements simpler and more accessible to students, by replacing the complex two‐tiered application process with a more generous set 12 month timeframe for all remission applicants.

As a result of this measure, most students will actually have longer to seek remission of their debt. Students will no longer have to apply within a set 3 month period, which has been an artificial barrier for students seeking to have their debt remitted. The new arrangements make the application process more transparent and accessible to students, and are less cumbersome to administer.

At the same time, this government has moved quickly to address concerns expressed by the administrative appeals tribunal about the legal limitations of the guidelines that have applied to the remission of debts. The bill will now give legislative force to the administrative guidelines on remission of debts by providing for them to be a disallowable instrument.
This bill reflects the government's commitment to a relevant, high quality education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SMALL SUPERANNUATION ACCOUNTS AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill amends the Small Superannuation Accounts Act 1995 to tighten the arrangements relating to the early release of monies held in the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve, or SHAR. These amendments are consistent with measures announced in the 1997‐98 budget reforming current arrangements for the early release of superannuation benefits to members.

The budget reforms will apply to savings in superannuation funds and retirement savings accounts and will largely be implemented through amendments to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations and the Retirement Savings Accounts Regulations. However, to ensure complete coverage of all superannuation savings arrangements, the government has decided to extend the reforms to SHAR.

SHAR was established to accept superannuation contributions from employers in circumstances where the employer's superannuation fund will not accept a particular contribution because of requirements that fees and charges not exceed the interest earned on such amounts.
SHAR is administered by the Commissioner of Taxation.

Consistent with the government's retirement incomes policy that superannuation savings should be preserved for retirement, SHAR only permits contributions to be accessed by the individual for whose benefit they are held, in the following circumstances:
. the balance is less than $500 and the individual has ceased to be employed by all depositors;
. the individual is in severe financial hardship;
. the individual has retired because of permanent disability;
. the individual has turned 65; or
. the individual is not an Australian resident and is not employed in Australia.
The amendments contained in the bill will restrict the circumstances when monies held in SHAR can be withdrawn. In particular, the amendments will have the following effects:
. The $500 threshold will be abolished.
. The `severe financial hardship' test will be replaced with an objective test of hardship based on whether the individual has received specified Commonwealth payments for a certain period.
. SHAR will be able to release monies to a person who claims to be a non‐resident only after that person has reached the preservation age, currently 55.
The amendments will take effect on 1 July 1997 but will not apply to withdrawal requests lodged with the Commissioner of Taxation before that date.
The government considers that these amendments will improve the administration of SHAR and will also address some abuses of the current arrangements.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

Before lunch I was suggesting that we move to clause 68, but I gather the government would rather move to the next set of amendments on the schedule. Those amendments are in our name, but identical amendments are to be moved by the Democrats and the Greens. In a sense, they go to matters that relate to whether the ballot should be a postal ballot. We have already resolved within the opinion of the Senate that the ballot should be compulsory, that it should not be voluntary. This set of amendments goes to about seven or eight different issues which provide for a postal ballot.

I do not know whether the government has made a decision to try the option of a compulsory postal ballot but, if the opposition, Democrat and Green amendments do not get up at this stage, then we will be in a position where the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 will reflect support for a compulsory postal ballot. That would raise all sorts of problems, some of which the government may have considered but the total implications of which the government may not have considered. The concept of a compulsory postal ballot is one which, it could be agreed overwhelmingly, would be very hard to implement and administer. For that reason, we are moving amendments Nos 5 to 7, 10, 21, 33, 39, 41, 43, 76, 77 and 79 which do, in fact, reject the concept of a compulsory postal ballot.

As we said in the earlier debate—there is probably no need to revisit all those arguments—the attendance ballot is the most appropriate one to pursue, and we do pursue it, for the reasons I mentioned earlier. In terms of the practical problems with a compulsory postal ballot, one does not have to apply their minds too much and too hard to realise that it is almost an impossibility to provide in law for a situation where people would have to mail back the ballot slip and envelope, or whatever. I think you will find a compulsion in terms of a postal ballot is something which is very hard to apply. We want to move on to consideration of an attendance day ballot and in some senses see these amendments as somewhat consequential to the decision taken by the Senate before lunch.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing these amendments. I note Senator Bolkus's comments. I did not realise there were difficulties with compulsory elections. I thought compulsory elections were good all the time. I note with interest that compulsion and postal do not go together. Perhaps the opposition should have thought of that when they decided to make this bill compulsory.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I deal with the reasons why the government does believe it is appropriate in this case for this election to be a postal ballot. There were a whole lot of reasons why we thought it should be postal, but, given our primary decision in relation to it being voluntary, there were and still are good reasons for it to be postal. It is quite clear—and I do not think the opposition would contend the argument—that a postal ballot does generally result in a higher turnout than an attendance ballot, when it is voluntary. That has been well proven in many elections.

Despite what the opposition have said, we are interested in a high turnout for this election. We are just not prepared to force people to do so. We would rather use the carrot than the stick. So there is a linkage, but not a fatal linkage, in the sense that without voluntary voting we would walk away from postal voting.

An attendance ballot, it must be said, would cost around $50 million compared with the estimate for a postal ballot of $35 or $36 million. So if we are just talking about whether it is postal or attendance, we are talking about a difference of a considerable amount of money. That is a consideration in this case for a government which, as you all know, has had to contend with a significant problem in the government's finances. While we are prepared to commit some $36 million to an election, we think that is an amount that is warranted. But to go to a compulsory attendance ballot, you are talking up to $20 million extra to elect delegates to attend a 10‐day convention. Of course, the convention will cost some millions to run so we drew a line at that.

We do believe that it is appropriate to have a postal vote. They are now very widely held in the community in a range of organisations—at local government level, in a number of civil organisations and in the trade union movement—and it is a growing feature of state and federal elections that people cast their vote by post. We are not, as a government, advocating any greater postal voting in parliamentary elections. But this is not a parliamentary election, as we have to keep reminding the Senate. It is an election for delegates, elected state wide, to a 10‐day convention.

We do not believe there is either the incentive or the opportunity for any fraudulent activity. There are a number of quite appropriate security measures built into the bill to minimise the extent to which there is any electoral fraud. I find it a bit rich to hear arguments about electoral fraud, given the opposition's constant statements when in government that there was absolutely nothing wrong with the electoral system.

We do not believe that there is any disenfranchising. The argument about millions of people not having the opportunity to vote is based on a slightly misleading perception about statistics in this area. There are about two million voters, I gather, who change their enrolment throughout the course of any one year. So there is a 20 per cent turnover in the roll in any one year. That does not mean that at any one time on any one day there are two million people incorrectly enrolled. If that were the case, I think we would have a very significant problem with our electoral system. That is simply not the case. There are far fewer than that who at any one time are not enrolled correctly. There will, of course, be the normal period between the calling of the election and the closing of the rolls, and that always results in increased activity from electors to correct their enrolments. That same opportunity will apply in this case.

People who do not receive ballot papers because they are incorrectly enrolled will be able to obtain them. So that is being allowed for. There is sufficient time, because we are allowing three to four weeks from the dispatch of the postal ballot material to the time they have to be returned. So anyone who genuinely wants to vote but is not properly enrolled—and, as I said, we do want people to vote—will have that opportunity to get their ballot paper. There should not be all that many people in that situation. The other argument raised in this area is about Australian citizens from non-English speaking backgrounds. Again, as outlined to the Senate committee that inquired into this bill—and we should not forget there has been a full Senate inquiry into this bill—there are adequate measures in the bill to deal with that issue.

I also point out that it was not incidental to the government's consideration of this matter that this is a unique election. It will not involve the normal political parties and it will not involve the normal issues. There has not been anything like this for Australians before. There will be different candidates, different parties and different groups all discussing the one issue of whether or not Australia becomes a republic.

We think there will be some advantage in voters receiving, some three to four weeks before they finally have to vote, all the relevant voting material indicating who all the candidates are, what their objectives are, what they stand for, how to contact them and a lot of information on how to vote. They will have sufficient time—as I say, three to four weeks—to give a lot of thought to how they want to vote through this postal voting process. I think it has those advantages. So we do believe that, on balance, this election ought to be conducted by post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of points that Senator Minchin made. I say at the outset that this debate will be a lot shorter if we are not going to be in the business of distortion. You know full well, Senator Minchin, that our position has consistently been that we believe in compulsory attendance ballots. That is the cleanest, fairest and most democratic way to go. To argue that I might, in the language you used, have some problems with the compulsory election denies the fact that I have made it very clear that the concept of a compulsory attendance ballot is the right way to go and the most democratic way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: To argue that postal ballots are conducted elsewhere and widely held denies the fact that this is the first time that we are talking about a postal ballot of some 11.7 million people. Local council ballots are small in number. Trade union ballots are small in number. We are talking here of a nationwide—11.7 million people, maybe 12 million people—postal ballot. We think that in those circumstances there is increased capacity for fraud. We are concerned about fraud in postal ballots. Nothing we have said in the past would go to that issue.

In terms of the roll and the elections, as they are currently run, we reckon we have one of the fairest and cleanest systems you can find, if not the fairest and the cleanest. Evidence after evidence adduced to parliamentary committees supports that position. But, when you talk about some 12 million voting envelopes going out to the electorate, with no extra resources to ensure the security of that delivery and very little security in terms of who votes for whom, you have to be concerned about fraud in the system.

This may not be a parliamentary election; but this goes to the heart of the Australian constitution. As such, it needs to be treated as importantly, if not more importantly, than an election for the parliament every three years. We are talking here of a fundamental step. If you take the government's word seriously in this proposition, then this is an important step towards constitutional reform. If it is an important step towards constitutional reform, then it needs to be treated as seriously as a normal ballot. That is why we say that a postal ballot is inappropriate.

We have always said that two million people move each year and that some re‐register. We also said at the same time as that that no information will be provided in the voting envelopes to families of non-English speaking background and there will be no normal assistance for the aged, the frail, those who are not literate and so on. There are hundreds of thousands of those people in our community.

The other aspect that needs to be responded to is the capacity for people to change their enrolment, to re‐enrol. Senator Minchin might say, `It's a four‐week election campaign and people will have a chance to consider their vote.' But you are providing for one week from the close of nominations to the close of the rolls. When you are talking about a desensitised community to this issue, when you are talking about an election that in many ways will come upon them as a surprise, then you should realise that allowing so many people seven days, in the absence of a habitation review for some two years, is nowhere near good enough. How many slices of the democratic salami are you going to indulge in to ensure that people do not participate in this? We think a compulsory attendance vote is the only democratic way to go. This particular fall back position is one that is in many ways the worst of all worlds.

Senator Minchin, I have just a couple of questions. How much would it cost to run a compulsory postal ballot? How much would it cost to run a postal ballot—compulsory or voluntary—if you had to use the next size up in envelopes or use a tax pack for the three major states? Isn't it a fact that your constitutional convention is going to cost $4 million?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a mathematician; I do not carry those figures around in my head. If it were a compulsory postal ballot, the Electoral Commission estimate of the enforcement of compulsion in relation to a postal ballot is up to $4 million, in relation to tracing all those who do not vote and instituting all the prosecution and offence provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act to enforce compulsion. You would have to add that to the cost of the postal ballot, so you are talking about another $4 million. So it would be close to $40 million for a compulsory postal ballot as against $50 million‐plus for a compulsory attendance ballot.
—No, $49.5 million—your figures.

—A minimum of $49.5 million, but you know what elections are like. As I say, we are not expecting a need for the envelope the next size up, but whether we will need it is entirely dependent on the number of people who do nominate. If there were a lot of nominations in the biggest state of New South Wales and we had to use that envelope, as you know from evidence—I think this was all discussed in the original committee, so I am not sure why we are going over it all again—it would be 75c per item in New South Wales, so you would add that times the number of voters, which is $1½ million to $2 million, I guess. This was all brought to your attention at the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Your third question related to the cost of the convention itself, and of course that is a cost that has to be worn whatever election method is used. We are budgeting for up to $4 million to conduct that convention. We will be meeting the expenses of all delegates in terms of airfares, accommodation and allowances. We will not be paying any sitting fees or anything like that, but to run this thing and pay for delegates' expenses we have budgeted for up to $4 million.

Can I say also, because I think this gets a bit lost in the ether, that of course any change to our constitution would require under current law, which we have no proposal to change, a compulsory attendance ballot at a referendum. We are not proposing any change to that. That is what would be required if the constitution were to be amended. This is an ancillary stage, a preliminary stage, commensurate with our election policy, which was that we have this national discussion in the forum of a convention to which half the delegates would be elected. We think that in those circumstances, as a preliminary to a referendum, or plebiscite, this should be done by a voluntary postal ballot, and we remain committed to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if the minister could tell the committee what the government estimates are for the number of people who will miss the vote because their postal address is different from their street address and what arrangements will be made for people overseas. In other words, under your proposal for a postal vote is the onus on the people who do not live at their postal address to have postal votes forwarded, or will they be able to pick up a postal vote from the electoral office or through embassies? If so, what do you do about the problem, then, of two postal votes heading in their direction?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure of the first question, because voters will have the postal voting materials sent to their postal address. If they register a postal address different from their street address, it will be sent to their postal address. So I am not quite sure what that question was alluding to.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as you know, we have introduced amendments consistent with the recommendation of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee to introduce measures commensurate with a normal election in relation to overseas voters. That is a government amendment that we will move at a later stage, depending on what happens to the rest of the bill. If the Senate wants it to be a compulsory attendance ballot, then the government's amendments will be superseded, but we have proposed, on the basis of it being a voluntary postal ballot, amendments to the overseas voting arrangements so that they will in effect be the same as they currently are for an attendance ballot: people will be able to go to overseas posts and obtain ballot voting ma terial and either mail it back or deposit the vote there and then with the overseas mission.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem there, of course, is that in the meantime presumably there will be a good number of those people who are having their postal ballot sent out to their electoral address back home. In other words, people overseas who are getting postal votes from the local Australian authority with have two postal votes headed their way—the one they pick up and fill in on the spot over there and the one that is heading to their electoral address. We might deal with that issue first and then go back to the other one.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Brown's question, the security measures which are detailed in the bill will prevent the possibility of anybody being able to cast two votes. That will be impossible because of the unique bar code arrangements. The Electoral Commission has established arrangements to make sure that, if in any circumstance two votes were received from the one person, only one can be counted. There cannot be double voting, according to the security measures put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question I put related to this: people are enrolled according to their residential address, not their postal address. When Senator Minchin replied, he implied that people enrol according to their postal address. They do not. They enrol according to their residential address.

SPEECH.PARA: That being the case, there are thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of Australians whose postal address is different from their residential address, who may not even have a letterbox at their residential address. This applies to a lot of people in the bush, for example, and in new housing areas around cities. I am wondering what provision the government has for this novel situation, because I think it is very unprepared in being able to match up people who are on the electoral roll with postal addresses that the electoral authorities do not know about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral Commission conducts mail‐outs to voters all the time. If a voter wishes to have a postal address—for example, a box—different from their residential address, they have that option. They have always had that option. There are names and addresses in the electoral roll which record, at the voter's request, a postal address different from the residential address. Where a postal address is recorded, that is where voting material or any other material the Electoral Commission sends out in its regular mailings is sent. If no separate postal address is identified, then the material is sent to the residential address, as is the case with all electoral material now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not quite the same as electoral information. This is a person's vote. I again ask the parliamentary secretary: isn't it the case that there are many people who are enrolled according to a residential address and the electoral office does not know their postal address? I suggest that, if the electoral office is saying it does know both of those things all the way down the line, it is out of touch with how rapidly people are moving in Australia—I think Senator Bolkus said some two million people move a year—and how many people have different residential and postal addresses.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder if the electoral authority has done any assessment of what the fallout rate will be there. It cannot tell me it is nil. It is going to be quite considerable. If the electoral authority is simply saying it is nil, then it has not looked at the problem.

This is a national postal election being proposed by the government for the first time. It is not, as Senator Bolkus said, local government. It is massive, and I wonder what preparation the government has got for that fallout. I would feel much more confident if the government had some estimate of the fallout there is going to be after it sends mail to addresses at which people do not live. When it sends mail to residential addresses which do not receive mail and there is no facility for receiving mail, there is no way the electoral office is going to be able to follow those people up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this debate. To be correctly enrolled is a matter of law. You must give an address to the Electoral Commission in the electorate you care to be enrolled in. You must state a residential address. If you want to have material mailed to you at a different address, you can give a postal address, but you have to show an address or you cannot be correctly enrolled. It is a matter of law. We have a compulsory enrolment system. You have to be enrolled and, if you move, you must by law notify the Electoral Commission of your change of address.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already said in response to Senator Bolkus that there are nothing like two million people at any one time who are incorrectly addressed. The Electoral Commission cannot, by definition, give you an answer as to how many people on any one day are not living at the address at which they are enrolled. If they do move, they only have 30 days, I think, as a matter of law to correct the enrolment or they are in breach of the Electoral Act.

If those people do not receive ballot material, they can obtain ballot material and vote. It is just the same as people who go to an attendants' booth at an election and find their name not on the list. If they say they should be there, they can be given a provisional vote. It would work in exactly the same way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then the question to you, parliamentary secretary, is: do all the people on the electoral roll by law have to notify the electoral office of their postal address, as distinct from their residential address?

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to give an address when they enrol. If they want postal material sent to an address other than their residential address, they have the option of indicating to the Electoral Commission a separate postal address. But they must give a residential address in order to be correctly enrolled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot duck this. The point is that the government is instituting a postal election process for the first time. Our names on the electoral roll have always been based on our residential address. In fact, electoral authorities come around and strike you off the roll if they find you are not at that electoral address. It is not postal addresses; it is residential addresses. That is because we have always had voting at the polling booth. You go along to the polling booth and state your name and address and a line gets put through your name if the two match. But never have people been required by law to give their postal address in anticipation of a postal election.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying is that people have not necessarily recorded their postal address with the electoral office. They have not been required to. Suddenly, out of the blue, we are having this proposal for an election based on postal addresses, but there has been no provision in the existing laws when people have enrolled up to now to ensure they give their postal address. Sure, the electoral office sends out postal material, but it is doing so to inform people of an election, without there being a legal requirement on the electoral office that a ballot slip goes to everybody on the role.

The point I am making is that many people have a different postal address to their residential address, and you do not have the provision to pick up those people and ensure they get their ballot slips under present laws. You are going to say, of course, that most of them will be picked up. That is fine, but I am concerned about those people who are not going to be picked up because they are registered with a postal address that is different to their residential address.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe we are speaking at cross purposes. I am not quite sure where Senator Brown is coming from. If they have a residential address and no postal address, the ballot slip will be mailed to their residential address. I know plenty of people with a residential and a postal address and they get mail at both locations. Some would prefer that they did not receive mail at their residential address, but it comes to them at that address and they accept the mail at their residential address.

SPEECH.PARA: If people have indicated to the Electoral Commission that they want their mail directed somewhere else, that is where it will go. If they have not, it will go to their residential address and they will collect it in the normal way, along with every other Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This is wonderful. My office has just checked with the electoral office. You do not have to put your postal address on the enrolment form. I do not know where Senator Minchin has been, but what I am trying to say is that, if the electoral office mails out voting slips to people who do not have letter boxes or mail receiving facilities at their residential addresses, they will not get those slips. That is it; pure and simple.

SPEECH.PARA: You ought to recognise, Senator Minchin, that many Australians do not receive mail at their residential address. It may be that they move a lot. It may be that they get it at their business. Everybody else knows their postal address, but the electoral office does not know where to mail information to those people because it has not recorded it. What I am saying to you is that many people in our community are not going to get their ballot slips because they do not have mail receiving facilities at their residential address.

If you ring Australia Post, you will find that it does not deliver mail to every residential address in this country—not by a long shot. Is the government going to ensure that everybody who receives mail via mail boxes at post offices gets a ballot in their mail box at that post office when it does not know which mail box belongs to which person? Of course, you are not.

I am saying that the government is proposing, on the run, a system whereby people vote according to their postal address, but it has not required the information from voters to ensure that they will receive that mail where they normally get it. If you send out the voting slip to residential addresses, there are going to be tens of thousands of situations where the mail just does not get there. You will have a huge pile of RTS back in the Electoral Office because the postie had nowhere to put the mail, because either they do not go to that residential address or there is no mailbox there to receive it when they get there. If you have lived in the bush you will know what I mean. If you have lived in new residential areas around cities you will know what I mean. If you have ever wondered why people have mailboxes at post offices you will know what I mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —The questions that are being asked by Senator Brown are predicated on the likelihood or the possibility of the government's proposal being accepted. The amendments that are currently before the chair would mean that the government's proposals would not be accepted, and may I offer assistance to the committee by indicating that I am supporting the amendments.

—I thank Senator Harradine for that. I just hope that the members of the other house, the House of Representatives, read some of the justification for the Senate, if it so deems, turning down this government proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to prolong this, and I thought the line of questioning was quite to the point, though it had to be stretched out a bit.

SPEECH.PARA: The other two issues which need to be noted by the House of Representatives are to do with the question of compulsion. If you have compulsory postal voting, you have two possibilities. The first is that, on Senator Brown's example, substantial numbers of persons who should have received postal ballots will not. They could therefore claim that they could not be subject to compulsion or, alternatively, that they were deliberately excluded from an election to which they should have been allowed access. I can see you would have the prospects of High Court challenges as to the validity of the outcome of such an election where persons do not receive the postal voting ballots and are excluded one way or the other.

BREAK.PARA: The second aspect is that of enforceability. It is very difficult, where a substantial number of persons claim that they never received the postal ballot, to then fine them or attempt to discipline them in some way for failing to obey the dictate of compulsion. Those are the other two points I would make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make the point that the Electoral Commission does send out acknowledgment cards to everybody's residential address, so there is already a means of communication with people. If they choose not to have any material received at their residential address, if they do not wish to receive mail from anybody ever and they have not indicated a postal address—I do not know how many Australians are in that category; I am not going to accept Senator Brown's assertions to that effect—it is quite an extraordinary position to be in.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is the case that we will be advertising, prior to the close of the rolls, the fact that this is a postal ballot and that, if you are on the roll and you do not want to receive material at your residential address, you need to update your postal address. We will be putting a lot of emphasis on that to ensure that Australians have the opportunity to correct their postal address or give a postal address if they want one. Further, if they do not receive any postal ballot material because they come within Senator Brown's case—that it cannot be delivered—they can obtain that material from the Electoral Commission. So we will be taking a lot of measures, a lot of steps, to overcome the problems to which he points.

TALK.START.PARA: —A point has been conceded by the government. It is going to be left to the electors to be responsible, basically, to make sure they get a postal ballot, and that just won't do.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells having been rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether you could inform the committee whether there is a pair for Senator Colston?
—I cannot inform the chamber of that; it is no business of the chair.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Clause 65, page 36 (lines 20 to 25), omit the clause, substitute:
(1) The Electoral Commissioner must cause copies of the pamphlet of candidate statements to be sent, by post or other means to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the office of each DRO; and
(b) each office, whether in a parliamentary building or otherwise, of every Member of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory Parliament; and
(c) every public library in Australia; and
(d) every post office in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Electoral Commissioner must cause such numbers of copies of the pamphlet of candidate statements as the Electoral Commissioner considers appropriate to be sent to any person or organisation who asks the AEC or a DRO for a copy of copies of the pamphlet.

We are dealing with clause 65 and opposition amendment No. 24, Democrats amendment No. 19 and Greens amendment No. 26. Democrats amendment 19 and Greens amendment 26 are identical. The opposition have kindly indicated to me that they would prefer that I led. This clause relates to the issue of candidate statements. We believe that, given the unique nature of this election, candidate statements should be made available to voters as there may be so many groups and individuals that will run on a republican or monarchist ticket, or individually, without identifying their position in detail. That is a feature of this election.

One of the true statements that Senator Minchin has made is that this is not a typical election. This is an election where bodies which do not normally participate will be participating, and their policies and positions will not be clearly identified. Many voters in a normal election attach an automatic significance to the title `Democrat', `Liberal', `Labor', `National' or `Green'. In this situation, they are likely to need more guidance. Therefore, voters need to be able to assess the arguments the candidates are putting forward and judge which accords most closely with their own view. As there is no public funding in this election, we believe the AEC should take responsibility for distribution and printing.

Our amendment differs with the ALP amendment, which is why they have deferred to us in this instance, in that it adds paragraph (d), re availability in post offices, a place which is more often frequented—although some of us wish it was not so—than public libraries or divisional returning offices. We think this improves the position. I commend my amendment to the chamber accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment really is consequential upon the Senate's insistence that we spend up to another $20 million on this election to make it a compulsory attendance ballot. The government had provided in its legislation for candidate statements to be received from candidates and to be printed in a booklet so that, in our system, every single Australian elector would receive in the mail, with their ballot material, statements from all the candidates indicating their positions on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, because the Senate is insisting it be a compulsory attendance ballot, that will not be possible, because they will not be receiving anything in the mail. This is partly the farcical situation in which we now find ourselves. So opposition parties have had to scramble together and put in an amendment to try to overcome that situation, to ensure that there is some access to information. Of course, it will not be as good a mechanism as our system for getting information to candidates, which would have ensured that every single Australian elector received information about candidates—in an election which is unique and will be different—and about issues they have not faced before.

Now we have a situation where that will not be possible and people are going to have to run off to post offices or libraries or something. Senator Brown complained that what we are proposing puts the onus on the elector. This puts a huge onus on electors to find out something about the candidates they are going to vote for. They have to go to libraries or post offices, or somewhere, to find out who on earth are all these candidates, whom they have never heard of. This is part of the stupidity of what the Senate has now done. The government's attitude is that these amendments are all really connected with amendments designed to make it an attendance ballot, to which we are opposed. Therefore, we oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We support these amendments. We do not think this is an act of stupidity. We think this is an act to supplement the normal election process. It is an act that appeals to us because it gives another avenue of information to electors, an avenue which otherwise would not be there in the conduct of an ordinary ballot.

SPEECH.PARA: There are suggestions that we should provide resources, through public funding, to ensure that the information gets out through the organisations that will be running candidates. But we have decided not to support that concept in the context of this legislation. So, in the absence of making the demand on government for public funding for this election, we think that this is, in essence, the least we could do to ensure public dissemination of information.

It is a very inexpensive approach that has been proposed by the Democrats. It is one that will provide people with another avenue of receiving information over and above avenues available to them through the media and avenues available to them through the propagation of information by candidates and their groups. Particularly in the context of not supporting public funding for this proposal, we think that this is a very cost‐effective approach and one that should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Minchin that this really is an amendment consequential upon what the Senate has already done. I suppose to vote against it would mean that clause 65 would stand. Clause 65 is clearly written to complement the government's voluntary polling proposal, which has been defeated by the Senate. As it is consequential upon what we have already done, I will be supporting the amendment.

PARA.TAB: (1A) Where, according to the most recent Census of Population and Housing taken by the Australian Statistician, at least 5% of the adults resident in a statistical local area have a common first language other than English, candidates or groups of candidates may include in their group or candidate statement a translation in that language of the information provided in the statement in English.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are to do with the information coming from candidates which is to be distributed to electors so that they will know how the candidates stand and the arguments of each candidate in putting themselves forward to represent people at the Constitutional Convention.

We believe that the restriction on the number of words to be included in information booklets is too tight. It is very difficult to have a group of candidates sum up in 50 words what their position is on the constitution and the need for change—and indeed on having an Australian as head of state. We want to increase the number of words available from 50 words for the group and 25 per individual candidate to 150 for the group and 50 per candidate. That is still very restrictive on the ability of candidates to account for themselves in putting themselves forward to the electorate.

Remember, we are going to have candidates here putting themselves before the people, with very little opportunity, except in this booklet going out to voters, to be able to say where they stand. We can expect that voters are going to read that booklet very carefully and they are going to weigh up on the basis of just 50 words per candidate, even if this amendment succeeds, whether or not they are going to vote for that person. Twenty‐five words is totally inadequate. Fifty words is inadequate but at least it gives some opportunity for people to say a little about why she or he is standing and what they stand for.

It also gives the opportunity for people whose first language is not English to understand what the candidates stand for, because there is provision here that, in districts where statistically more than five per cent of the people speak as their first language a language other than English, the candidates' words will be translated into that language for that area. So, if people have as their first language Japanese, Vietnamese, Italian, Spanish, Greek or whatever, they will be able to read, in their own first language, before they go to vote, what the candidates are saying to them.

It is very important in this multicultural society that we provide for those people, at least in those areas where five per cent of people have a language other than English as their first language, to enable them to understand the case being put by candidates every bit as clearly as for the other 95 per cent of the electorate who have English as their first language. SPEECH.PARA: It may be appropriate at this point to put the government's position in relation to the Senate style voting system which we have proposed and to which there are a couple of amendments—government amendment No. 3 is one of them. We understand that the opposition parties want the electoral system to be purely as it is for the Senate. The government approached this question in good faith, believing that would be the case, prima facie. When we decided that it would be a Senate style election, we moved into the area on the basis that we would have an actual Senate system, with a ballot paper and a system exactly the same as the one the Senate operates. It soon became apparent, after a thorough discussion with the Electoral Commission and an examination of what was likely to occur in such a ballot, that that was going to prove to be highly impractical—and probably impossible.

In a half Senate election, which is our norm, where you have six candidates up—and four or five of them are probably pre‐ordained—and there are existing and traditional parties contesting those elections, it is a recognised and familiar format. Even in a double dissolution, you have only 12 in every state. In this situation, our proposition—and you might want to increase it—was to have 20 positions available in New South Wales, 16 in Victoria and 13 in Queensland. So all those states would have more delegates' positions available than in a double dissolution Senate election. You also have a situation where you are not asking people to commit six years of their lives to this chamber; you are asking them to set aside 10 days in December—Senator Faulkner has already indicated to me that he is not all that enthusi astic about that, and I am sure there are others in that boat.

This is a completely different situation from a Senate election. There could well be many hundreds of Australians who decide, in the circumstances, that they wish to nominate for election to attend what will be a unique event—a 10‐day convention to discuss, along with state, federal and territory parliamentarians, the question of whether or not Australia becomes a republic.

We had to work as a government on the basis of a worst case scenario. In New South Wales, where we would all agree this issue is discussed and debated more than anywhere else—there is a lot more interest in this issue in New South Wales and you have 20 positions available—it is reasonable for us to assert that there could well be 400 or 500 candidates wishing to present themselves for election in a method of election that is meant to be based on the Senate.

In those circumstances, the Electoral Commission convinced us—we came to this on the basis that there would be an election exactly the same as the Senate—that that would practically be impossible, and it would lead to a ballot paper the size of which we had never seen before as to be almost unworkable and a list of candidates the like of which we had never seen before. You would all recall the sort of ridicule that was heaped upon the ACT when it had its first Hare-Clark election and the size of its ballot paper. I think this could leave that in the shade.

It was also evident that if you followed the Senate system exactly, you could be spending two months or more before you knew who had actually been elected. Our plan was for the Constitutional Convention to be sitting in December. In the time frame that we have available to us, that, again, would be an impossible situation. We would all look silly if, on the first day of the convention, we had not yet had a declaration of who was elected to it.

On the advice of the Electoral Commission, we then said, `How can we make it most like a Senate election but do something slightly different to accommodate those difficulties?' On the advice of the commission, we came up with the system that we have. There was some inclination in our party to say, `Let's just make it one‐in‐the‐box.' I think it was a Labor initiative to bring in one‐in‐the‐box voting, and 95 per cent of people do vote one‐in‐the‐box. It was discussed internally. We said that we could solve this problem by having one‐in‐the‐box voting, as 95 per cent of people now do for the Senate.

A consensus was reached within the government that we ought to give people the opportunity to vote `below the line' and to indicate their own order of preferences. That is why we came up with this system of boxes below the line. If voters did not wish to vote one‐in‐the‐box above the line, either for the group or candidate of their choice and have their preferences distributed according to the registered how‐to‐vote cards of the group or candidate, they could vote below the line by putting their preferences in boxes below the line.

To enable voters to do that sensibly and in a way that could be counted by the Electoral Commission, we decided that every candidate who nominated would have a discrete number. This is in the context of postal voting, where they would have plenty of time. All the elector has to do is determine the order of candidates they want—they do not have to vote for all of them; it can be any number of candidates they like, option or preferential, but in New South Wales it is up to 20—and they could put the 20 candidates of their choice in the order of their choice in the boxes below the line.

It did seem to us to be a reasonable compromise. We endorsed the Senate system as it is for Senate elections. I think we all support that. It was just our view, based on Electoral Commission advice, that that was simply not going to work in this case in the unique situation we have before us. Therefore, we have proposed the system that we put before you. I counsel you to think carefully about it and the practicality of having a normal Senate election in these circumstances based on what I have alluded to.

Government amendment No. 3 takes on board the recommendation of the Senate committee—I think motivated by a recom mendation of Malcolm Mackerras—that in the smaller states we have a minimum number of boxes. I think it is up to nine boxes, which is the number of boxes in Western Australia, so that South Australia, Tasmania and the territories do have that number of boxes. So if they want to indicate more preferences than the seats available from those states, they can do so. We have no objection to that. Therefore, we have taken on board that Senate committee recommendation in the context of the Senate‐style voting system we have proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do appreciate that explanation from Senator Minchin. I say to Senator Minchin, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that a small part of it makes some sense. I would see in this particular proposal of the government—in effect, in those states and territories where fewer than nine delegates are to be elected to the convention—a capacity for voters to choose candidates of their choice up to a number of nine candidates. I say through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to Senator Minchin, that I acknowledge that it is a small improvement on a very poor voting system. I do acknowledge that. It means, effectively, that, in those states and territories where there are fewer than nine delegates to be elected, there is more choice for voters. This is one of the very serious concerns that the opposition has with what the government is proposing.

SPEECH.PARA: What we effectively have before us now is a debate about a completely new ballot paper in the Australian political system. This will be a ballot paper that Australians simply are not used to. It is described by Senator Minchin as a Senate style ballot paper. Apart from the fact that it has a thick black line on the ballot paper, it bears no resemblance to a Senate ballot paper and it certainly bears little resemblance to a Senate voting system.

The real concern with this—I would like those senators who are considering their vote on this particular matter to take what I say in relation to below‐the‐line voting into consideration—is that this is extraordinarily complex. It is going to be very hard work for enrolled voters to make a formal ballot if you decide to take the option that many Australian electors do to vote for a number of candidates of your choice.

You have to place the candidate number of your preferred candidate into the first preference box; and you find that number in the guide to the Constitutional Convention election booklet. In this case, one assumes that they will not already have it, but it will be available—correct me if I am wrong, Senator Minchin—to electors either in booklet form or poster. You then have to get the number next to your preferred candidate name and insert that number in a box on the ballot paper. Then, if you want to extend your vote, you find the next candidate of your choice, you find the candidate number next to that candidate's name and you put that in the box.

It looks less complex, I suppose, on this mock‐up ballot paper. I appreciate that we have received these from the Australian Electoral Commission. It does not look so complex when you get to the state of Tasmania, but when you start to look at the mock‐up ballot paper for the state of New South Wales you can see what an extraordinary task this is. In the state of New South Wales you may choose to vote for 20 individual candidates in order of your preference. That means on 20 occasions you have to go to a group voting ticket or to a small booklet, find numbers next to candidates' names and insert those numbers on the ballot paper.

This is a voting system that is foreign to all Australians. It is something that Australians have never had to do in a ballot of any form at any time in our history. It is extraordinarily complex and I really do think that one can only come to the conclusion—I hope it is not an accurate conclusion, but it is very hard to come to any other conclusion—that the government is trying to make this as difficult as possible for people to cast a formal vote. Of course, in all states and territories, if you wish to vote for candidates of your choice—below the line—we have a situation for, again, the first time in our federal electoral history, whether it be at a Commonwealth election, a plebiscite or a federal referendum, of optional preferential voting.

BREAK.PARA: So it is a massive change to our voting system and something that will be foreign to everyone, even though I know the Electoral Commissioner said in evidence, `Some Australians will be used to it because it is a bit like filling out a betting slip at the TAB.' Some Australians do not fill out betting slips at the TAB.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some have got phone accounts.

—I did not realise you had a phone account, Senator Harradine. Good luck to you. If you have a phone account, you would be better off than voters here because there is no suggestion that we are going to have a hotline funded for electors to be able to receive this sort of information in this ballot. Filling out a ballot paper like this, with a complex, completely untried and completely new voting system, will be harder than backing winners at Randwick, and all Australians will have to fill it out.

BREAK.PARA: Above the line there is a capacity for group voting in the sense that you can vote for the lodged voting ticket of groups or ungrouped candidates, as Senator Minchin has correctly indicated. But again, it is a very different ballot paper design from the Senate ballot paper which Australians are used to. I really think in this situation what governments and parliaments have a responsibility to do is to try to ensure that our electoral process is as reasonably accessible and simple as possible. There is no advantage to anyone in making this a complex exercise to cast a formal vote.

That is the concern I have with Senator Minchin's amendment, but I want to come back to where I started my contribution and say this to Senator Minchin. If, indeed, you are successful in your other amendments, and your preferred voting system and ballot paper design is the will of the Senate and the parliament, then I certainly would accept that the amendment that is before the chair at the moment is a small improvement on the government's proposed ballot paper layout. I hope, Senator Minchin, you take my comments in the spirit in which they are intended. They are a small improvement because it does allow people in those states and territories where there are fewer than nine delegates to have more options in extending their vote.

I acknowledge that but I say very clearly to the Senate that it is only a small improvement on what I believe is a totally inappropriate, totally inadequate, ludicrously complex ballot paper layout and voting system, and it is for those reasons that the opposition will not be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Minchin on behalf of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to speak generally to the amendments before us which relate to the conduct of a Senate style voting system. We are all aware, of course, that our Senate style voting system is an open access one. In other words, the number of candidates who get nominated and accepted by the AEC and pay their nomination fee can, in theory, overwhelm our system, but do not. So some of the bogies that we put up may not be true.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendments relate to the implementation of provisions for the conduct of a Senate style ballot at the election. We prefer, as we have said before, to keep this election as close as possible to that which Australians are familiar with. I think we should accept and recognise that at every election and between elections the AEC does in fact spend substantial sums of money in trying to educate, inform and develop Australians' understanding of the voting system. In that respect, we should not attempt to change the voting system in a way which would undo the value of all those years and dollars in educating Australians.

This election to decide on the shape of Australia's future and its relationship with the world—of all elections, in our view—needs to be consistent with other elections that have been held federally. We agree with the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). The ballot paper and the system of voting proposed is very confusing and we believe that that will result in people being turned off by the complexity. We do not accept the government's argument—at least in relation to New South Wales, not necessarily in relation to the other states—that there will be so many candidates the ballot paper will be a metre square.

BREAK.PARA: We believe it is essential that all candidates' names appear on the ballot paper so that people have before them the names of those they will be voting for. I indicate to you, Senator Minchin, that, like the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, we do think your amendment No. 3 is an advance on your previous position. However, in the event of the identical amendments of the opposition, Australian Democrats and Greens getting up, amendment No. 3 should fall away. I suggest that we deal with those amendments prior to amendment No. 3, otherwise the debate will be aboutface.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk generally about what we have proposed. I hope you accept our bona fides when we say that it was not out of some desire to experiment with the electoral system that we proposed this. It was a desire to have something that would actually work. We are a practical, pragmatic government. We are not proposing any changes to the electoral system as such or to the way in which the Senate is elected. We have operated on the advice of the Electoral Commission. You will note from their public comments and the evidence before the Senate committee that the only two independent electoral experts to have engaged in this debate—Malcolm Mackerras and the electoral reform society—both, in principle, endorsed this approach and commended the government on it.

I do think, frankly, that it is a little patronising to say to Australians that they are too stupid to work out the electoral system we have proposed. I am not going to get unduly rhetorical about that, but I do think it is a little demeaning of the Australian people to suggest that they are incapable of filling in 20 squares. Anyone who does not want to do that of course has the option of putting the No. 1 in the box above the line. As we know in the Senate, 95 per cent of voters do that. If they do not want to fill in the boxes, they can do that. But to suggest that we should not do this because Australians are too stupid to be able to fill it in below the line is a bit unfortunate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that they're not used to it. You'd have to acknowledge that. They're not used to it.

—I think you suggested that they would not be able to cope with it. We will not go on with that debate. Given that we are flashing ballot papers, we have prepared a Senate style ballot paper based on the existing Senate system. This ballot paper is for New South Wales and has only 300 candidates—I think there could well be 500—and this is a reasonably significant ballot paper. So, if you think you have problems with that one, have a look at this one. I commend to the Senate this amendment and the Senate style voting system, which we think is practical, sensible and workable in the context of an election for delegates to the Constitutional Convention.

The paper he presents to us with 300 names is barely twice bigger than the paper with 140 names prepared for us by the Electoral Commission. I do not know what point he is trying to make, other than the fact that more and more we come back to the point of wondering why we have embarked upon this exercise and why we did not have a plebiscite to get the will of the Australian people.

As Senator Minchin says, it might be that big under us but it will be substantially the same size, on the basis of the information prepared for us by the Electoral Commission, if the government's proposed postal ballot were to take place. We could have all embarked upon a nation building course of origami to work out how to fit them all back in the envelopes. We would have had that problem facing us as a nation.
