We have had a substantive debate on this issue regarding government amendment No. 3, but I would like to respond to the suggestion that Senator Minchin made in his contribution—an unfortunate comment, I thought—when he indicated that I had put the view that I did not have adequate faith in Australian electors to be able to fight their way through what is an extraordinarily complex ballot system. That is an unreasonable comment for Senator Minchin to make, and I think he probably understands that it was not the force of my comments at all.

What I was saying is that this is a voting system of which no Australian has had any experience. I do not think even Senator Minchin could argue against that. It is new. It is untried. It is complex. It is difficult. That is not in any sense a put‐down of those Australians who have demonstrated in very many federal elections over very many years a capacity to cast formal ballots, but most governments have approached electoral law in the spirit that we ought to make voting as easy and as accessible as possible.

Until now most major political parties have approached the Commonwealth electoral law in that spirit. I am doubtful that that same spirit is afoot in the government in relation to the Constitutional Convention. I do not resile from that. I do not resile from the fact that I believe that this is a politically motivated exercise. Voting is being made as hard as possible. This is a new system that happens to, in the view of some Liberal Party apparatchiks, suit the Liberal Party; that is, a voluntary postal ballot. This is all foreign to Australians, who do have a tradition of taking seriously the exercise of their civic responsibility of voting.

That is the point that needs to be made. What Senator Minchin is proposing here is not the Australian way of voting. It is not the Australian way that ballot papers have been designed and developed. It is not what Australians are used to. I am sure that is going to cause a very significant amount of confusion in the electorate, particularly when the government is doing nothing to assist those people who might require information and help with voting. That is the point I am trying to make.

I do not accept any comment that the parliamentary secretary might make suggesting that this is a put-down of Australian electors. It is not a put-down. We in this place have a responsibility to assist Australians to cast a formal ballot, to make this process relevant. One way we do that is by ensuring that we do not have an incredibly cumbersome ballot paper which is part of a voting system that no Australian has any familiarity with. That is, in my view, a very retrograde and irresponsible step. That is the spirit of the comments that I made. Senator Minchin probably knows that, and I think he only tries to make a crass political point opportunistically in this debate, and I will not let it go without remarking on it.

The reality is that what we are about is ensuring that we have a voting system, ballot papers, for this Constitutional Convention that Australians have knowledge of and familiarity with and that we have a ballot that is in the tried and true Australian mould. What Senator Minchin is putting up, as I have said before, is not the way we do things in this country. I might be being unfair to Senator Minchin, although I do not think so, when I say he and some other apparatchiks from the Liberal Party machine—of course, I am one of those who admire people who have come from the machines of political parties, and I accept that they make a very positive contribution to parliament‐ I had better say this because I would be in trouble if I did not.

Senator Minchin brings great expertise in this area, great expertise to the parliament, and this could benefit the parliament, I am sure, if it were applied in a proper and positive way. It is not. It is being applied from someone who is being partisan and politically opportunistic. Those opposite are not well motivated in this. This is a Liberal Party scam, and it is disappointing to see this convention and its voting procedures being used as the thin end of the wedge for the obsession of some in relation to voluntary voting and changing our electoral system.

We want to make it accessible to all Australians. We have always understood the importance of our electoral system. We have always embraced compulsory attendance ballots because it is the Australian way of doing things. We have always considered it a civic obligation, an obligation of Australian citizens, to vote in elections, and it is in that spirit that I made the comments I did. So let the record stand corrected.

SPEECH.PARA: I also move amendment 10. These amendments would pave the way for the constitutional convention delegates to be fully elected. The Greens maintain that this is a people's convention and it ought to be fully elected by the people. We are opposed to the government and parliaments appointing delegates. We think that the people should be fully in control of this convention to determine whether or not we will have a republic and what sort of republic it will be. It is as simple as that. I put it to the committee, particularly to opposition senators, that they support this amendment and make this a real people's convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —This would have been our preferred position, but we recognise that the government have a degree of authority to pursue their model in this particular instance. This is something that they propose and we believe it is a third‐best option, but it is one that we are prepared to accept for the purposes of ensuring that a constitutional convention does go ahead. We feel that the government have put the case forward for a half‐elected, half‐appointed convention. We are concerned at the way the appointment process has proceeded so far and we will get to that in subsequent clauses. At this stage, it is probably a bit late to be insisting on a fully elected convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have considerable sympathy with the proposition put by Senator Brown. However, we think that the time frame and the processes that we are in have gone too far—that the process of appointing delegates, advising them and progressing it is too far advanced. Right from the start, our preference was for a fully elected convention. However, that is not to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I must acknowledge some of the sense of the government's argument in making appointments in that they have recognised the reality of election processes to date. It does not mean that those election processes would not change in forthcoming elections. But the fact is that, to date, women have not been properly represented in our parliaments, indigenous people are not properly represented in our parliaments, ethnic people are not properly represented in our parliaments and neither are young people. On the current statistics of the federal parliament, without appointments there would be only 20 per cent or less women, no Aboriginal people and no‐one between the ages of 18 and 25. I am aware from what the government have said that they intend to redress that situation through the appointments process—and I welcome that. I think that is a useful advance.

It is possible, Senator Brown, that the election might well have thrown up a better balance but history, unfortunately, has not yet shown that. Hopefully, Australia will progress a little better in those areas. We are referring here to amendments 1, 3 and 10. We will oppose all three. Amendment 10 refers to the fact that federal and state parliamentarians are not eligible to stand for election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that it would be better if amendments 1 and 3 were taken together. Amendment 10 should be taken separately because the effect of it is that clause 24 stand as printed. If it would help the processes of the committee, we will deal only with amendments 1 and 3 now.
—Thank you for your guidance. I therefore advise the committee that, regrettably, we must oppose amendments 1 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government joins with Senator Murray and the opposition in opposing these amendments. I appreciate the tone of the remarks by Senator Murray. The government believes it is appropriate that the convention be half‐appointed and half‐elected. We went to the last election with that as our promise as to the constitution of the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a mandate for it and for a very good reason. As Senator Murray has explained, the fact is, regrettably, that Australian elections do not produce outcomes that adequately and properly reflect the composition of the Australian population in relation to women, Aborigines and young people in particular. We believe that there should be a component of delegates appointed to the convention to ensure adequate representation of those groups. We also believe that parliamentarians should be involved. One of the beauties of the model which we have proposed is that we will have elected community delegates, parliamentarians and particular appointed delegates to take account of certain groups which are not adequately represented in the electoral process, so that together we can discuss this very important question of whether or not Australia should become a republic.

We are committed to eight of the 36 appointed delegates being between 18 and 25 years old—that is just over 10 per cent of the 76 appointed delegates—as well as to ad equate representation from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders; and as close to fifty‐fifty as we can get representation between males and females among those 36 appointments. On behalf of the government, I therefore reject Senator Brown's proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fifty‐fifty component of the delegates, but the component that is coming out of the parliaments, including this parliament, is going to reflect the gender gap that there is in terms of the numbers already in parliament. In other words, the parliamentary delegates mainly are going to be male. I would prefer to leave it in the hands of the people. I think they would come up with a better combination. I think we are more likely to have women better represented if it is left in the hands of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray implied that we can do better by allowing the people full rein on the vote. I do not think we can do that. However, we could debate that all night. I simply put it again to the committee—and it seems that the Greens are alone in this—that this is a people's convention and it ought to have the people voting in all the delegates to the convention. Politicians could take part in the vote and we would get a better mix that way than we would get through this appointment system.

Clause 24 agreed to.

—It removes the prohibition on members of parliament being elected. If you had a fully elected set of delegates going to the convention, it would mean members of parliament would stand.
—I am sorry, I did not realise that. I was waiting for the government's response to that.

—Initially it was partly my fault, Senator Harradine, but it was not only my fault. The committee made the decision that we would accept Greens amendments 1, 3 and 10 together. But it was evident in the course of the discussion and the debate that there were going to be different decisions for amendment Nos 1 and 3 from those for No. 10. That is, in effect, what happened. The result of amendment No. 10, moved by Senator Brown, is that it was defeated. The question was asked that clause 24 stand as printed, and the committee has agreed to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition amendment No. 2 is to delete clause 6 of the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill. I suggest that we take this in conjunction with opposition amendment No. 82. Clause 6 provides for the purpose of the act, and we think it is a pretty bare reference to what the purpose of this legislation is. As a consequence, we do not think it is adequate.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, what we will be doing is opposing the purpose of the act as it now stands. With our amendment 82, we will be moving that a preamble be put into the legislation, to go in straight after the opening paragraph on page 1 of the legislation and before the words `the Parliament of Australia enacts'. That preamble is geared towards looking at the purpose of the legislation. The preamble says:
This Act provides the necessary framework for the election and appointment of delegates to a Constitutional Convention . . .
It details that the convention will provide a forum for debate about whether the present constitution should be changed and what republican models should be put to the voters, and so on.

As importantly, as part of this preamble we recognise the fact that, for this Constitutional Convention to be successful, it needs to reflect the diverse experiences, backgrounds, views, beliefs and aspirations of the Australian people. The clause goes on to read:

To that end, the appointment of non‐parliamentary delegates to the Convention should reflect the diversity of our nation. Furthermore, it is to be hoped that all groups standing for election to the Convention will draw upon our diversity when nominating candidates. In particular, and in light of the fact that the Constitutional Conventions of the 1890s which led to Federation were composed entirely of male delegates, it is to be hoped that all groupings will provide for the fair and equal representation of women.
We find that this particular clause is geared towards reflecting diversity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have a point of order. I do not think that we have been asked to approve that opposition amendments 2 and 82 go together. I note that Senator Bolkus is talking to them. I do not agree that amendments 2 and 82 should be heard together.

—I rule in favour of the point of order.

—I will rephrase what I have said. As to amendment No. 2, we think a more inclusive preamble is probably the best way to go. We do not propose the deletion of clause 6 in a vacuum; we do so in the context of our further amendment 82. I take the point that that amendment refers to an expanded role for this legislation and, as such, maybe it should be considered later on.
—I rise to indicate that the Australian Democrats will be supporting our position on amendment No. 2.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government proposes that clause 6 stand as printed. This legislation only deals, as it should, with the election of delegates. It is the prerogative of the government, as the elected government of Australia, to determine the appointments in proper consultation with all community groups, and with the opposition. From our point of view, this bill should deal with only the election of delegates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is complex and difficult, but we are dealing with a situation that is a little bit out of context. If this amendment stays, I think that some of the other amendments that are proposed by the opposition could live with it. By and large, we are talking about the appointment of delegates. I would have been rather inclined to think that all persons who attend the Constitutional Convention should be there because of a decision taken by either electors directly or persons whom electors have directly voted into the parliament. I suppose that the government can argue that government appointees would be in this position.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another amendment by the opposition that these appointments should be made by a committee of the parliament. I assume that the opposition is going to proceed on that line. This would be in the minds of the opposition when proposing that clause 6 of the bill be deleted. However, I think that that has gone a bit too far now, hasn't it? Maybe the minister could indicate to the committee whether or not invitations already have been issued to a number of people to consider appointment as delegates to the convention.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, consistent with government policy, which was that 36 Australians would be appointed to the convention, the Prime Minister announced earlier this week that we have, in fact, already written to 36 Australians inviting them to be non‐parliamentary appointed delegates. That has not been finalised; we have to hear back from them. There will be some, obviously, who will be unable to attend and we will have to find alternatives to them. But that process has already commenced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is right: we do have an amendment later on to ensure that a joint parliamentary committee, a committee representing all sides of parliament, has the authority to select or appoint those delegates to be appointed. Those amendments have been floated for some time. The government knew that they would be coming up before us today and they have known that for some time. I think the government's decision to invite people this week in the face of the deliberations of this parliament is an act that not only is provocative but also defeats the spirit of bipartisanship which is quite critical in this sort of process.

SPEECH.PARA: We have bent over backwards to try to accommodate the government in respect of a lot of these proposals. I would have thought it more appropriate for the government to defer such appointments until the parliament and the Senate had decided how to proceed with this. Senator Harradine quite rightly puts it that, in the absence of direct election by the people, the process of election by the representatives of the people is a mechanism that we should have used.

We do not know how people were selected. We have not been given criteria. We do not know who selected them. We do not know whose officers were involved. We do not know whether they were political operatives who selected them. We do know that 850 people self‐nominated. We do know that, on top of that, organisations such as the opposition and others in this place had the capacity also to nominate people. So how, out of 850‐plus nominations, has the government chosen 36? Why did it do so at a time when this process was about to be debated? Why has it done so in flagrant disregard for the democratic processes of this place?

We are asked, at the moment, to endorse the government's actions. Yet there is no indication from the parliamentary secretary that we will be told who was asked. We have no idea as to who has been asked to take up a position as an appointed delegate. These are acts that go very much to the heart of destabilising any bipartisan approach that should have been available to us. I think that there is still a need for that process to be embarked upon and for this parliament to set up a joint parliamentary committee not just to determine the rules and not just to, for instance, determine who should chair and give authority to Mr Sinclair and maybe Mr Barry Jones, but also to have a look at how the delegates should be appointed.

Senator Minchin, you are asking us to sign not just one blank cheque but a whole blank chequebook. You are asking us to give approval to a process of selection about which we have been given no criteria, about which we do not know who was involved and a process which goes very much to the heart of people's representation. I am not happy with it. Let us see how this discussion evolves but I still think there is a need, particularly in the absence of critical information, for the parliament to assert its authority and to say, `Some of these letters might have gone out but we will put people on notice that we also, as a parliament, need to get together to try and come up with a bipartisan selection process.'
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Carr)—by leave—agreed to:
That consideration of government business order of the day no. 1 (Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997) take precedence over consideration of government documents today.
Motion (by Senator Campbell)—by leave—agreed to:
That on Thursday, 19 June—
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 9.30am to 6.30 pm and 7.30 to 11.10 pm.
(b) the routine of business from not later than 7.30 pm shall be government business only; and
(c) the question for the adjournment shall be proposed at 10.30 pm.
Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —With great respect to Senator Bolkus, the government is not seeking the approval of the opposition for the appointments. It is a matter of government policy. We have a convention to which half the delegates will be elected and half appointed by the government. It does not require a legislative base for us to hold a convention to which we appoint some delegates. I recall Labor holding plenty of summits of various kinds to which it appointed delegates and members. That is the procedure we have undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been under considerable pressure, quite properly, from republicans and constitutional monarchists to announce the appointed delegates as far before the close of nominations for election as we can in order that people can have a reasonable time to decide whether they contest the election based on the appointments. In endeavouring to meet the expectations of both the republican and the monarchist organisations we have had to do what we have done in relation to the invitations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, in opposition to this, the intention is to remove the purposes clause. The purposes clause at this moment says the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Act is to provide for elections of delegates from each State and Territory to the Constitutional Convention. As well as delegates who are elected, there will also be delegates to the Convention who are appointed delegates. The Act does not deal with the appointment of delegates.

In the world of parliamentary drafting, that is not going to set the world alight. It is pretty well a nothing clause. I would indicate—and I will not speak for the other parties who have their purposes clause up—that we have at amendment No. 63 a proposal to replace that purposes clause with something more meaningful. The point I wish to make with regard to this issue of appointments or not—and delegates and how far the government is down the road—is that our purposes clause does not interfere with that process, simply because we feel it has gone too far and we should not interfere with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Murray pointed out, and he has read the particular clause, the problem that I have, and probably the committee as a whole has had, is that nothing should be done which would give an undue reason for this measure to be pulped and the convention not to take place, given the statements that have been made by both the opposition and the government with respect to these matters. I have a somewhat different view but, if you have this legislation, and you have indicated that there is some authority that the government has to pursue this particular approach—that is, for there to be appointed delegates as well as elected delegates—that ought to be included in the legislation. It is included in clause 6.

BREAK.PARA: The only problem is that, if we ultimately accept the proposal by the opposition that the appointed delegates be appointed by the process, as mentioned in the opposition's proposed amendments, perhaps we would have to agree to a consequential amendment at that particular stage which would take out the last sentence of the clause. So, at this stage, I am voting that the clause be part of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clause 6 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4 (after line 9), after clause 6, insert:
(1) The purpose of the Constitutional Convention is to consider changes to the Constitution that would be necessary for Australia to become a republic.

(2) The Convention may consider any other constitutional matters which a majority of delegates consider are relevant to Australia achieving a fair, environmentally sustainable and democratic republic.

This is an amendment to explicitly state that the convention can determine its own agenda. The legislation we have is basically about how the convention is going to be brought together. It does not state what the convention is going to deliberate upon. We have to assume that that will be a directive from the Prime Minister and that the government is going to have a very strong say—and members opposite shake their heads—in conscribing matters that the convention can deal with. We believe the convention, again, is the people's convention and it should be able to determine not just whether or not we are having a republic but what sort of republic that should be, and all things germane to that in so far as recommendations on the constitution are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The priority constitutional concern for the opposition is to resolve the republic issue. We do not believe other issues should be brought into this. That was our view before the election. It is good to see the government has adopted our view now and is proceeding with a convention for a single purpose as opposed to the whole gamut of issues that it had been discussing beforehand. We do not support the Greens' amendment because of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —In the quaint language which has developed around this whole process, I would probably be described as a `maximalist'. In other words, I do believe that our constitution needs attending to in many fundamental ways, most of which are familiar to all the senators here.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have agreed consistently that to retain the cross-party focus on the republican issue it is very desirable and advisable that this particular convention focus firmly on the minimalist position and just deal with the republican issue. So, although Senator Brown and I agree that there are many other issues that need to be dealt with in the constitution, I do not think that this particular convention is the time and the place. Therefore, regrettably, I must oppose the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is pleased to have the support of the ALP and the Democrats on this issue in that it is our view that the convention should deal only with the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. Therefore, we also oppose the Greens' amendment.
—The amendment has to be seen in light of an

BREAK.PARA: amendment coming down the line very shortly in which the Greens say there ought to be a plebiscite with the election of delegates whereby the Australian people can indicate whether or not they want an Australian to be head of state, whether or not they want a republic. Therefore, we move to the position of the convention determining what sort of republic that should be.

The Greens believe the people should have control of this process. The convention should be based upon an indication from the electorate. I am hearing from the other parties in this place that the people are not up to that at this stage, that we are being a bit previous in thinking that the people's delegates, having been given the go‐ahead at a plebiscite to discuss what sort of republic, will not know how to confine that and to make the best of it. I think they do. I think they will. I think the other parties are being a bit restrictive in this, a bit directive, a bit prohibitive. At the outset, they ought to be supporting the Greens' move to give the people a say by simply ticking a box as to whether or not they want a republic when it comes to the election of delegates in August or September in the lead-up to this convention in about December.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 7, page 4 (lines 10 to 12), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 7 Number of delegates to be elected from each State and Territory

SPEECH.PARA: The number of *delegates to be elected from each State and Territory is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: The driving force for this amendment is not numbers but principle. The principle is based on the convention that has been applied to constitutional reform conventions over the last 20 to 30 years. That convention has been that both sides of parliament, either side of parliament, including minor parties, have fair representation. If we look at conventions in the 1970s and 1980s, we would find, for instance, from state representation, that there would be equal numbers from the government side, the coalition, and opposition side of parliament. If one was to look at the federal parliament's representation at conventions in this period of some 25 to 30 years, the same principle has applied.

It is the principle that has applied for a long time that we now wish to apply here. We think it is appropriate to do so. No case has been put forward to come up with a proposal whereby, for instance, the federal government has an overbearing majority or state governments have a two to one majority over other parties represented, particularly the opposition, in those states.

We think the principle should be maintained. With that driving force, we realised that the only way we could do that was to somehow get the numbers right by ensuring, as a starting point, that state representation went from three to four and that territory representation went from one to two. We felt that to accommodate that there should be a decrease in federal parliamentary representation from 20 to 16 and such representation to accommodate minor parties as well as give government and opposition fair balance. We also felt that we should not decrease the number of nominated appointed delegates by the parliament. To get the numbers right we felt it needed to come up to 80. We felt to abide by the government's imperative of having half elected and half appointed, then the numbers for those to be elected should go from 76 to 80.

The consequential changes reflected in opposition amendment No. 3 are based on the government's formula for working out how many delegates are appropriate from each state. They do reflect the fact that we have gone from 76 to 80 to ensure an equal number are appointed as opposed to elected.

As I say, it is the principle this one seeks to apply here. We need to apply the principle with no unforeseen negative consequences. The only way we could do that was to come up with the formula we have in amendment No. 3.

But I do remind the parliament that we are talking here about constitutional change. In the context of constitutional change, it has always been an imperative that there be fair representation of the parliament. Over that almost 25-year period that I have referred to, that has been recognised by parliaments of all persuasions. Unfortunately, in this particular instance, on such a critical issue, the government once again has sought to play politics. It is this sort of playing of politics that we seek to redress by amendment No. 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, I recognise that you must have had an impossible task balancing tradition, fairness, equity and all the various population characteristics and the mathematics of it all. You have confessed that it is not your strong suit. So I think Labor has given you an out. It is our opinion that Labor's amendment does address some inequities in the bill. For that reason, we believe it is appropriate to support it.

—I have had some difficulty with this particular amendment, but it is, on the face of it, the fairest option. If you look at the numbers of parliamentarians across the country, it does mean that there will be a fairer representation of the major parties. In my home state of Tasmania, I understand that the three delegates who will be appointed by the government will be the Premier, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Greens, Mrs Christine Milne, who, with her three fellow MPs, is in the balance of power in Tasmania. This amendment, if it gets up, will mean that the Leader of the Opposition will be able to appoint another person. That is an anomaly which in some ways may redress the anomaly of the current situation in other states. There is no good way out of that. On balance, the opposition's amendment is fairer than the government's prescription.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this amendment on the very grounds that Senator Bolkus gave in support of it. If we look at precedent with respect to constitutional conventions, the issue clearly is that there has been equality of representation from the states. That is the point that has been forgotten in the argument advanced in this proposition. That was the case in the latest Constitutional Convention, and it was the case in the first Constitutional Convention and the second.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a matter that we as a Senate ought to have regard to. We are not really having regard to it. I am opposed to the government's proposal, but this proposal is worse than theirs. Take my home state, for example. The representation it will receive under the government's proposal is six out of 76 and under Senator Bolkus's proposal it will receive six out of 80. That is downgrading the state of Tasmania's representation on the Constitutional Convention. I am not in favour of that.

As I understand it, what this measure will do is provide, in essence, for New South Wales to get another couple of delegates and Victoria to get another one. New South Wales, under the government's proposal, gets 20 and under Senator Bolkus's proposal gets 22; Victoria, under the government's proposal, gets 16 and under Senator Bolkus's proposal gets 17; Queensland, under the government's proposal, gets 13 and under Senator Bolkus's gets 14; and Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania remain the same. So I will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Harradine to consider this in the context of the fact that the motivating force is to get equal numbers from each side of parliament in the states, moving it from a representation of three to four from each state. If you want to do that but keep the number of delegates to be elected from each state at the same level as before, we can consider that, but our initial and major driving force here is to ensure that we do not have an imbalance in the representation from the state parliaments. We moved from three to four there; as a consequence, we felt that, in order to keep the final balance right in terms of what the government wanted to do and have equal numbers elected and appointed, we should increase the number of elected delegates. It is a difficult one. But the principal driving force here is to get an equal representation from both sides of parliament and equal numbers from each parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the opposition amendment, for reasons along the lines of Senator Harradine's. We did think long and hard about the composition of this—how many and what was workable and what was fair. I note that in the opposition's proposals the four extra delegates all go to the three bigger states so, as a South Australian, I share Senator Harradine's concern about that. But also the division of the state and federal parliamentarians was thought through long and hard, and we believe it is fair and proportional to the nature of the composition of those parliaments. Therefore, we oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 14, page 7 (line 18), omit "7", substitute "21".
(9) Clause 14, page 7 (line 20), omit "7", substitute "21".

We are moving these because we feel that there should be a longer period for people to change their place of enrolment and to enrol. There will not be a habitation review in the lead‐up to this ballot, no matter how the ballot is held, whether it is an attendance ballot or a postal ballot—which it will not be now. It has been two years since the last habitation review, and there could be hundreds of thousands—if not more than a couple of million—of people who will want to register on the roll.

In the lead‐up to this ballot, therefore, we would like to see the Electoral Commission run a habitation review, but I do not think there is time for that. Our second best option is not only to exhort them to ensure that they do as much work as possible to update the rolls but also to give people enough time to enrol. One week is nowhere near enough and, as an alternative, we suggest that a three‐week period be made available between the closing of nominations and the closing of the roll, to ensure that the many people who would not have focused on this election process—and, let us face it, not many people are focusing on it at the moment although they might get stimulated in the next few weeks—have a reasonable opportunity to put their names on the roll, maybe even for the first time, at the right address. That is the motivation behind this amendment, and we think it has merit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of this amendment is to increase from seven to 21 days the time between the calling of an election and the closing of rolls. I understand the argument. However, we have consistently said that we wish to keep this bill as close as we can to federal election practice and process. Section 155 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act provides that the date fixed for the close of rolls shall be seven days after the date of the writ. We will not be supporting the amendment.

—I wonder whether the minister could provide us with any information which would indicate that the proposal by the opposition is unworkable. If it is not unworkable, it is in the interests of democracy and the intentions of the government to agree to the opposition's amendment. I am very much inclined to support the opposition's amendment on this question, unless the minister says straight out that it is technically impossible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In adopting the proposal set out in clause 14, the government has simply incorporated the current provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which provide for a minimum of seven days for the close of the rolls. We have adopted exactly the same arrangements as are currently the case, and we think they are appropriate in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The government announced back in March that there would be an election. Since then it has always been the case that it would be in the August period. Since March, everyone has known that there would be an election. If they want to participate in it, they should get on the roll and get their entry accurate. In the two weeks leading up to that close of rolls, it is intended that there be a lot of activity from the Electoral Commission's point of view, using electronic advertising to tell people that the rolls close. So we think it is appropriate to adopt exactly the same provision as is in the current Electoral Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference is that this election is going to take more people by surprise than the normal election does. The other point about this is that we want to be making sure that those people who are most likely not to be on the rolls but who are qualified to vote have the opportunity to do so. Those people are 18‐year‐olds—the young people. It has already been mentioned that there is going to be some special measure to ensure appointment of young people as delegates to the convention. I support that.

SPEECH.PARA: We ought to be making sure that young people are able to vote and that 18-year-olds have time to get on the rolls. There will be thousands of them who will need to be given that time. There has not been a set date for this convention. The government is talking about December. It could just as easily talk about January or it could talk about November. Within the fluidity of the program that the government has put, I cannot see any good reason why this amendment to give people more time to get on to the rolls cannot be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether we can ask the Democrats to reconsider their position in the light of the fact that, although we are talking about an attendance ballot being endorsed by this parliament, we still have a situation where there has not been, nor will there be, a habitation review. There has not been one since before the election and there will not be one before this ballot, no matter how this ballot takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of a couple of million people moving a year, okay, a lot of them re‐register and change their address but a lot of them may not and, in the context of a quiet lead-up to the election, I wonder whether the Austral ian Democrats could show some flexibility and maybe even look at some sort of compromise proposal of two weeks. I do think a one‐week period is too short.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our original sympathy with Labor for this amendment was on the premise that, if postal voting was proceeded with, it would be appropriate. In terms of what Senator Bolkus has just said, Senator Minchin, could you just outline where we are with habitation reviews and how material such an issue is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, there has not been, as Senator Bolkus says, a full habitation review. The Electoral Commission reminds me that, in expectation of this sort of postal ballot, they have been doing what they call a lot of very targeted activity in relation to the electoral roll to try to update it, in terms of identifying vacant houses and things like that. I do not know that I can list the others right now, but I can assure you that the Electoral Commission has been preparing for this eventuality and undertaking measures of a targeted nature to ensure that it has a roll which is as accurate as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there is a provision in the budget for this exercise of electronic advertising in the two weeks leading up to the close of rolls to ensure that people are alerted to the fact that there is an election. So it is no different from an early election being called in that sense, although we did give notice back in March. This is a lot more notice than you would get for a normal federal election, when you never know when it is going to be. We think it is appropriate.

I remind you that this provision is as it is in the Electoral Act. There is a stipulation that it be a minimum of seven days—we are not saying that it is a maximum—between the announcement and the close of rolls. It cannot be less than a week.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (9) Clause 23, page 11 (line 10), after "18", insert "before the date of the poll".

This amendment ensures that we give the maximum opportunity to 18-year-olds to nominate for a position of delegate to the convention. As things stand, people who turn 18 after nominations actually close but before the election is held, even though they are going to be 18 on election day, will not be able to stand. We believe that they should be able to stand. It might be a small group of 18-year-olds, but we do not believe that they should be precluded from standing. This amendment is to ensure that those folk who are 18 on election day, without exception, are able to stand if they wish to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this amendment. We believe that it is a small step which will allow younger people, who would obviously have a very direct interest in how the constitution is framed in the future, to be able to participate in the process. As a consequence, we support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —While having some sympathy for Senator Brown's position, there has to be a cut-off somewhere. In relation to a nomination process, it is the norm that you meet the nomination qualifications on the date set for nomination. Any date is arbitrary, but we do think, on balance, that our proposition is fair and reasonable—you have to have turned 18 by the date of nomination. Therefore, we oppose that amendment.

—Of course people need to meet the requirements for nomination on nomination day. We are saying, `Let's alter those requirements to ensure that people who turn 18 between nomination day and election day can duly and properly nominate.' It is as simple as that. Let us not exclude anybody who is going to be 18 on election day from nominating by the time nominations close.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand, again, what Senator Brown is doing here and have some sympathy with his view. But our consistent position throughout is that we are going to try to keep this bill as close as we can to federal election processes. The objective in our terms is to maintain consistency with the normal processes for federal and state elections. Our entire rationale over our approach is that this is a meaningful federal election and needs to be run as such. Because this amendment does not conform with the Commonwealth Electoral Act, we will be opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 26, page 12 (after line 27), after subclause (4), insert:
(4A) A nomination must include a statement of the candidate's position in relation to the concept of an Australian republic but may be limited to a statement as to whether the candidate:

PARA.TAB: (a) supports the concept of a republic; or
(b) does not support the concept of a republic; or
(c) is undecided.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is unusual in that it requires an indication from candidates for election as to their position. In this respect this bill is very different from a federal parliamentary election. This election is to be held on a cross-party basis and is essentially about the nature of a republic and an Australian head of state.

If, as in New South Wales, you get large numbers of candidates, both grouped and ungrouped, standing, it may be very difficult for voters to easily and quickly identify where the particular candidates stand in terms of a republic. So what we have asked for is that a nomination must include a statement of the candidate's position in relation to the concept of an Australian republic. It may be limited to a statement as to whether the candidate supports the concept of a republic, does not support the concept of a republic or is undecided. I would be dismayed if anyone stood for election who was undecided. Nevertheless, we need to leave the option for people to say that they have an open mind and to be sent there with an open mind.

I do think it is important that voters are able to easily identify candidates' policies and beliefs, in the broadest sense, without having to deal with all the nuances. I do not think I can put any more gloss on it than that. I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this move. I think it is a good one. You might be surprised, Senator Murray. Senator Minchin will remember a name being drawn out of a hat the other night to determine how to solve the insoluble, that is, the problem of the government appointing a Green to the convention, as against one of the conservative independents. Mr Rocher from the House of Representatives was the person whose name was drawn out and I approached him to find out what his point of view is on this. He certainly fits into the category of undecided. So we are going to have one undecided person going to the convention. Take that as you want. I find that a very peculiar circumstance, but there you are. We are represented by somebody who does not have a point of view, at this stage, as to whether we should be a monarchy or a republic, but who is going to listen and form a point of view as it goes along.

—I would like to believe that too. The opposition thinks this is a useful proposal that has been moved. It is not a normal election period and I think there needs to be some degree of required information for the public on which they can base their assessment. On a single issue such as this I do not think it is unreasonable to ensure that the public is advised on what a particular person's stand is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
