DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent times, many Australians have become shocked, outraged and just generally confused about the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's assertion in its Bringing them home report that Australia has been engaged in genocide. I wish to address that assertion in my remarks this evening, but before embarking upon those comments I want to pay tribute to the tremendous amount of work and hours which the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission spent in providing a vehicle for those affected by the misguided policies of the past in order to give expression to the hurt that was occasioned.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to detract from those cruel policies in any shape or form, but I am somewhat concerned that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission have overstated the case and, as a result, detracted from what is otherwise a very illuminating report. At page 266 we are told:

Genocide was declared to be a crime against humanity by a United Nations Resolution of 1946, followed by the adoption of a Convention in 1948. The Australian practice of Indigenous child removal involved both systematic racial discrimination and genocide as defined by international law. Yet it continued to be practised as official policy long after being clearly prohibited by treaties to which Australia had voluntarily subscribed.

Most Australians, when confronted with the term `genocide', think of national socialism, the Holocaust or events in Africa of late. They do not think of happenings in their own country. Indeed, many Australians would be quite upset at the allegation that their relatives—that is, those nurses, police, public servants, welfare officers, missionaries and politicians of the time—were involved in acts of genocide.
Genocide is an internationally recognised crime. Article 2 of the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide defines it this way:
Genocide means any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy—
these are the important words: `with intent to destroy'—
in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group, as such . . .
Then it goes through a number of clauses. For the purposes of this contribution, the relevant clause is, `forcibly transferring children of the group to another group'. We are then told in Article 3:
The following acts shall be punishable: (a) genocide.
Article 4 goes on to say:
Persons committing genocide shall be punished, whether they are constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals.

If genocide did take place, as asserted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, then the corollary is that those responsible ought be charged with committing the crime of genocide. The convention is prescriptive. It says, `Those involved shall be punished.' Those to be punished include constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals. Would it therefore not stand to reason that those re sponsible be tried for this crime of genocide? That question was indeed put to Mr Sidoti of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission at estimates. His response, on page 110 of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee Hansard of 10 June, is somewhat illuminating. The comment was made:

I think some of these people may well have been very well motivated and would be horrified to think—most of them posthumously now—that they were somewhat engaged in an activity of genocide. I think the vast majority of them would feel absolutely horrified by that assertion, by that finding.
Mr Sidoti said:
I believe it is in that area that the question of intention does become relevant . . . intention will go to the issue of criminal liability . . .
I have left out a few words. The questioner continues to ask about the international treaty on genocide and says that it has its basis in criminality. Mr Sidoti then says:
My view is that they would be able to successfully defend such a charge if they pleaded intention and could demonstrate intention.
Then he goes on to say:

It is interesting. Perhaps as a last comment I can assure you that there was no single issue in this process that we argued more and longer about ourselves than this issue before we finally came to that conclusion—

that is, that genocide had been committed. So it is quite clear that that caused some considerable debate within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, and so it should have done. Unfortunately, I submit that they came to the wrong conclusion. If what Mr Sidoti says in the Hansard is right, then it is an interesting approach to the crime of genocide. The convention clearly says that you need to have the intention to destroy. So, if Mr Sidoti is prepared to admit that the intention is absent, you do not have the crime of genocide. But the consequence of that is, of course, as I have just said, that if there is no intention to destroy there is no genocide. As a result, the whole assertion of genocide comes crashing down. It is clearly unsustainable.

If it is sustained, it then needs a perpetrator. Who was the perpetrator? It appears that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would have us believe that there is such a thing as a crime without a perpetrator—a perpetratorless crime. If the crime was committed, the perpetrators ought be identified and charged. If you identify them and then say that they are all not guilty, then of course the crime was not committed. But the logical consequence is this: all our former Prime Ministers, as constitutional rulers, all our former Governors-General who are still alive today and—if you listen to Mr Mick Dodson, who believes genocide is still occurring in Australia today—the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the current Governor-General and all the other officials should be publicly identified and charged with this international crime of genocide; indeed, so should all the welfare workers and others involved.

Time is short. The fact is that the assertion of genocide has been specifically rejected in the past by Commissioner Elliott Johnston in the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I submit that it is still unsustainable today. The use of hyperbole and overpleading the case, I think, has unfortunately done a great disservice to the Aborigines who, through misguided policies, were taken from their parents. Unfortunately, if you overstate the case by claiming genocide, a lot of otherwise sympathetic people will become alienated. I believe that that is unfortunately what has occurred within the Australian context.
Can I also quickly make remarks on one of the recommendations. There are many recommendations that I would like to discuss more fully, but in recommendation 14 of the report we are told:
Monetary compensation be provided to people affected by forcible removal under the following heads.
7. Loss of native title rights.

Then we are told on page 309 that contributions to this national compensation fund `must be over and above existing funding'. I thought the indigenous land fund that this parliament set up in recent times was important. Allow me to indicate to the Senate why it was set up:

BREAK.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.
That has already been done, and unfortunately the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission did not seem to recognise that that has already been done. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Dental Health Program Importation of Cooked Chicken Meat

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate this evening to raise two matters which this government may have thought had gone away but have not. Firstly, I would like to deal with the removal of funds for the Commonwealth dental health program. Senators might remember that in the budget before the most recent one this government saw fit to stop funding under the Commonwealth dental health program, which substantially reduced the funding available to dental health clinics across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: These dental health clinics catered for particular groups which were badly off in our community: pensioners, the elderly and also those with health cards who are not in the financial position to be able to provide for their own dental care. These clinics provided that care at absolutely no cost to the recipients. I think they provided a very good service and a service very much appreciated by those who enjoyed it.

Back in 1994, when Labor was in government, a decision was made to provide this additional funding because the clinics as they then operated had insufficient funding and patients were waiting for long periods to have their dental needs dealt with. Certainly it was very successful and it reduced the waiting time to a reasonable period. By the time the scheme was operating at its maximum, people were having to wait for only a few days for emergency treatment and about only eight weeks for regular checkups, which most of us who are better off enjoy having when we choose, which was pretty good.

BREAK.PARA: Elderly people are now not getting access to dental care. The funds are limited, and they can get dental care only in an emergency. If they have an ulcer or are in major pain, they can get in within about seven days—if you are in severe pain, seven days is a very long time—for some emergency treatment. But, with the limited funds, emergency treatment does not mean what it used to mean. Now it means in many cases just pulling out the tooth concerned. Without those Commonwealth funds, that is all that is allowed for in relation to time and resources.

I would have thought that in this day and age even those people who are not very well off in our community are entitled to a decent level of dental care, and to me that means a bit more than just yanking out a tooth so that they are not in pain. The elderly and those people on social security with health cards are being treated in that way because of what this government has done to this funding.

Also, regular checkups, which I think should be a normal part of people's health care, are not being provided because, once those emergency cases have been dealt with, no time or resources are left to deal with that type of preventative care, which I think is a fundamental part of health care. Postcards like the ones I have here have been distributed from my office and sent directly back to the minister. I do not know the total number which have been sent back, but 192 people have provided them to me first—I have already tabled one lot; this is the second lot—and they are then sent on to the minister. I suggest to the Senate that that is just a small token of the number of people who are upset by this decision—and they come from only the area that I reside in, which is the central coast. I want to express very strongly to this government that a lot of pain and suffering is still being caused by that decision and a lot of people are extraordinarily angry.

The other issue I want to raise this evening is the importation of cooked chicken meat. This issue has been boiling over since before the election but, in terms of this government's treatment of it, it has been boiling over since the election last year. There has been no adequate response to the whole issue. In May last year there was some disarray when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) said that no decision had been made about the importation of cooked chicken meat while at the same time Senator Parer had said in this chamber that the decision had been made and AQIS was finalising the basis upon which cooked chicken meat could be imported from Denmark, the USA and Thailand, but that was finalised.

Thanks goodness the government saw fit to pull back from that decision, but I am fearful, as many people in the chicken industry are, that that was not really a change of position. It was merely a tactical delay in order to disguise the true effect of the government's decision, and I want to remind people of the true impact that the importation of cooked chicken meat could have.

A large number of jobs would be affected. About 900 families and 17,000 jobs Australia wide would be affected by the importation of cooked chicken meat. But, more importantly in my view, we will endanger both the purity of our food and our environment if we give up protecting Australia in these two areas by importing cooked chicken meat and we will never return to our original position. We are one of the few countries in the world that are not infested with newcastle disease. That may not seem like much to some people, but newcastle disease is an epidemic in many other countries and, once it gets into chicken stocks, it is almost impossible to remove. Secondly, not only does it affect domestic fowls but it can also infect bird life, particularly our native bird life, which has been protected for many years by our geographical isolation.

I feel very strongly that the importation of cooked chicken meat into this area does not provide us with an opportunity which is valuable enough to give up one of our disease free livestock for, particularly poultry. Nor does it provide us with a valuable enough opportunity to give up our protected and disease free native birds. I would like to remind the Senate of that issue.

I understand that the final decision on the Nairn report, the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee report on cooked chicken meat and the report of the National Task Force on Imported Fish and Fish Products is to come down sometime in the next few weeks, although the government has not been exactly clear when. I would hope that, when that occurs, the firm decision of this government will be that they will not allow the importation of cooked chicken meat.

There was a meeting just last month on the Central Coast, an area where probably 1,000 people are employed in the chicken industry. Five hundred people attended that rally. I have to say there was a lot of anger and a lot of upset people involved there. They wanted me very strongly to bring back the message to this Senate, the parliament and the government that they will not stand for the importation of chicken meat and that they will all be ensuring that the marginal seat of Robertson, which is now held by Jim Lloyd, will be held by the Labor Party after the next election if the government's decision on this issue is not changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about one of the important issues that Senator Neal just touched on—a matter of grave concern to many thousands of low income families and indeed, in many instances, to employers of people who are not able now to access dental health programs. The axing of the Commonwealth dental health program, which was set up in 1994, is already having a very significant and very serious effect in all states where we have been able to get statistics and look at the lengthening of the queues.

SPEECH.PARA: The program was set up in 1994 with the aim of reducing the geographic and financial barriers that prevented low income earners from receiving dental care, in some cases totally. The program injected additional funds into publicly funded dental services that were provided by the states and territories, and there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that it was a highly successful program. It was well targeted and it was very, very cost-effective.

BREAK.PARA: Last year's evaluation report on the Commonwealth dental health program by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare's Dental Statistics and Research Unit makes it very clear just how important and how valuable that program was. They found that, in the two years after the introduction of the Commonwealth dental health program, low income earners who received publicly funded dental care benefited in the following ways: firstly, they had a decreased need for extractions and fillings; secondly, they reported less frequent experiences of toothache; thirdly, they visited more often to actually get dental care; fourthly, they waited shorter times for their check‐ups; and, fifthly, they were more satisfied with the dental treatment they received.

The AIHW also identified some important flow on benefits, including the development of an oral health and dental policy focus at the Commonwealth level; an improvement in the monitoring and evaluation of adult access to dental care; and the support of a number of much needed ancillary projects, such as the remote and Aboriginal dental care demonstration projects and rural dental projects under the National Oral Health Advisory Committee. The AIHW concluded that, despite the Commonwealth dental health program resulting in improved dental care for card holders and low income earners, they still remained disadvantaged in terms of their oral health and their access to dental care.

So the abolition of the Commonwealth program has served to further increase that disadvantage. Indeed, I would argue it has been at a considerable long‐term cost to the entire Australian community. It was a short-sighted and ill‐considered move, and I note that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) himself said that he did not enjoy doing it. I suspect that the decision made by Dr Wooldridge was an uncomfortable one for him because he knew how successful that program was. He knew that he was party to actually scrapping one of the most successful health programs. It was a program delivering real and practical health benefits to a group of Australians who now face the loss of teeth as a direct consequence of their inability to pay for dental care.

Let us just take a quick look at who these people are. These are taken from some case studies that have been passed onto us by various public dental health services around the country. A woman in her 40s whose husband died several years ago and who is bringing up four children under 15 had been in pain for weeks before a neighbour told her about the free dental health service at her local community health centre. She needed several fillings. She needed two extractions. There was no way she could afford any of that in the private system. If she had not seen the community health centre's dentists at that time, she would have most certainly lost more teeth and, indeed, had serious problems as a consequence of gum disease.

A pensioner in his late 60s had a serious gum infection which had gone untreated for several weeks because he could not afford private dental care. When the public service treated him, they also noticed that his existing denture did not fit properly and were able to put him on the priority list for new dentures.

A 16-year-old homeless boy needed four teeth extracted because he had not been looking after his teeth. He had a drug problem and had not been to see a dentist in a long time. An unemployed sole parent had a 14-year-old daughter who had severe dental pain caused by a broken tooth which had remained untreated for days. The girl's mother was extremely distressed because she had no money to pay for dental treatment and had not known about the public dental service until referred by her general practitioner.

Finally, I have just one more example. A young man in his 20s with mental illness had been beaten up on the street and left with three broken teeth. He had actually asked a private dental clinic for help but, when they did the assessment and told him how much it was going to cost, he simply could not afford to pay. He was eventually treated as an emergency patient at a local community health centre after being directed there by the casualty department of a large hospital.

These are just a few case studies. Indeed, there are many case studies. There are people who have come into this country after surviving horrific dental torture. There are street kids, pensioners, unemployed people, veterans and people with disabilities. There are now people in remote and rural areas who have no access to dental care whatsoever. Indeed, there are hundreds of thousands of Australians on low income who now do not have access to proper dental care.

These are the people who have suffered from the Commonwealth government's decision to abandon the Commonwealth dental health program. These are the people who now are waiting for years to receive dental treatment. The waiting lists in most states have at least doubled, if not expanded further, and I think one of the hardest hit has been Tasmania.

Looking at this government's lack of interest and lack of any support in this budget, I would suggest that we are going to see the waiting lists increase. It is going to be this government that is responsible for considerable pain and suffering and, I would suspect, additional treatments in the public hospital system, which in the end is far more expensive for government, as a result of this very poor decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment tonight on the almost unprecedented attention given lately to the role of the judiciary, to what are the proper limits to judicial law making and to what are the proper restraints to be observed by judges in making public comments about non‐judicial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The first question has arisen against the background of what has been widely regarded as judicial trespass on the role of the legislature and parliament in decisions such as the Mabo judgment in 1992, the recent Wik case on pastoral leases and native title and the free speech cases—all of which have, to a significant degree, shifted political responsibility from the parliament to the High Court.

Widespread criticism of this sort of judicial activism led to the unprecedented move by the judges to declare their judicial independence this year and to set up their own advocate, the Judicial Conference of Australia, a national watchdog to safeguard judicial independence. I might add that the government has provided $60,000 funding to establish the secretariat and $40,000 to enable research to be carried out on judicial independence.

The doctrine of separation of powers is, of course, an issue of fundamental importance to the proper functioning of our democratic institutions. It is timely that we consider the sorts of issues aired recently in a speech by High Court Justice Michael Kirby, recognising the need to redefine the judicial function to prevent what he has described as `the uncontrolled idiosyncratic opinions of unelected judges'. His Honour's statement calls for a consideration of the proper boundaries between a reformist approach to the law, where legislation is ambiguous or where authority is simply outmoded or an inappropriate expression of contemporary standards on the one hand, and usurping the role of a democratically elected parliament to develop policy and pass laws on the other.

While recognising that there is a role for judges in reforming the law, the difficulty is that in the current adversarial system not only are judges not infallible, they do not and cannot adequately inform themselves of community values or the social and economic impact of decisions beyond the narrow confines of the particular case and the evidence the parties choose to put before the court.

For instance, we have not developed in our judicial system a mechanism such as the Brandeis brief, named after the famous Justice Brandeis of the US Supreme Court, who introduced the concept of the broad ranging impact statement able to be filed by third parties to a dispute. We can only wonder what might have been the effect on the court of an economic and social impact statement as to the likely consequences of finding that native title may coexist with pastoral leases or, for example, on the impact on legal aid resources of the High Court decision in Dietrich, where in practice prosecutions, especially for lengthy retrials, can be put seriously at risk by the requirement to provide legal representation at taxpayers' expense.

This said, there is a crucial role for judges of the High Court to question the appropriateness of rules that were apt for earlier generations and to interpret and develop the law within proper judicial constraints free from political interference. It is an entirely different matter when a judge ventures into the political arena in areas unconnected with the discharge of judicial responsibilities and comments publicly as a judge on controversial political issues.

There have been, of course, much quoted recent examples, including that of Mr Justice Nicholson, Chief Judge of the Family Court of Australia, commenting in an overseas forum on the stolen children report. The judge is reported as having claimed to have made his comments as chair of a convention on the rights of children and young people and not in his judicial role. He is reported as having said in an interview that he believed an apology on behalf of the Australian government would be an appropriate response and that there should be no legal reason why such an apology should not be given.

And herein lies the problem. Whatever personal views one might hold on the matter, it must be said that there are different points of view across the political spectrum about what might be an appropriate response to the stolen children report, and we have yet to see what the government's considered response will be.

The question is whether by engaging publicly in matters of political controversy a judge thereby undermines confidence in the administration of justice—that it will be impartial, fair and untainted by political controversy or bias.
What is the community to make of a judge who has made his or her views publicly known on controversial political matters under active policy consideration?

The judiciary in Australia has, I hasten to say, a proud record of impartiality. Not for one moment am I suggesting that any actual bias would follow from judges holding private views on contentious matters. But it is also the appearance of impartiality that underpins confidence in the administration of justice. Can the community be confident that a judge who has entered the political fray will act impartially if confronted with ideas or propositions he or she does not like?

Let me put it another way. The High Court has consistently refused to entertain applications for advisory judgments, no doubt because such a procedure is not within Commonwealth power. But if it were possible, the court would be constrained to act judicially to hear and consider arguments and to test propositions before coming to a considered view.

If, for instance, the court were asked to give an advisory opinion in respect of legal problems, if any, with respect to the 10‐point Wik plan, it would be done as an exercise of judicial power and not as a quasi‐political statement. There is a stark distinction, I suggest, between a judge weighing up evidence and commenting upon policy considerations as may impact on a case before him or her in the exercise of judicial function on the one hand and, on the other hand, making non‐judicial public statements about controversial political matters when clothed with judicial office. A judge still speaks with the authority and status conferred by judicial office whether chairing a convention or presiding in court.

It may be difficult for some to see the distinction and no doubt difficult for some judges to contain their non‐judicial utterances. These restraints on free speech might be regarded as but another personal cost of accepting a judicial appointment and making the splendid public contribution that judges usually make. Such restraints are, however, an essential safeguard in avoiding potential abuses of power and in maintaining public confidence in the courts and the independence of the judiciary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly, given the time remaining, on another issue that is affecting the Australian Capital Territory. I refer to the closure of the High Court on weekends and public holidays as a result of budgetary decisions, and would like to put my views on the record with respect to this particular course of events.

SPEECH.PARA: It has become quite clear since the budget that the process for the decision making regarding the closure of the High Court is one that is quite complex and rests perhaps not with the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) but with the processes within the High Court to close it. Nonetheless, this government must still bear the responsibility of the consequence of its budget cuts that have led to the closure of the High Court to the public on weekends and public holidays. It is on this basis that I wrote to the minister for territories as opposed to the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) to ask him to intervene on behalf of the ACT to make representations to ensure that this facility—this national institution—does indeed remain open.

I find myself doing this not from a party political point of view—a partisan point of view—but collectively with my colleagues who are representatives from all sides of the political spectrum. I do not think that comes about by any accident. It comes about because we all recognise the injustice of this closure and we all recognise that the implications of this decision could flow on to other national institutions.

So why is it important? The ACT at the moment is suffering a bit of a beating. I have spoken about that many times in this place. One of the planks in our economic platform here is, of course, tourism. And one of Canberra's great strengths as an economy is our role as the nation's capital. Within that role we are very proud to house the parliamentary triangle and the national treasures that are contained within the parliamentary triangle. The High Court is one such institution that falls within that definition. To close one national institution in that parliamentary triangle will detrimentally affect the ability of the ACT, the nation's capital, to sell itself and promote these national attractions as part of both our status as a national capital and our tourism potential.

I have had a number of arguments with various people with respect to this: will it make a difference whether or not the High Court is open? I believe it will, because of the symbolism of the message that it sends. Already I have had feedback from members of the Tourism Council who were visiting the region recently and who had heard on the national media that the High Court was, indeed, going to be closed to the public on weekends and public holidays. Their response was, `Well, Canberra's really shutting down, isn't it? This is just another nail in the coffin for you guys.' Already, at a national level, it is being perceived as yet another negative impact, another indictment on this government and its regard for the nation's capital. This can seriously damage our role and our ability to promote ourselves as a destination for both Australian and international travellers.

I would like to put on the record tonight a bipartisan plea, if you like, for this government to take whatever action is necessary to reverse this decision. I do not really care whether it is the minister for territories or the Attorney‐General who takes the decision—or how the process is reached—but someone needs to take all action possible to reverse this decision to ensure that Australians not only have access to this national institution, but have access to a crucial institution which symbolises Australians' access to justice.

Hardwood Woodchips—East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement Export Licences

I refer to your letter of 3 February 1997, seeking advice pursuant to section 30(3) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, concerning applications for Regional Forest Agreement export hardwood woodchip licences for Midway Wood Products, Harris Daishowa (Australia) and TJ Andrews Sawmills.

As you are aware, the Australian Heritage Commission has provided advice to the Prime Minister on the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement recently signed between the Victorian and Commonwealth governments.
A copy of the advice is at Attachment 1.

The Commission and its staff have been actively involved in the development of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement to ensure that due consideration has been given to the protection of the National Estate as part of this process. In addition, the Commonwealth and the AHC have signed a Memorandum of Understanding regarding the identification, conservation, review, monitoring and advice on national estate matters in East Gippsland.
A copy of the Memorandum is at Attachment 2.

With regard to the applications for woodchip licences, the Commission advises that the advice on the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement is applicable, and that separate advice is not required. This advice will also be applicable to other licences that are within the framework of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement.

This advice is based on the premise that the commitments made in the Regional Forest Agreement and the Memorandum of Understanding provide a sound basis for the ongoing conservation of the National Estate. The Commission will monitor the outcomes of the Agreement and will advise you further if this should not prove to be the case.

Dear Prime Minister
East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement between the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments

I refer to the letter of 20 September 1996 from the Hon Chris Miles on your behalf, seeking advice pursuant to section 30(3) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, concerning the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement between the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments.

The decision of government to enter into the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement with the State of Victoria is a decision which might affect to a significant extent places that are listed in the Register of the National Estate. It might also affect other places with national estate values identified through joint assessment with the Victorian Government.

The Commission notes that the advice sought in your referral is to cover all national estate values identified in the joint assessment of the National Estate in East Gippsland by the Commission and the Victorian Department of Natural Resources and Environment and documented in the following publications:

PARA.TAB: Methods Papers: East Gippsland and National Estate Assessment, Volume One—Natural Values (1996)
Methods Papers: East Gippsland and Central Highlands Joint Forest Projects, Volume Two—Cultural Values (1994)
Comprehensive Regional Assessment—East Gippsland—National Estate Report (1996)
publicly available plots of GIS coverages.

ANSWER.PARA: In preparing this advice, all of these values have been considered. It should be noted that the advice is provided only in relation to forestry activities and operations in the region and that the Commission will continue to provide advice on other Commonwealth actions in the region which may have an adverse effect on the National Estate.

The Commission has, for some time, been an advocate of the process of regional assessment that has led to this Agreement and is pleased to have worked co‐operatively with the Commonwealth and Victoria in this instance. The commission will continue to support the process.

The Commission notes, however, that some key stakeholders have chosen not to be part of the process. There is a need to actively explore ways of involving these stakeholders in future regional assessments.
Background

The Australian Heritage Commission and the Victorian Government have been working co‐operatively since 1992 on the joint regional identification and assessment of national estate values in the forested areas of East Gippsland.

The results of this identification and assessment were published in July 1996 as part of the Comprehensive Regional Assessment studies undertaken to provide the basis for the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement between the two governments.

The Commission and its staff have been actively involved in the development of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement to ensure that due consideration has been given to the protection of the National Estate as part of this process.
Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Australian Heritage Commission
The Commonwealth and the Commission have signed a Memorandum of Understanding regarding the identification, conservation, review, monitoring and advice on national estate matters in East Gippsland.
A copy of the Memorandum is at Attachment 1.
The Memorandum supports the Regional Forest Agreement by detailing the Commission's ongoing role, in partnership with the Commonwealth, in the forests of East Gippsland for the life of the Agreement.
Regional Forest Agreement for East Gippsland between the Commonwealth and Victoria
The Regional Forest Agreement for East Gippsland includes a commitment by the Commonwealth and Victoria to enhance protection of the National Estate.

Clause 12 of the Agreement states that "Parties will manage the National Estate in accordance with the provisions of the Agreement as detailed in Attachment 2". This attachment describes the arrangements that will be put in place for the listing, protection and management of national estate values in East Gippsland.
The commitments made by the Commonwealth in the Regional Forest Agreement are consistent with those made in the Memorandum of Understanding.
Protection of the National Estate
The Commission notes that the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement will provide enhanced regional protection for the National Estate. In particular:
. the identification and definition of the National Estate, based on the assessment of both natural and cultural values, has been significantly improved;

. the agreed national criteria for the inclusion in a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative (CAR) reserve system of wilderness (90% of the area of high quality wilderness that meets minimum area requirements); old growth (60% of old growth forest within each forest ecosystem and all viable examples of rare and depleted old growth) and forest community biodiversity (15% of the pre‐1750 distribution of each forest ecosystem) have been met in East Gippsland, resulting in regional protection for equivalent national estate values;

. national estate protection will be enhanced through the establishment of the CAR reserve system, as the tenure or zoning of a number of specific areas with national estate values will be changed to provide increased protection.
‐ Three areas of State forest will become Dedicated Reserves: Ellery Creek (National Park), Martins Creek (Flora and Fauna Reserve) and Goolengook (Flora and Fauna Reserve).

‐ The zoning of thirty‐one areas of State forest will be amended from either General Management Zone or Special Management Zone to Special Protection Zone, which will protect national estate values in those areas;

. recognising that the State forest component of the CAR reserve system may vary over the life of the Agreement, the Commonwealth and Victoria have agreed there will be no net deterioration in the protection of identified values. Any amendments to that component of the CAR reserve system which is in State forest, including those in which national estate values are represented, will only occur in accordance with the RFA;
. there will be public consultation on any proposed changes to the Forest Management Plan for the East Gippsland Forest Management Area. The Commission will be actively involved in this process;

. the maintenance and protection of national estate values will be one of the parameters considered in the assessment of any proposed zoning amendments to the Forest Management Plan for the East Gippsland Forest Management Area;

. the protection of rainforest will be enhanced as the new Martins Creek and Goolengook Flora and Fauna Reserves include significant areas of rainforest. Most stands in all National Rainforest Sites of Significance are now protected within Dedicated Reserves. All other rainforest, including a surrounding buffer, is excluded from timber harvesting;

. Victoria has included conservation principles, which were developed by the Commission in co‐operation with Victoria, in Section 6.4 of the Forest Management Plan for the East Gippsland Forest Management Area. These principles provide a regional framework for the preferred management of national estate values;

. endorsement by the Commonwealth and Victoria of the continuing joint preparation of a set of management guidelines, the Guidelines for the Management of Cultural Heritage Values in the Forest, Parks and Reserves of East Gippsland and agreement to finalise this document by June 1997. When completed, Victoria agrees to manage in accordance with the guidelines;

. involvement of indigenous groups in decision making will be improved. Victoria has undertaken to formalise a consultation, participation and negotiation mechanism with relevant indigenous groups to ensure the appropriate management of indigenous heritage in East Gippsland, including the maintenance of traditional and historic uses and values;
. the sensitivity and/or resilience of each national estate value identified in East Gippsland and on the current protection of each value has been agreed (Attachment 2);
. ongoing management decisions will include consideration of all identified national estate values;

. the advice of the Commission will be sought in relation to proposed actions which might adversely affect any national estate values in East Gippsland, notwithstanding that some of these values may be in areas that are not within the CAR reserve system and are not within places in the Register of the National Estate;

. a commitment by the Commonwealth and Victoria to develop a data agreement will ensure that datasets are maintained and that continuing access to datasets relating to national estate values and places is provided for the Commission and interested third parties;

. agreement by the Commonwealth and Victoria to assess the operation of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement in relation to the conservation of the National Estate as part of each five yearly review of the Agreement. The Commission will work co‐operatively with the Commonwealth as part of these reviews;

. opportunities for public input in the five yearly review of the Agreement to monitor progress under the Agreement. There will be public access to compliance reporting by Victoria and public involvement in any amendments to the Forest Management Plan and Codes of Practice. The Commission will work co‐operatively with the Commonwealth as part of these reviews.

On this basis, the Commission advises that national estate values will be protected regionally, subject to the effective implementation of the Regional Forest Agreement and the Memorandum of Understanding.

PARA.EMPHASIS: General impact of timber harvesting on national estate values

ANSWER.PARA: During the life of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement, timber harvesting will occur in areas outside the CAR reserve system, including in areas with national estate values.

The impact of harvesting in these areas will depend on the resilience of the values represented in the area and the implementation of ecologically sustainable forest management practices, including the application of legislative and management prescriptions.

Taking into account the enhanced regional protection afforded by the Regional Forest Agreement, the impact of harvesting for areas with national estate values in which timber harvesting occurs, will be as follows:
. where the values represented are generally robust to harvesting, harvesting is not considered to be incompatible with the maintenance of the value. Attachment 2—Category 1 details these values;

. where the values represented are sensitive to harvesting and not protected by specific prescriptions, timber harvesting may have a significant adverse local effect on national estate values, although the value should remain adequately protected at a regional level. Attachment 2—Category 2 details these values;

. where the values represented are sensitive to harvesting but are managed according to specific prescriptions directed at ensuring the maintenance of the value, timber harvesting is not considered to be incompatible with the maintenance of the value. Attachment 2—Category 3 details these values;

. where the values represented are sensitive to the effects of timber harvesting but due to the nature of the value or current forest management practices are excluded from areas to be harvested the exclusion of harvesting should ensure that the value will remain adequately protected. Attachment 2—Category 4 details these values.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Particular impact of timber harvesting on national estate values and places

ANSWER.PARA: During the life of the Agreement, timber harvesting will occur in a number of areas with extensive national estate values which are sensitive to harvesting. In these areas, harvesting will have a significant adverse local effect on these values. The areas are:
. Sandpatch (wilderness and flora refuge values)
. Thurra (succession and natural landscapes values and modelled values related to flora and fauna richness)
. Buldah/Quadra/Cobon (old growth, succession and natural landscapes values)
. Brodribb (part)/Sardine Creek (old growth, flora refuse, natural landscapes values)
. Cobberas/Mt Stewart (wilderness and flora refuge values).
Three existing national estate places—Croajingolong, Coopracambra and Rodger River—overlap marginally with some of these areas.

A high percentage of the national estate values in these areas and places are protected in the reserve system. Agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria on the establishment and enhancement of the CAR Reserve System will mitigate the effect of timber harvesting on these values at a regional level.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Impact of mining on national estate values and places

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission notes that the Agreement does not change existing restrictions on access to National Parks, Wilderness Parks, State Parks and Reference Areas for exploration and mining.

The Commission notes that exploration and mining in other parts of the reserve system will be permitted only where identified conservation values, including national estate values, are not incompatible with exploration and mining.
The Commission advises that many national estate values are not compatible with mining.

The Commission therefore considers that this restriction is essential and confirms that the maintenance of the conservation values for which the reserve system has been established will be crucial to the conservation of national estate values at a regional level.

In summary, the Commission's advice is that the decision of the Commonwealth to enter into the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement with the State of Victoria will result in enhanced protection for the National Estate in East Gippsland and will ensure that national estate values remain protected at a regional level for the life of the Agreement.
However, the Commission notes that some timber harvesting activities undertaken during the life of the Agreement will have a significant adverse local effect on national estate values.

This advice is based on the premise that the commitments made in the Regional Forest Agreement and the Memorandum of Understanding provide a sound basis for the ongoing conservation of the National Estate.

While these Agreements remain in place the Commission is confident that the National Estate will be regionally protected in East Gippsland. The Commission will monitor the outcomes of the Agreement and will advise you further if this should not prove to be the case.
Yours sincerely
Wendy McCarthy AO
Chair
Attachment 1

PARA.EMPHASIS: MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA AND THE AUSTRALIAN HERITAGE COMMISSION
PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATIONAL ESTATE VALUES AND THE LISTING OF NATIONAL ESTATE PLACES IN EAST GIPPSLAND

ANSWER.PARA: Purpose of Memorandum of Understanding.

1. This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) records the intentions of the Commonwealth and the Australian Heritage Commission (the Commission) regarding identification, conservation, review, monitoring and advice on national estate matters in the context of the East Gippsland Regional Forest Agreement (the RFA) between the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments.

2. The Commission and the Victorian Government have been working co‐operatively since 1992 on the joint regional identification and assessment (the joint study) of national estate values in forested areas in East Gippsland.

3. The Commonwealth and the Commission endorse the findings of this joint study and agree that national estate values exist as documented in publicly available plots of xxx coverage's and in the following published documents: Methods Papers: East Gippsland National Estate Assessment, Volume One—Natural Values (1996); Methods Papers: East Gippsland and Central Highlands Joint Forest Projects, Volume Two—Cultural Values (1994); and, Comprehensive Regional Assessment—East Gippsland—National Estate Report (1996).

4. The joint study has served to provide a regional framework for the identification and assessment of national estate values and has been incorporated into the RFA and the establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative (CAR) Reserve System.
Definition of Region
5. The area covered by this MOU is the East Gippsland Region as show in Map 1 of the RFA.
Duration of Memorandum of Understanding

6. This MOU takes effect upon signing by the parties and will remain in effect for the duration of the RFA, subject to ongoing satisfactory protection and management of the National Estate in East Gippsland as agreed in the RFA.
7. This MOU and its provisions are not intended to give rise to legally enforceable rights or obligations between the parties.

8. In the event that the Commission considers that the RFA fails to provide certainty for the agreed National Estate outcomes as outlined in the RFA, the Commission will, in writing, detail its concerns to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth agrees that it will raise with Victoria such concerns using the provisions of Clause 24 of the RFA.

9. In the event that Victoria does not satisfactorily address such concerns, or that the Commonwealth and the Commission disagree on the efficacy of any such subsequent actions, the Commission and/or the Commonwealth may consider withdrawing from this MOU.
Protection and Management of National Estate Values
10. The Commonwealth and the Commission note that the RFA and related assessments have resulted in enhanced protection for the national Estate in East Gippsland, including:
. significantly improved identification and definition of the National Estate, based on the assessment of both natural and cultural heritage values;

. establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative (CAR) Reserve System which is designed to ensure the conservation and protection of environmental and heritage values, with regional protection for national estate values that correspond with the CAR criteria for wilderness, old growth and forest community biodiversity;
. significantly improved off‐reserve management directed specifically towards the management of the National Estate;
. incorporation in the East Gippsland Forest Management plan of a set of conservation principles which provide a regional framework for the preferred management of national estate values;

. continuing joint preparation of a set of management guidelines, the Guidelines for the Management of Cultural Heritage Values in the Forests, Parks and Reserves of East Gipps land which the Commonwealth and Victoria have agreed to finalise by June 1997. When completed, Victoria has agreed to manage in accordance with these guidelines.

. an undertaking by Victoria to formalise a consultation, participation and negotiation mechanism with relevant Indigenous groups to ensure the appropriate management of Indigenous heritage in East Gippsland and including the maintenance of traditional and historic uses and values;
. agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria on the sensitivity and resilience of each national estate value identified in East Gippsland and on the current level of protection of each value.
Review and Monitoring the Management of the National Estate

11. The RFA commits the Commonwealth and Victoria to review the performance of the RFA every five years to check progress against established milestones and the extent to which obligations under the RFA have been met for the National Estate, in accordance with Clause 30 of the RFA.

12. The Commission agrees that it will work co‐operatively with the Commonwealth on the review of the National Estate, within the framework of the RFA five yearly review. In conducting this review, the Commonwealth will provide the Commission with:

. details of any amendments that have been made to the dedicated and informal components of the CAR Reserve System during the period under review and the effect of these amendments on the conservation of national estate values within the region;
. updated GIS coverage of national estate values in forest ares within the region taking into account the factors likely to have effected those values since the last review;
. notification of national estate places in the region known to have degraded national estate values;
. advice on whether management prescriptions are fulfilling the aims for which they were established with respect to protection of the National Estate;
. advice on whether the agreed categorisation of national estate values by sensitivity and resilience remains appropriate;
. details of the extent to which the agreed conservation principles have been included in park and forest planning processes and documents;
. advice on any recommended changes to the agreed conservation principles;

. a report on the operation of the Guidelines for the Management of Cultural Heritage Values in the Forests, Parks and Reserves of East Gippsland , including recommendations on any amendments that should be made to the guidelines to improve their effectiveness;
. advice on the effectiveness of processes established by Victoria for consultation with Indigenous communities; and
. advice on the extent to which the RFA and its monitoring processes have responded to changing forest conditions and increased scientific knowledge and understanding.
Listing of National Estate Places—Existing listings
13. The results of the joint study verify the National Estate significance of existing places in the Register of the National Estate.

14. The Commission undertakes to update by end 1997 the Statements of Significance and condition and description statements for all existing listings to incorporate the results of the Comprehensive Regional Assessments and to reflect the protection and management status of the areas.
Listings of National Estate Places—Listings arising from the Joint Study

15. The Commonwealth notes that the Commission's listing policy for the National Estate in East Gippsland is based on the unique circumstances arising from the joint study, the Comprehensive Regional Assessments and the Regional Forest Agreement, which together have identified and protected the National Estate in a regional context.
16. The Commonwealth endorses the Commission's policy decision on listing in East Gippsland which is at Attachment 1.

17. The Commonwealth and the Commission agree that the Commission will work co‐operatively with Victoria to finalise listing details and documentation by end June 1997. The Commonwealth notes that the Commission intends to proceed as follows:

. New listings in Dedicated Reserves (within the CAR Reserve System) and Informal Reserves, the boundaries of which are unlikely to change, should be distinct places and may be based on any national estate values.

. Listing of other national estate places outside the CAR Reserve System will be based on robust values, and those values that are protected by forest management. Areas of contiguous values will be listed as a single national estate place.

. Boundaries for listing National Estate places outside the CAR Reserve System will be based on identified values and will follow natural topographic features and/or roads as appropriate. In areas where a national estate value overlaps an Informal Reserve, but also continues outside the informal reserve, the full coverage of the value will be listed and it will be recognised that a portion of this value is protected.
. For places arising from the joint study, only places identified by the above principles will be listed in the Register of the National Estate.

18. The Commission notes that, the identification and assessment of national estate values for the CRA has been completed with the only exception being Indigenous heritage. The Commission will continue to work with Victoria and Indigenous communities in an effort to finalise this work.
Listing of National Estate Places—Future Listings

19. The Commission confirms that, based on the completed joint study, there is no evidence to identify additional large areas with national estate values in the forested areas of East Gippsland and that it therefore does not anticipate listing additional large places in the region.
20. The Commission and the Commonwealth confirm that they do not intend to undertake any further major regional studies of national estate values in forested areas in East Gippsland.

21. The Commission undertakes to advise the Commonwealth of any future nominations by third parties for the inclusion of places in forested areas in East Gippsland in the Register of the National Estate.

22. The Commonwealth and the Commission agree that the information and outcomes of the RFA will be used in assessing any such nominations and that any new research or information provided will be compared with the East Gippsland national estate database.

23. The Commonwealth and the Commission agree that the Commission will be responsible for carrying out the assessment of any such nominations and that the Commission will consult closely with the Commonwealth on such nominations.
24. The Commission undertakes to work co‐operatively with Victoria on these assessments and on the detail of any consequent listings.
ATTACHMENT 1
Statutory Advice under s30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975

25. Both parties have agreed that all identified national estate values will be considered in ongoing management decisions and that the advice of the Commission will be sought in relation to proposed actions which might adversely affect national estate values in East Gippsland, notwithstanding that some of these values may be in areas that are not within the CAR Reserve System and are not within places in the Register of the National Estate. Parties note that the Commission will take into account the outcomes of the RFA work in providing its advice and will continue to provide such advice in a regional context.

26. The Commonwealth and the Commission agree that any advice provided by the Commission in response to referrals under s30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 will cover all national estate values identified in the joint study.
27. The Commission notes that the RFA will reduce the number of such referrals.

28. The Commission undertakes to explore the delegation of this statutory advice function to an appropriate official in a State Agency for referrals related to forestry operations and activities in the region.
29. The Commission undertakes to develop operational guidelines for such referrals.
Research
30. The RFA commits the Commonwealth and Victoria to consult in the development of future research projects that may affect the RFA.

31. The Commonwealth undertakes to advise the Commission of any proposed research projects that relate to or impact upon national estate assessment methodologies, assessments, identification, listing, protection or management.
32. The Commonwealth undertakes to work cooperatively with the Commission on the terms of reference for any such projects.
Data Agreement
33. The RFA commits the Commonwealth to develop a data agreement with Victoria which addresses issues of data ownership and custodianship; archival lodging and access, use and maintenance of data.

34. The Commonwealth undertakes to consult with the Commission on the content of the data agreement and to ensure that the Commission will continue to have access to current datasets relating to national estate values and places.
35. The Commonwealth undertakes to ensure that the national estate values layers produced as part of the joint study will remain publicly available to interested third parties.

122nd meeting of the Australian Heritage Commission
Listing Policy for Regionally Assessed National Estate Values

. The Commission renewed its commitment to its regional approach in forests, recognising that it continues to provide an effective means of identifying the national estate significance of forests and supports the conservation of the National Estate.
The Commission's regional approach to forest conservation entails:
‐ the systematic identification of national estate values in forest regions;
‐ an assessment of the relative significance of values within a regional context;
‐ consideration of the protection of values within a regional context, not on a coupe by coupe basis;
‐ recognition of the need for a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest reserve system in the region;
‐ recognition that values outside the reserve system are managed for conservation within a regional context;
‐ an analysis of the sensitivity of values to proposed operations; and
‐ a regional, spatial and temporal consideration of the impact of proposed operations.
. The Commission considers that its involvement in the broader CRA/RFA program continues to have benefits for the National Estate resulting in:
‐ enhanced identification of the national estate significance of forests;
‐ increased understanding of the national estate significance of forests by all levels of government and community and industry groups; and
. The Commission determined that when considering listings arising from CRAs, it would be guided by the following principles:
‐ the independence of the Commission;
‐ the statutory requirements of the Act;
‐ the public transparency of the process;
‐ the Commission's capacity to exercise discretion;
‐ the Commission's commitment to the regional approach to forest identification and conservation; and

. The Commission decided that, in exercising its discretion in determining national estate listings in the regions covered by Regional Forest Agreements, it will recognise the unique regional process and context of the RFAs and the CRAs.
In particular, the Commission was guided by its expectation that the Regional Forest Agreements will result in:
‐ a significantly improved identification of the National Estate within each forest region;

‐ a substantial improvement in the protection of the National Estate, through increased reservation and/or a significant improvement in off‐reserve management directed specifically towards the management of the National Estate;
‐ an overall increase in forest reserves;
‐ a significant improvement in the ecological sustainability of forest management practices; and
‐ increased certainty of conservation outcomes.
Additionally, and to support these principles, the Commission considers a successful CRA/RFA program must have the following attributes:

‐ the full results of the CRAs, including the national estate assessments of all areas identified as having national estate values, are published and available to the community, in text, database and mapped form;
‐ There is appropriate consideration of national estate protection principles and management prescriptions;
‐ a rigorous and transparent CRA and RFA process;
‐ s30 advice is based on all identified national estate values;

‐ there is a recognition, in the Agreement, that all identified national estate values will be considered in ongoing management decisions, notwithstanding that some such values will not be a formal part of the CAR reserve system;
‐ there are appropriate performance indicators and monitoring and review processes;
‐ the overall regional outcome improves conservation of national estate values in the region;
‐ an enduring inter‐governmental agreement which the governments fully implement to achieve the expected protection outcomes.
. The Commission's policy stance, and its statutory advice, is dependent upon its consideration of the outcomes of each Regional Forest Agreement in relation to the above expectations and attributes.

. Within the CRA/RFA program, the Commission will continue to identify and record all areas of national estate significance which arise from the CRA assessments. The outcomes of this work, all areas identified as containing national estate values of significance, will be mapped and publicly available.

Within this context, the Commission considers that it would generally be appropriate to list all places containing national estate values which are protected by reservation, by reserve management prescription, by site exclusion, by consultation processes or other measures appropriate to the value, or which are robust and not affected by harvesting or other off‐reserve management regime or activity.

The Commission also considers that, within a CRA/RFA context, it would generally be inappropriate to list places which are outside the CAR reserve system and whose values are adequately protected regionally through the application of the above principles, while reserving the right to list selectively, and on an exceptional basis, already identified unprotected places of very high significance. The Commission also reserves the right to list any places identified in the future as a result of new information. The Commission will work cooperatively with the State agency on such listings.

. The Commission will monitor the outcomes of each RFA and, if in any region they fail to provide the regional level of protection anticipated, the Commission reserves the right to take action, including to list all identified areas.
Regional Forest Agreement: Section 30 Advice

. The Commission recognises that the active participation of State agencies in the CRAs and the agreement of State management agencies to conserve the National Estate in the region as part of its forest management responsibilities has the potential to significantly improve the identification and conservation of the National Estate.

. Therefore, the Commission has decided to explore options for the delegation of its section 30 responsibility to an appropriate official in a State agency. The Commission decision has been taken in light of the following:
‐ the jointly developed national estate database would be the starting point for the provision of advice on proposed activities in the region;
‐ the development of advice would also be guided by the jointly agreed protection principles;
‐ the development of guidelines to assist in determining whether a section 30 referral is required:
‐ the development of indicative section 30 advice for values of varying sensitivity;
‐ the delegation could be withdrawn by the Commission if warranted.

. The Commission also determined that, should the option of delegation be accepted by the State, familiarisation with the processes and requirements and a trial period of delegation would be appropriate.
Identification, Integration and Protection of National Estate Values
. The Commissioners noted the information provided and endorsed the continuing process to develop protection principles, integration rules and advice guidelines.
Regional Forest Agreement AHC Commitments
. The Commission discussed the Attachment entitled Draft RFA Commitments.

. The Commission agreed that, in general, the commitments outlined were an appropriate way for the Commission to contribute to the certainty of RFA outcomes relating to conservation (including conservation of the national estate) and production.

. The Commission emphasised that it would remain an active participant in ongoing monitoring and review of the operation of the RFA and, in that context, would reconsider its position should the RFA fail to achieve the conservation outcomes in relation to the National Estate.

‐ are based on the sensitivity and resilience of each value, the extent and/or regional rarity of value, its relative significance, and reserve design and/or management considerations.
Statutory and Other Advice
. For the purposes of formulating its statutory and other advice, the Commission:
‐ recognises that there will be fewer Commonwealth decisions in the post‐RFA era and therefore fewer s.30 referrals;

‐ will use as the basis for the provision of advice in the future, the full database containing all CRA assessments results (which constitutes the best initial information resource for the purposes of s.30 advice);
‐ will take into account:
. national estate protection principles and management prescriptions,
. effects of the proposal on values, spatially and over time;
. RFA protection regime;
‐ will provide greater certainty by developing:
. operational guidelines for determining whether s.30 referral is warranted;
. clear process for formulating s.30 advice, together with indicative advice;
‐ will prepare its s.30 advice consistent with these guidelines and in consultation with the State land management agency;
‐ will delegate to an appropriate office holder within a State agency the Commission's s.30 function for the RFA region, noting that the delegation can be withdrawn by the Commission, if warranted.
Monitoring and Review
. The Commission will undertake, to the extent possible, continuous improvement in its methods with a view to:
‐ improving data collection, storage and analysis;
‐ refining/restating protection principles to improve clarity, effectiveness and implementability;
‐ ensuring efficiency and effectiveness of prescriptions in maintaining values;
‐ making the s.30 advice formulation more consistent and transparent;
‐ making all aspects of these activities responsive to advances in scientific understanding.
. The Commission will participate actively in the review and monitoring arrangements as detailed within the RFA.

‐ Should the RFA fail to provide certainty for the agreed conservation outcomes, the Commission will review the appropriateness of these commitments in relation to the identification and conservation of the National Estate, and reserves the right to take appropriate action, including to list areas identified as having national estate values but not already listed.
