ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Representations on behalf of Mr and Mrs Latona

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a letter concerning Mr R and Mrs M Latona, dated 30 August 1994, from the then Shadow Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Howard) to the then Attorney‐General (Mr Lavarch), in which he stated:
My purpose in writing is to put it to you, in the strongest possible terms, that this matter is deserving of a sensible negotiated settlement. . .
I believe great injustice has occurred. Mr & Mrs Latona do not have the resources to properly litigate the matter. . .

I ask that you give sympathetic consideration. I, along with Mr & Mrs Latona's solicitor, would be happy to attend any conference you might suggest with an appropriate senior officer in your department or your good self.
(1) Does the Prime Minister still hold those views expressed in that letter; if not, why not.
(2) Did the Prime Minister ever attend a conference as suggested in the letter; if so, when; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Prime Minister still consider that a `great injustice' has incurred.

(4) Does the Prime Minister intend to pursue the matter via the Attorney‐General to address the specific injustices that the Prime Minister agrees have occurred to Mr and Mrs Latona; if so, how; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)—(4) The views expressed in my letter of 30 August 1994 to the Attorney‐General were based on information provided to me by Mr and Mrs Latona. The purpose of that letter was to convey concerns about the case to the then Attorney‐General in an attempt to have the matter resolved in a sensible manner. Neither the then Attorney‐General nor the then Minister for Justice, who responded to my letter on 2 November 1994, took up the suggestion of a meeting.

While Mr and Mrs Latona's concerns are understandable, the matter was carefully considered by the current Attorney‐General in response to representations made on behalf of Mr and Mrs Latona in 1996. The Attorney‐General has advised me that the Official Trustee administered Mr and Mrs Latona's estate in a responsible manner and that no injustice was done to them in that process. In these circumstances, while I understand that Mr and Mrs Latona still feel a sense of grievance, there is no further action I can properly take.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Victorian Office of Housing has sold off more than 1,000 public houses in the past 18 months and that a further 30 houses have been earmarked for sale across several other inner city suburbs.

(2) Given that, under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, the States receive capital grants to build and maintain public housing units, has the Minister sought an explanation from the Victorian Government as to: (a) why these houses have been sold; and (b) what has been done with the proceeds of the sale.

(3) Can a list be given of the number of: (a) public houses that have been sold or demolished in the past 12 months; (b) public houses by State which have been sold; (c) new public housing units which have been built nationally in the past 12 months; and (d) new public housing units in each State.
(4) How many public housing units does the Minister consider adequate given that there are 235,000 people waiting for public houses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the Victorian Office of Housing Strategic Plan.
(2) (a) No. Management of public housing assets is the responsibility of States and Territories.
(b) The 1996 Commonwealth State Housing Agreement requires the proceeds of asset sales to be retained for the provision of housing assistance.
(3) Actual figures for the past 12 months are not available.In the twelve months to 30 June 1996:
(a) 6020 public housing properties were sold or demolished;
(b) public housing properties sold by State:
NSW—690; Victoria—473; Queensland—111;
WA—477; SA—1075; Tasmania—39; ACT—64; NT—187; Australia—3116.
(c) 5818 properties were constructed out of a total addition of 9746; and
(d) new public housing units in each State
NSW—3509; Victoria—2052; Queensland—2067; WA—1307; SA—488; Tasmania—108; ACT—175; NT—40; Australia—9746.

(4) The composition and management of public housing waiting lists is complex and the length of waiting lists is not necessarily a valid measure of demand for public housing per se. For example, the Australian Institute of Family Studies report, Housing Across the Family Life Course (1996), found that, of those surveyed, 42 per cent of those on housing waiting lists would prefer private rental.

Given the recent developments in housing reform and the extent of State‐specific factors and other variables in the demand for public housing, it is not sensible for the Commonwealth to make a unilateral judgement about an adequate number of public housing units.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund will be allocated to the farm forestry program, in addition to the $22 million already identified.
(2) Will any other money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund be used for commercial plantation establishment, if so: (a) under what programs; and (b) how ml]ch.
(3) What conditions are applied to the recipients of funding under the farm forestry program, in particular are recipients prohibited from clearing native vegetation to establish plantations.
(4) Who is eligible for grants: (a) individual farmers, (b) plantation-growing companies, and (c) State plantation or forestry agencies.
(5) How are public and private benefits evaluated in making grants.

(6) Have any applications been received from the following for farm forestry or plantation establishment grants under the Natural Heritage Trust Fund: (a) Victorian Plantations Corporation, (b) Harris-Daishowa and (c) North Forest Products; if so can the following information for each application be provided: (i) date, (ii) location, (iii) purpose for which the grant is sought, (iv) area to be planted (v) amount requested and (vi) whether the application has been accepted or rejected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The amount of money available for farm forestry activities is still the subject of discussion between myself and Senator Hill.

(2) The National Partnership Arrangements 1997-98 outline the purposes for which funds under the Farm Forestry Program will be made available. In relation to tree planting, funds will be provided for establishing and managing strategic regional plantation and farm forestry demonstrations and trials. Proposals to establish demonstrations should show how these will be used to catalyse development and support extension, research and monitoring strategies. It is not intended that funding be used solely to support the planting of trees on individual properties without significant public benefits.

(3) Contractual conditions applied to recipients of funding under the Farm Forestry Program (FFP) will be similar to those applies to other Trust programs. The objective of the FFP is to promote wood production on cleared agricultural land, and where possible, to integrate commercial tree growing with other agricultural land uses.
Under the Trust, projects which are inconsistent with the principles of national strategies and which are not in the spirit of the NHT will not receive funding.

(4) Eligibility for funding under the Trust is not restricted. Under the National Partnership Arrangements, State and territory agencies can apply for funding under all programs. In addition, regional organisations, local governments, non-government organisations, educational institutions and industry are eligible to apply under the Farm Forestry Program.

The Farm Forestry Program aims to foster a regionally integrated approach to farm forestry by working in partnership with the States, local government, regional development organisations, industry, landholders and Landcare and community groups. Individual farmers are therefore eligible to contribute to a wider regionally integrated application lodged by these organisations.

(5) An intensive assessment process, involving the consideration of proposals by Regional Assessment Panels, Technical Assessment Panels and State Assessment Panels, has been established in conjunction with each state to evaluate the relative merits of applications against Trust and program guidelines. "Direct funding for commercial activities" is listed in the National Partnership Arrangements 1997-98 as an activity which is ineligible for funding.

Activities on private land may be funded, taking into account the amount of public benefit received relative to the private benefit derived from the activity. Individuals who are direct beneficiaries of Trust programs will be expected to make complementary efforts to contribute to the project being funded to the extent of the private benefit they derive.
(6) I am not aware of any applications from Victorian Plantations Corporation, Harris-Daishowa or North Forest Products. Applications lodged
under Community Group and National Partnership Arrangements are received in the first instance by relevant State agencies and not the Commonwealth.
